We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:
  1. Ask questions! The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).
  2. Edit questions and answers wiki-style. Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors).
  3. Add a followup to comment or ask further questions. To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.
  4. Go anonymous. Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.
  5. Tag your posts. It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.
  6. Format code and equations. Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.
  7. View and download class details and resources.
Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place! Welcome to our discussion board! You can use this board to can communicate with your fellow students and the instructional team about problems related to MATH 136.

Please read the following rules that we will use to improve our Piazza experience. 

 

1. Be courteous and respectful in your posts and replies.
This discussion board will be monitored. All inappropriate and offensive posts (e.g. giving away assignment solutions, using abusive language, etc.) will be removed. Further actions may be taken against offenders.  Please post in English so that everyone can understand. 

2. Search before you post.
Be sure to read the other posts and announcements on LEARN before posting a question. Very often the question you want to ask has been asked already. Do a quick search for the problem and see the previous discussions. If your question hasn't been answered, ask away.

3. Be specific in your questions.

Do your best to ask specific questions.  Don't ask vague questions looking for hints.  

 

4. Tag/Title/File your post:

Tags/folders are useful to keep things organized and are very helpful when searching for questions. The tags/folders are arranged as follows:

- one tag for each of the Written Assignments

- one tag for each extra practice set

- tags for the midterm, final, logistics

- the tag "tips" will be used for study tips that the instructors will post throughout the term

 

5. Help each other out.
Feel free to post replies to other students' questions. Do not worry too much about being right or wrong - if you are wrong, the instructional team will correct you. The best use of Piazza is to share your ideas and learn from your mistakes.

Don't be shy to post, you will be the only one losing out if you don't participate.  You always have the option to post anonymously if you are nervous about asking or answering questions in front of your peers.  Your post will be anonymous to other students, but it will not be anonymous to the instructional team. 

 

6. Maintain academic integrity.
Piazza is a tool to help students and not a place to share answers to assignment questions.  We want to encourage asking questions and having students answering them as well, but we ask that you be mindful of sharing too much when it comes to assignment questions. 

If you are ever worried about posting too much information, feel free to make  a private post to the instructors and then they will repost it publicly if it is not too specific or answer it privately if it is too specific.

If you are ever worried about posting too much information, feel free to make  a private post to the instructors and then they will repost it publicly if it is not too specific or answer it privately if it is too specific.

 

Posting Mathematical Notation on Piazza

 

Piazza has a wonderful feature that lets users type in mathematics into the browser. To write a line of mathematics, start with two dollar signs and then input LaTeX commands concluded by two more dollar signs. For a list of LaTeX commands,

 

https://www.artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/LaTeX:Symbols

 

should get you started. If you can't find your symbol, try drawing it on

 

http://detexify.kirelabs.org/classify.html

 

As an example, the command

 

\dfrac{2}{\sin^{2}x+\cos^2x}= 2 will appear as

$$\dfrac{2}{\sin^{2}x+\cos^2x}= 2$$ 

after bookending it with two dollar signs.

Feel free to try to post a student reply or follow up to this comment to practice displaying some mathematics.

"Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Typing Linear Algebra in Piazza", "created": "2024-04-12T19:03:27Z", "content": "

Quick Reference Guide in the "followup discussions" below

This is a quick introduction on how to type Math in Piazza using LaTeX. If you're going to type something in LaTeX on here, you need to encapsulate it in two pairs of dollar signs.

So to write something like a vector $$\vec{v}$$, you need to write 

$$\vec{v}$$


If you use the Rich text editor, there's also a f(x) button in the toolbar that gives you shortcuts for lots of LaTeX functions. It's a good way to learn how to type some things. However, you may find it quicker (now or later on) to type things in yourselves.

Here are the main commands:

1) \bmatrix

  • Use this to create vectors or matrices
  • Separate elements of a given row with &
  • End a row with \\ and then hit enter

For example, the matrix $$\begin{bmatrix} 3&7&8\\ -3&6&1\\ 2&2&5\\ 4&-4&-1 \end{bmatrix} $$
is typed in as 

$$\begin{bmatrix}
3&7&8\\
-3&6&1\\
2&2&5\\
4&-4&-1
\end{bmatrix}
$$


A column vector is just a bmatrix with one element per row, so
$$\begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 5 \\7 \end{bmatrix}$$
is easily typed in one line as

$$\begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 5 \\7 \end{bmatrix}$$


2) \vec

  • puts an arrow on something
  • encapsulate the object getting an arrow with { }

For example,
$$\vec{u}$$
$$\vec{v}$$
$$\vec{w}$$
are typed in as

$$\vec{u}$$
$$\vec{v}$$
$$\vec{w}$$


3) \rightarrow

  • makes an arrow pointing to the right, used in functions declaring domain and codomain
  • $$\rightarrow$$


4) superscripts

  • use ^ and then type the number
  • if that number has more than one character (eg -1 or 15), you need to use ^{ } 

For example,
$$x^2$$
$$P^{-1}$$
$$A^{153}$$
are typed in as

$$x^2$$
$$P^{-1}$$
$$A^{153}$$


If you forget the { }, then you get funny looking stuff like
$$P^-1$$
$$A^153$$

$$P^-1$$
$$A^153$$

So don't forget those braces!

5) Sets! If you want to type { } in LaTeX, you need to use \{ and \}.
So
$$\{ \vec{v}\in\mathbb{R}^2~:~A\vec{v}=\vec{0}\}$$
is written as 

$$\{ \vec{v}\in\mathbb{R}^2~:~A\vec{v}=\vec{0}\}$$


6) Special sets! You just saw $$\mathbb{R}$$ written above.  That "\mathbb" stands for "Math Blackboard Bold", which is why we have these symbols for sets of integers, rationals, reals, and complex numbers. Just put braces around what you want to make into its math symbol. So
$$\mathbb{R}$$ (real numbers)
$$\mathbb{Q}$$ (rational numbers)
$$\mathbb{Z}$$ (integers)
$$\mathbb{N}$$ (natural numbers)
$$\mathbb{C}$$ (complex numbers)
are written as

$$\mathbb{R}$$ (real numbers)
$$\mathbb{Q}$$ (rational numbers)
$$\mathbb{Z}$$ (integers)
$$\mathbb{N}$$ (natural numbers)
$$\mathbb{C}$$ (complex numbers)


7) Norm! Surround a vector by \| on either side. So $$\|\vec v\|$$ is written as

$$\|\vec{v}\|$$


8) A few other symbols and features:

dot product\cdot$$\cdot$$
cross product\times$$\times$$
fraction\frac{a}{b}$$\frac{a}{b}$$
nicer looking fraction\dfrac{a}{b}$$\dfrac{a}{b}$$
square root\sqrt{x}$$\sqrt{x}$$
nth root\sqrt[n]{x}$$\sqrt[n]{x}$$
subscriptsA_{12}$$A_{12}$$
calligraphic font\mathcal{B}$$\mathcal{B}$$ (used for bases)

If you can't find your symbol, try drawing it on

 

http://detexify.kirelabs.org/classify.html

\end{bmatrix}
$$


A column vector is just a bmatrix with one element per row, so
$$\begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 5 \\7 \end{bmatrix}$$
is easily typed in one line as

$$\begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 5 \\7 \end{bmatrix}$$


2) \vec

  • puts an arrow on something
  • encapsulate the object getting an arrow with { }

For example,
$$\vec{u}$$
$$\vec{v}$$
$$\vec{w}$$
are typed in as

$$\vec{u}$$
$$\vec{v}$$
$$\vec{w}$$


3) \rightarrow

  • makes an arrow pointing to the right, used in functions declaring domain and codomain
  • $$\rightarrow$$


4) superscripts

  • use ^ and then type the number
  • if that number has more than one character (eg -1 or 15), you need to use ^{ } 

For example,
$$x^2$$
$$P^{-1}$$
$$A^{153}$$
are typed in as

$$x^2$$
$$P^{-1}$$
$$A^{153}$$


If you forget the { }, then you get funny looking stuff like
$$P^-1$$
$$A^153$$

$$P^-1$$
$$A^153$$

So don't forget those braces!

5) Sets! If you want to type { } in LaTeX, you need to use \{ and \}.
So
$$\{ v\in\mathbb{R}^2~:~Av=\vec{0}\}$$
is written as 

$$\{ v\in\mathbb{R}^2~:~Av=\vec{0}\}$$


6) Special sets! You just saw me write $$\mathbb{R}$$.  That "\mathbb" stands for "Math Blackboard Bold", which is why we have these symbols for sets of integers, rationals, reals, and complex numbers. Just put braces around what you want to make into its math symbol. So
$$\mathbb{R}$$ (real numbers)
$$\mathbb{Q}$$ (rational numbers)
$$\mathbb{Z}$$ (integers)
$$\mathbb{N}$$ (natural numbers)
$$\mathbb{C}$$ (complex numbers - not in course)
are written as

$$\mathbb{R}$$ (real numbers)
$$\mathbb{Q}$$ (rational numbers)
$$\mathbb{Z}$$ (integers)
$$\mathbb{N}$$ (natural numbers)
$$\mathbb{C}$$ (complex numbers - not in course)


7) Norm! Surround a vector by \| on either side. So $$\|v\|$$ is written as

$$\|v\|$$


8) A few other symbols and features:

dot product\cdot$$\cdot$$
cross product\times$$\times$$
fraction\frac{a}{b}$$\frac{a}{b}$$
nicer looking fraction\dfrac{a}{b}$$\dfrac{a}{b}$$
square root\sqrt{x}$$\sqrt{x}$$
nth root\sqrt[n]{x}$$\sqrt[n]{x}$$
subscriptsA_{12}$$A_{12}$$
calligraphic font\mathcal{B}$$\mathcal{B}$$ (used for bases)

If you can't find your symbol, try drawing it on

 

http://detexify.kirelabs.org/classify.html

Additional symbols can be found 

https://artofproblemsolving.com/wiki/index.php/LaTeX:Symbols

and 

https://tug.ctan.org/info/undergradmath/undergradmath.pdf

[{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-08T15:39:39Z", "content": "

The geometric interpretation of a vector $$\begin{bmatrix} \\ v_1 \\ v_2 \\ v_3 \\ v_4 \end{bmatrix}$$ is a directed line segment from 

the initial point O (the origin) to a terminal point whose coordinates are $$(v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4)$$ , and the same applies for

higher-dimensional vectors. However, you can't draw them.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-08T15:38:38Z", "content": "

The geometric interpretation of a vector $$\begin{bmatrix} \\ v_1 \\ v_2 \\ v_3 \\ v_4 \end{bmatrix}$$ is a directed line segment from 

the initial point, typically the origin, to a terminal point whose coordinates are $$(v_1, v_2, v_3, v_4)$$ , and the same applies for

higher-dimensional vectors. However, you can't draw them.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwea27oxg6a4", "lkqwekngmbzga"], "children": [], "id": "lr538537cky3qd", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I believe it's the same way you represent vectors in R^2, just just now with more coordinates
A vector [ 1 2 3 4 ] will be (1 2 3 4) geometrical, since you will now have 4 axis as opposed to 2 axis in R^2

I believe you can draw them on a graph with 4 axis (4D graph) since you can draw in 3D for R^3

Do correct me if I am wrong :)
", "created": "2024-01-08T15:41:32Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xiangru Mo", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwea27oxg6a4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I doubt you'll be able to draw 4D or higher vectors as they're impossible to properly visualise. 3D is also not straightforward, but is still possible.", "created": "2024-01-08T15:47:49Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xiangru Mo", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwea27oxg6a4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwea27oxg6a4"], "id": "lr53jydfriwj2", "updated": "2024-01-08T16:34:14Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "True, but the fact that R^4 vectors exist geometrical, doesn't that mean they can be represented geometrically, not necessarily a graph but there must exist some representation for them", "created": "2024-01-08T15:51:42Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xiangru Mo", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwea27oxg6a4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwea27oxg6a4"], "id": "lr53oxvuuub4u1", "updated": "2024-01-08T16:34:15Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "@blake
Is it possible to plot let's say R^4 on the graph below? Do we have planes/surfaces in R^4 just like in R^3?

", "created": "2024-01-08T16:15:20Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xiangru Mo", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwea27oxg6a4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwea27oxg6a4"], "id": "lr54jcbiza2lj", "updated": "2024-01-08T16:34:15Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "As long as you have 4 axes which are all perpendicular to each other, you can plot 4-dimensional vectors by ascribing each entry of the vector one of the axes.

If you can imagine 4 perpendicular vectors in your mind, then that would certainly be one way to do it. I can't, so for 4 or more dimensions, I typically stick to a strictly algebraic representation.

Most often in mathematics, examples in 3 dimensions tend to generalize to higher dimensions, so finding a geometric explanation for why or why not something works in 3 dimensions and asking why or why not it generalizes to 4 or more dimensions is often more practical than trying to find a direct geometric representation.", "created": "2024-01-08T16:30:03Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xiangru Mo", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwea27oxg6a4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwea27oxg6a4"], "id": "lr55292ey7475a", "updated": "2024-01-08T16:34:17Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "To my understanding, the whole point of representing vectors algebraically is to represent as high as n dimensions, far more than what can be geographically represented. So like in theory yes u could graph it in 4D and even for higher dimensions, but there's no point in even considering geometric approaches for that since we have the algebraic representation, and since we geometrically only have access of up to 3D. This is just my current understanding of it so I could be wrong as well. ", "created": "2024-01-08T18:14:52Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lr58t27qcrk4rv", "updated": "2024-01-08T18:14:52Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "surely there is some way to simplify a 4d vector into something that can be drawn. Maybe in the same way that a 3d space or vector or point or something like that can be represented as the combination of two separate 2d planes/vectors, with one plane being the "top view" and the other being the "front view", there is a way to do something similar for 4d? or is 4d different?", "created": "2024-01-08T20:29:54Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_3", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lr5dmpldjul5tk", "updated": "2024-01-08T20:29:54Z", "config": {"editor": "plain"}}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwea27oxg6a4"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lr53buw65j634", "updated": "2024-01-08T20:29:54Z", "config": {}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-08T15:52:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xiangru Mo", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwea27oxg6a4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hbsg02xli8p54o", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-08T15:52:36Z", "content": "We don't! We use the geometrical representation in $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ and $$\mathbb{R}^3$$ to motivate results in $$\mathbb{R}^n$$, $$n\geq 4$$, which we prove completely algebraically. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwea27oxg6a4"], "children": [], "id": "lr53q38yc4e6qg", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lr52yp8bpoe4p3", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 7, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456370711, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I highly suspect your instructor will draw a picture which will make this all make sense.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdl9os1tne"], "children": [], "id": "lr53ou68ijy5g7", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-09T05:03:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-09T05:03:52Z", "content": "

No new picture but here is a picture I took from the course notes on Learn (:

\n

The projection of $$\\vec v$$ onto $$\\vec w$$ is the vector you get if you literally "squash" $$\\vec v$$ onto the line drawn out by $$\\vec w$$. The key point here is that in the way that it is "squashed", the angle where the red arrow meets the green arrow is always a right angle (this is what is being asked to shown).

The perpendicular of $$\\vec v$$ on $$\\vec w$$ is the remainder of what's left, so that

\n

$$\\text{proj}_{\\vec w}(\\vec v) + \\text{perp}_{\\vec w}(\\vec v) = \\vec v$$

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lr5vzo6v7vj5zt", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lr53kdqpxu7x0", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456371766, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Recall that for $$\vec x, \vec y \in \mathbb R^3$$, $$\vec z := \vec x \times \vec y$$ satisfies:

a) $$\vec z \cdot \vec x = 0$$ and $$\vec z \cdot \vec y = 0$$
b) $$\vec y \times \vec x = -\vec z = -\vec x \times \vec y$$
b) if $$ \vec x, \vec y$$ are nonzero, then $$\|\vec z\| = \|\vec x \| \|\vec y\| \sin \theta$$ where $$\theta$$ is the angle between $$\vec x$$ and $$\vec y$$

Suppose we want to extend the cross product to other dimensions. In $$\mathbb R^2$$, suppose you have nonzero $$\vec x, \vec y \in \mathbb R^2$$ where $$\vec x$$, $$\vec y$$ are not collinear with the origin (imagine $$\vec x, \vec y$$ do not have the same direction up to positive or negative). It turns out that the only vector which is orthogonal to both $$\vec x$$ and $$\vec y$$ is the zero vector (I challenge you to think about why this might be the case and why it changes if $$\vec x, \vec y$$ are collinear with the origin). 

In 3 dimensions, for nonzero vectors $$\vec x, \vec y$$ which are again not collinear with the origin, it turns out there is always exactly a line which is orthogonal to both $$\vec x, \vec y$$.

Here, I've drawn $$\vec x$$ and $$\vec y$$ as blue and red, on the axis to make it clear where they point. The pink line represents all vectors which are orthogonal to both $$\vec x$$ and $$\vec y$$.

If we want to fix the magnitude of this vector, you would be able to identify exactly two vectors on this line which have the right magnitude (one going in each direction of this line). Then comes in the right-hand rule, where we need to uniquely identify which of these two vectors we give to the cross product. This unique choice always satisfies the property of skew-symmetry (think about what $$\vec x \times \vec y$$ and $$-\vec x \times \vec y$$ each represent).

However, in more than 3 dimensions, there is no longer a line which is orthogonal to both $$\vec x$$ and $$\vec y$$ but rather a higher dimensional space: for instance, in 4 dimensions, there is a plane of vectors which are all orthogonal to both $$\vec x$$ and $$\vec y$$. By specifying a specific magnitude $$(\|\vec x\| \| \vec y\| \sin \theta$$), you could identify a "disc" of vectors on the plane with this magnitude. At this point, you would need a much more sophisticated rule to identify which vector on this disc you want to uniquely assign to the cross product, as there are now an infinite number of vectors on this disc, as opposed to the two options in 3 dimensions.

So, in general, the cross product tends to only be used in 3 dimensions.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 20, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-09T14:16:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lr6fqso43m47b0", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-09T14:16:50Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lr6fqso0zpi7az", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-01-09T15:37:10Z", "cid": "lr6im3qbu4f3ny", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Study Horizontally", "created": "2024-01-09T14:16:50Z", "content": "

I will be posting "tips" from time to time this semester.  They will not be as often as last semester in MATH 135, but I hope they will be helpful.  These tips are my own opinion and I do not speak on behalf of all the instructors.  At times other instructors may disagree with my advice and I hope they will post their ideas as well. 

 

My first tip is one that I posted in MATH 135, but I think it’s a great one to consider as you are starting a new semester. 

 

I know it can be very easy to fall into the trap of having a "MATH 136 day", a "MATH 138 day", and a "CS 116/136 day" and so I want to encourage you to think about organizing your calendar horizontally.   By this I mean that  I encourage you to redesign your weekly calendar by dividing it into horizontal strips. Work on each course for a little bit every day (or at least most days). My claim is that spending at least one hour per day on each course is better for most people most of the time when compared to spending seven hours on one day per week. Some of the benefits I perceive are

  1. Less fatigue. When I spend more than one hour on a single subject, I begin to read the same sentences over and over again. I repeat the same thoughts. My production drops dramatically.
  2. Synchronization with lectures. Using this approach, you are more likely to review material closer to the time when it was covered in class. This should make the connections clearer. What you learn in lecture and what you figure out on your own are more likely to inform each other.
  3. The power of letting it brew. If you work on assignment problems well before the due dates and you get stuck, you can just move on and return to it later. Chances are that ideas may come to you in the interim. For me, this happens when I least expect it. Some of my little moments of inspiration come to me as I fall asleep at night or step in the shower in the morning! I remember once in grad school I even solved a problem in my dreams.
  4. Getting help. By avoiding procrastination this approach gives you more time to seek help from others in a meaningful and helpful way.
  5. Stress reduction. These last three benefits are really a result of starting preparation early. If nothing else, it removes the inevitable stress and worry caused by leaving work to the last minute.

So I wondering whether [1 2]^T and [1 2 0]^T are equal to each other. "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 168, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-09T17:56:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Anika Smith", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1701090248, "llazq0fual03ej": 1702157509}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-09T17:57:49Z", "content": "

These two vectors are in different spaces. One is in $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ and one is in $$\mathbb{R}^3$$. A comparing law not defined unless more (embedding or equivalence) rules are introduced. For example, one cannot compare $$2\in \mathbb{R}$$ and $$\begin{bmatrix}2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb{R}^2$$.

These two vectors are in different spaces. One is in $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ and one is in $$\mathbb{R}^3$$. It is not defined unless more (embedding) rules are introduced. For example, one cannot compare $$2\in \mathbb{R}$$ and $$\begin{bmatrix}2\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb{R}^2$$.

Does T refer to the number of elements in column arranged in rows?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 141, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-10T01:14:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-10T01:14:25Z", "content": "Im pretty sure the T is just for saying that its a vector but you are writing it in that way"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lr738g7rg1d7ph", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "It’s just an operator that flips a matrix over the diagonal line.", "created": "2024-01-10T01:24:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwcfhf3hp7j6", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lr73l52f3ug7k2", "updated": "2024-01-10T01:24:44Z", "config": {}}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-10T01:24:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-10T01:25:03Z", "content": "

When we write

$$\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \end{bmatrix}^T$$

or

$$\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \end{bmatrix}^\top$$

we mean the same thing as

$$\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{bmatrix}$$.

The ^T denotes the transpose of a matrix (imagine drawing a line through the diagonal and flipping all elements across it): e.g.

$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & a \\ b & c & 4\end{bmatrix} ^ \top = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & b \\ 2 & c \\ a & 4 \end{bmatrix}$$

We tend to write $$\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \end{bmatrix}^\top$$ as an inline vector so that it doesn't take up too much vertical space.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-10T01:24:21Z", "content": "

When we write

$$\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \end{bmatrix}^T$$

or

$$\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \end{bmatrix}^\top$$

we mean the same thing as

$$\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{bmatrix}$$.

The ^T denotes the transpose of a matrix (imagine drawing a line through the diagonal and flipping all elements across it): e.g.

$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & a \\ b & c & 4\end{bmatrix} ^ \top = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & b \\ 2 & c \\ a & 4 \end{bmatrix}$$

We tend to write $$\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \end{bmatrix}^\top$$ as an inline vector so that it doesn't take up too much vertical space.

There is no "vector times vector."  We can talk about the dot product of a vector with another vector.  If we calculate the dot product of a unit vector with itself, then we will end up with the square of its length which is 1 and so the square will also be 1. 

(The dot product of two vectors is a scalar.)

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Is section 1.7 covered?", "created": "2024-01-10T23:22:19Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 30, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-11T16:09:43Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lr9eno02qbe5ao", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-11T16:09:43Z"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Create Your Own Definitions List", "created": "2024-01-11T16:09:43Z", "content": "

In MATH 135 we stressed the importance of definitions.  I would say that definitions are even more important in MATH 136.  I would recommend writing out your own list of definitions.

 

Writing out this list will serve a few purposes:

  1. It will be a handy reference for you as you complete the assignments and prepare for the quizzes. Many problems and proofs in Linear Algebra follow directly from the definitions of the terms used.  So having easy access to a list of definitions will be helpful for you.
  2. Writing out the definitions will help you remember them. For that reason, I encourage you to actually write them out or type them up.  Don't just cut and paste. 
  3. You can continue to review the list as it grows and this will help you prepare for the midterm and the final exam.
  4. Summary lists are a good way to notice larger connections between concepts.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week1"], "nr": 33, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-12T17:33:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrax2rwkiy2b0", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-12T17:33:07Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwa9eqf90pz", "data": "lraxvpp8wdk3n", "to": "lrax2rwi2vx2az", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-12T17:55:37Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lraxwx8ydm652o", "to": "lrax2rwi2vx2az", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-12T17:56:34Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Geometric interpretation of the dot product", "created": "2024-01-12T17:33:07Z", "content": "

Could someone show me a geometric representation of the dot product?
I learned from lecture that

U dot V = ||U|| ||V|| cos θ 

My first thought would be the component of U on V but that is the definition of projection so it is simply not true. The projection is a vector whereas a dot product is a scalar. Since there is a scalar there is no way of representing it geometrically so I guess I just answered my own question here, but I am still not sure what the dot product is besides the two definition that was provided in class.
1. U dot V = the sum of the multiples of the components of u and v 

2. U dot V = ||U|| ||V|| cos θ 
I am also not sure how the two formula are related.

Please give me another way I could think about the dot product other than the definitions themselves as well as how the two definitions are related to one another.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 104, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-12T17:55:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwa9eqf90pz", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-12T17:55:37Z", "content": "It’s basically the product of magnitude of the component of u along v into magnitude of v.

Geometrically you could make two vectors u and v. Get a projection of u over v. The product of magnitude of projection and vector v represents dot product.
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lraxvpp4y2m3m", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-12T17:56:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1697485981}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Akshat Shah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8em1rz14rg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Eike Zhao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqweg7lidj7dl", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-12T17:56:34Z", "content": "

The dot product is a function that encodes a bit of information about the magnitudes and directions of the two vectors.

If $$\theta$$ is the angle between $$\vec u$$ and $$\vec v$$, then $$\cos \theta$$ tells you the general direction the two vectors point. If they point in opposite directions, then $$\theta = \pi/2$$ so $$\cos \theta = -1$$ so the dot product will be negative. If they point in the same direction, then $$\theta = 0$$ so that $$\cos \theta = 1$$. You can check for yourself that when the dot product is positive, $$\vec u$$ and $$\vec v$$ point in the general same direction (i.e. $$0 < \theta < \pi/4$$) and if the dot product is negative, then $$\vec u$$ and $$\vec v$$ point in general opposite directions.

Here is one way to think of the dot product: consider the projection of one of the vectors onto the other (it doesn't matter $$\vec u$$ onto $$\vec v$$ or $$\vec v$$ onto $$\vec u$$, but here I've illustrated $$\vec u$$ onto $$\vec v$$).

By some trigonometry, we can find that the length of the projection is $$\cos \theta \| \vec u\|$$, and the dot product now is the simple (real-valued) product of $$\cos(\theta) \|\vec u\| \cdot \|\vec v\| = \|\vec u \| \|\vec v\| \cos \theta$$.

To see why the two formulae are equivalent, I'll leave you a hint: the above is a drawing of a triangle with sides $$\vec u$$, $$\vec v$$, and $$\vec v - u$$. Apply the law of cosines and see what happens.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "l6at4v5pzre7le", "lkqw8em1rz14rg", "lkqweg7lidj7dl"], "children": [], "id": "lraxwx8xw3h52n", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrax2rwi2vx2az", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456397219, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Yes, in $$\mathbb{R}^2$$, area is well-defined as long as you have a norm. In $$\mathbb{R}^2$$, you don't have cross product.

If your $$\theta$$ is the angle between $$\vec{u}$$ and $$\vec{v}$$, then $$\|\vec{u}\| \|\vec{v}\| \sin \theta$$ and $$\|\vec{u}\| \| \mathrm{proj}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{v})\|$$ are the same. I would recommand you prove it before using it.

Hints:

  • Using basic trig idenity, you can deduce $$\|\vec{v}\|^2\sin(\theta)^2 = \|\vec{v}\|^2 (1-\cos(\theta)^2)= \|\vec{v}\|^2 - \|\vec{v}\cos(\theta)\|^2 = \|\vec{v}\|^2- \|\mathrm{proj}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{v})\|^2$$.

  • On the other hand, using the techniques learned in class, 

              $$\|\mathrm{perp}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{v})\|^2 = (\vec{v} - \mathrm{proj}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{v}))\cdot (\vec{v} - \mathrm{proj}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{v}))$$

               $$=  \|\vec{v}\|^2 {\color{red}- 2(\vec{v}\cdot \mathrm{proj}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{v})) + \|\mathrm{proj}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{v})\|^2} = \|\vec{v}\|^2 {\color{red}-\|\mathrm{proj}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{v})\|^2}$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q1"], "nr": 39, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T11:51:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrc0aqgiuul11k", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-13T11:51:04Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lrc47tvvihv2vt", "to": "lrc0aqgdhkb11j", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-13T13:40:46Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "data": "lrd1zb0sqhr5ui", "to": "lrc0aqgdhkb11j", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-14T05:25:56Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "dot product and proj visualization", "created": "2024-01-13T11:51:04Z", "content": "

I'm a little confused about the difference between the visualization of the dot product and the proj of one vector on the other. 

Also, I'm slightly confused as to what the scalar value the dot product produces represents. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 104, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T13:40:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-13T13:40:46Z", "content": "

The geometric interpretation of the dot product of vectors $$\vec{u}$$ and $$\vec{v}$$ is that it calculates the product of the length of the two vectors and the cosine of the angle between them.  $$\vec{u} \cdot \vec{v} = ||\vec{u}|| ||\vec{v}|| \cos \theta$$.

The projection of $$\vec{v}$$ onto $$\vec{u}$$ can be thought of the shadow that $$\vec{v}$$ would make on $$\vec{v}$$ if a light was shone directly above.  We can also think of it the as the component of $$\vec{v}$$ the goes in the direction (or possibly opposite direction) of $$\vec{u}$$. 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrc47tvsqad2vs", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-14T05:25:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-14T05:25:56Z", "content": "

just to add, if you have a little bit of familiarity with highschool physics, I like to think of the projection of  u  onto  v  as the component of u that is in the direction of v.

hopefully that helps with some intuition :)

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrd1zb0q56f5uh", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrc0aqgdhkb11j", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456403563, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["q1"], "nr": 40, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T12:03:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrc0qs5d1f92u2", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-13T12:03:32Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lrc0r020lij341", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-01-13T12:03:42Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lrc4d8ckq2x5zw", "to": "lrc0qs58h3o2u1", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-13T13:44:59Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Parallel vectors", "created": "2024-01-13T12:03:42Z", "content": "Is every vector in R3 parallel with the zero vector?"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Parallel vectors", "created": "2024-01-13T12:03:32Z", "content": "Is very vector in R3 parallel with the zero vector?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 93, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-13T13:44:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-13T13:44:59Z", "content": "

Two vectors are parallel if they are scalar multiples.\u00a0 The zero vector is a scalar multiple of all vectors in $$\\mathbb{R}^3$$ and so by convention we can say that the zero vector is parallel to every vectors in $$\\mathbb{R}^3$$.\u00a0 However, the dot product of the zero vector with every vector in $$\\mathbb{R}^3$$ is 0 and so we can also say that the zero vector is orthogonal (or perpendicular) with every vector in $$\\mathbb{R}^3$$.

\n

\n

Essentially the zero vector can be thought of having no direction or all directions and that's why we can interpret it as being parallel to all vectors and orthogonal to all vectors.\u00a0

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Q5 from practice", "created": "2024-01-14T23:52:30Z", "content": "How do you do the backward proof after getting the dot product of vector x and vector y is 0 from knowing they are orthogonal?"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Q5 from practice", "created": "2024-01-14T23:52:12Z", "content": "How do you do the backward proof after know the dot product of vector x and vector y is 0 from knowing they are orthogonal?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 112, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-14T23:55:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Junyan Ye", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwb17ooi55le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-14T23:55:44Z", "content": "Hint: Express $$\|\vec{x} + \vec{y}\|^2$$ in terms of dot product and expand the dot product using linearity."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwb17ooi55le"], "children": [], "id": "lre5mj6iabk1os", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Literally can we get |vector x| dot with |vector y| is also zero directly from knowing vector x dot with vector y is zero vector?", "created": "2024-01-15T00:20:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I don't understand your question. The dot product $$\vec{x}\cdot \vec{y}$$ gives you a number not a vector, so it cannot be zero vector.

Think of $$\vec{e_1}\cdot \vec{e_2}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\\0\end{bmatrix}\cdot \begin{bmatrix}0\\1\\0\end{bmatrix}=0$$. Neither $$\|\vec{e_1}\|$$ or $$\|\vec{e_2}\|$$ is zero.

", "created": "2024-01-15T00:58:49Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lre7vn07xxp5hs", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-01-15T01:26:18Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lre6itfdu3x4c9", "updated": "2024-01-15T14:49:29Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

This is what I have for the forward proof, I was kind of confused when you put the length symbols around the vectors vs when you don't.

Additionally, can I conclude that x dot y = 0 from the line I have before it?

", "created": "2024-01-15T00:46:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Your formula star isn't right. $$\|\vec{x}\| \|\vec{y}\| \neq \vec{x} \cdot \vec{y} = \|\vec{x}\| \|\vec{y}\| \cos\theta$$.

Without any assumption, only using the definition of norm ($$\|\vec{u}\|^2 = \vec{u}\cdot \vec{u}$$ for any $$\vec{u}$$), 

$$\|\vec{x}+ \vec{y}\|^2 = (\vec{x}+\vec{y})\cdot (\vec{x} +\vec{y})$$. Can you expand the right hand side corretly?

", "created": "2024-01-15T00:56:47Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lre7t1kxc0h19s", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-01-15T01:19:04Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lre7gev1hp660d", "updated": "2024-01-15T14:49:34Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

I had $$||\vec{x}||^2+||\vec{y}||^2 = \vec{x}\cdot\vec{x} + \vec{y}\cdot\vec{y},$$

$$||\vec{x}+\vec{y}||^2 = (\vec{x}+\vec{y})\cdot(\vec{x}+\vec{y})=\vec{x}\cdot\vec{x} + \vec{y}\cdot\vec{y}+2(\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y})$$.

So with $$||\vec{x}||^2+||\vec{y}||^2 = ||\vec{x}+\vec{y}||^2$$, i got that $$2(\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y}) = 0$$, so they are orthogonal.

For other direction, we can do the same thing and we will find that the equation is true since we know $$(\vec{x}\cdot\vec{y})=0$$

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 156, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-15T01:07:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-15T01:09:21Z", "content": "

This might be a commonly made mistake. One cannot "cancel" $$\vec{w}$$ in $$\frac{\vec{v}\cdot \vec{w}}{\vec{w}\cdot \vec{w}}$$. $$\frac{\vec{v}}{\vec{w}}$$ is not well-defined.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T01:36:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mathilda Lee", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l3a6u2rficd4fp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-18T01:36:37Z", "content": "

The span of a set of vectors always includes the origin (consider simply taking all of the scalars to be $$0$$).

You can clearly see that

$$\mathcal P = \operatorname{span}\left\{\begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 4 \\ 6 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ 2 \\ -3 \end{bmatrix}\right\}$$

hence

$$\operatorname{span} \{\mathcal P\} = \mathcal P$$.

However, $$\mathcal M$$ is not the span of any set of vectors (I challenge you to think about what the span of $$\mathcal M$$ is).

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l3a6u2rficd4fp"], "children": [], "id": "lrijjszpnuk38k", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrie3uwo48d3pd", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456428982, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week1"], "nr": 67, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T06:04:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrit3t8d2um19e", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-18T06:04:06Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hbsg02xli8p54o", "data": "lrja49mhvd07lu", "to": "lrit3t8amvh19d", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-18T14:00:21Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "data": "lrjzz4duym11t6", "to": "lrit3t8amvh19d", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-19T02:04:11Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Q8b", "created": "2024-01-18T06:04:06Z", "content": "Can some one help me with this question? Tks!"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 124, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T14:00:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "hbsg02xli8p54o", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-18T14:00:21Z", "content": "For this question, most unfortunately, your best bet is to write out each vector in terms of its components and simply show the left and right sides are equal. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrja49mdjop7lt", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-19T02:04:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-19T02:04:11Z", "content": "

I will explain what I did.

Step 1: 

First of all, I did cross multiplication of vector v and vector w

I did:

vector u dot <(v2w3-v3w2) , -(v1w3-v3w1) , (v1w2-w2v1)>^T

Step 2:

Then I applied dot product on vector u. I got:

u1v2w3-u1v3w2-u2v1w3+u2v3w1+u3v1w2-u3v2w1

Step 3

<-v1(u2w3-u3w2) v2(u1v3-u3w1) -v3(u1w2 - u2w1)>^T = -<v1(u2w3-u3w2) - v2(u1v3-u3w1) v3(u1w2-u2w1)>^T because of scalar multiplication. Think of -1 as the scalar of the vector that is distributed inside each row of the vector. 

Step 4

Bring v1 v2 and v3 out

this simplifies to v dot -(u x w)

I hope this helps.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrjzz4dtu231t5", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrit3t8amvh19d", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456433229, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 68, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-18T14:03:05Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lrja7s55sof6bd", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-18T14:03:05Z"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Geometry is Helpful But It Only Goes So Far", "created": "2024-01-18T14:03:05Z", "content": "

As we work with vectors in $$\mathbb{R}^n$$, I strongly recommend that you think about $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ and $$\mathbb{R}^3$$ because these correspond to things that we can actually visualize.  Try to picture what a span of two vectors in $$\mathbb{R}^3$$ would look like.  What does the angle between two vectors in $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ mean?  When thinking about a theorem about a set of $$n$$ vectors in $$\mathbb{R}^n$$ (we haven’t had a lot of theorems so far but they will come), it's often helpful to consider a smaller set (like a set of 3 vectors in $$\mathbb{R}^3$$) and see if you can prove the theorem for this smaller set.  Then try to generalize your proof.

 

Although working in $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ and $$\mathbb{R}^3$$ is helpful, it will only go so far.  We have already generalized some geometric concepts like length, the angle between two vectors, a line and span to $$\mathbb{R}^n$$.    When working in higher dimensions these generalizations won't correspond to something that we can actually draw or visualize.

 

So aim to understand the geometry in $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ and $$\mathbb{R}^3$$, but don't hold onto to it too tightly because it will only take you so far.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week1"], "nr": 93, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-21T20:32:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l66pr4f64oe3ti", "data": "lrnygni4f2npq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-21T20:32:55Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjobx1y5ag46ny", "data": "lrnyr227h5v3i1", "to": "lrnygni1xulpp", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-21T20:41:00Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lro59iidinb1ws", "to": "lrnygni1xulpp", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-21T23:43:19Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l66pr4f64oe3ti", "subject": "Area of a Parallelogram", "created": "2024-01-21T20:32:55Z", "content": "

Given two vectors, v and w, the area of the parallelogram they create is apparently the length of the matrix v x w (the cross product between the two vectors).

I think I may have missed this fact from a lecture, could someone explain the proof behind this, and direct me to where in the textbook/lecture notes this was mentioned?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 107, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-21T20:41:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kjobx1y5ag46ny", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-21T20:41:00Z", "content": "

Most likely this wasn't proved in class, but you should think of it backwards. The cross product was defined as the vector that:

  • Is perpendicular to u and v
  • Has a length equal to the area of the parallelogram create by u and v
  • Respects the right hand rule

All three conditions are necessary to uniquely define the cross product. 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrnyr222tf13hz", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-21T23:43:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-21T23:43:19Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q1"], "nr": 94, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-21T20:46:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrnyyda3i1q42t", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-21T20:46:41Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwa9eqf90pz", "data": "lrnzhcedob05gz", "to": "lrnyyd9zxhk42r", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-21T21:01:26Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lro7ahhud6a1op", "to": "lrnyyd9zxhk42r", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-22T00:40:03Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WP1 Q7", "created": "2024-01-21T20:46:41Z", "content": "

Can anyone explain to me how can we get v1/u1 u1 =v1?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q1", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Charlie zhao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8zx877loc", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 106, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-21T21:01:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "x275wang@uwaterloo.ca", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwe7qdk3e5qr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwa9eqf90pz", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-21T21:01:26Z", "content": "

$$v_{1} = v_{1}$$

$$v_{1} \ \cdot\ \frac{u_{1}}{u_{1}} = v_{1}$$

$$\frac{v_{1}}{u_{1}} \ \cdot \ u_{1}= v_{1}$$

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week1"], "nr": 101, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-21T23:29:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lro4rvtwolzlz", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-21T23:29:36Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lro6gqvmani3xc", "to": "lro4rvtr4mnly", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-22T00:16:56Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwa9eqf90pz", "data": "lro6gza4bhl4e6", "to": "lro4rvtr4mnly", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-22T00:17:07Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "collinear and Parallel", "created": "2024-01-21T23:29:36Z", "content": "Does two vectors being Parallel imply they are collinear?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 118, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T00:16:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T00:16:56Z", "content": "

The term "collinear" usually requires at least 3 points. Collinear describes when a bunch of points fall on the same line. If you have two points (or vectors), then you can always draw a line that passes through both of them.

\n

\n

Perhaps you mean collinear with the origin (i.e. you can draw a line passing through the origin which also passes through both vectors). If this is the case, then yes, two parallel vectors are also collinear with the origin.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lro6gqvjl973xb", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T00:17:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwa9eqf90pz", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T00:17:07Z", "content": "Not necessarily as two parallel vectors can have a different starting point and thus are non collinear"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lro6gza315v4e5", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lro4rvtr4mnly", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456469304, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week1", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Danny Liu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwamzvoyp34s", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 146, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T12:32:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sandy Banh", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwd8exhah635", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T12:32:33Z", "content": "

You are correct in that the $$\vec{u}$$ is a typo in the preliminary step, however the final answer should be correct still. First, make sure that you calculated the projection to be what the answer shows. Let me know if you got something different.

Then, doing component-wise subtraction, notice that $$-1 - \frac{6}{14} = \frac{-20}{14}$$, $$1 - \frac{9}{14} = \frac{5}{14}$$, and $$2 - \frac{3}{14} = \frac{25}{14}$$. Factor out $$\frac{5}{14}$$ from everything to get $$\frac{5}{14} \cdot\begin{bmatrix}    -4 \\ 1 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix}$$.

If you're still stuck you could post your steps and I'd be happy to help you out! 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4", "lkqwd8exhah635"], "children": [], "id": "lrowqrn76yj46", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwamzvoyp34s"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrodthuyid17in", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456472469, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week1"], "nr": 105, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T15:33:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrp381oie3f7ik", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-22T15:33:57Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrp3v5rs1j736", "to": "lrp381ofz2m7ij", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-22T15:51:56Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lrp381ofz2m7ij", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-01-22T16:43:28Z", "cid": "lrp5pfiotihnm", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "lrp381ofz2m7ij", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-01-22T17:01:45Z", "cid": "lrp6cycoa8925l"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WP1 Q8b", "created": "2024-01-22T15:33:57Z", "content": "

Can someone explain how you get the second last step? Why is the cross product reversed? I can't really see it in the third-last step, and don't we need the expanded cross-product to have negative components so that it can be reversed?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 135, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T15:51:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T15:51:56Z", "content": "

Do you mean

$$\quad (u_3 w_2 - u_2w_3) + (u_1w_3 - u_3w_1) + (u_2w_1 - u_1w_2)$$

$$= (w_2u_3 - w_3u_2) - (w_1u_3 - w_3u_1) + (w_1u_2 - w_2u_1)$$

$$= \vec w \times \vec u$$?

If not, could you please clarify your question?

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrp3v5rpd2w35", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I was also confused on how they went from the second last step to the last step. How did they get v * (w x u) = - (u x w) * v", "created": "2024-01-22T16:43:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "The last step follows from skew-symmetry of cross product (i.e. the property that $$\vec u \times \vec w = - \vec w \times \vec u$$) and commutativity of dot product (i.e. the property that $$\vec a \cdot \vec b = \vec b \cdot \vec a$$).", "created": "2024-01-22T17:01:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Bradley Ming Wei Low", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8btlx5d4as", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqw8btlx5d4as"], "id": "lrp6cycoa8925l", "updated": "2024-01-22T17:36:38Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrp5pfiotihnm", "updated": "2024-01-22T17:01:50Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrp381ofz2m7ij", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456473525, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week1"], "nr": 106, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T16:57:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrp67s20osv48g", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-22T16:57:44Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrp6jwc2knx4r", "to": "lrp67s1wjpb48f", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-22T17:07:09Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WP1 Q1c", "created": "2024-01-22T16:57:44Z", "content": "

If 2 $$\vec{u}$$ = $$\begin{bmatrix} -8 \\ 15 \\-17 \end{bmatrix}$$ , then is 

$$\vec{u}$$ = $$\begin{bmatrix} -4 \\ 15/2 \\-17/2 \end{bmatrix}$$

or should I consider scalar and vector as two different things

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 114, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T17:07:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T17:07:09Z", "content": "

The answer to your first question is yes, $$\vec u = \begin{bmatrix} -4 \\ 15/2 \\ -17/2\end{bmatrix}$$.

I'm not sure what you mean by "should I consider scalar and vector as two different things". In a vector space such as $$\mathbb R^2$$, we have vectors which are elements of $$\mathbb R^2$$. A property of vector spaces is that it is closed under scalar multiplication, which means that if you take a scalar such as $$2$$ or $$5/2$$ or $$e$$ and multiply a vector such as $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0\end{bmatrix}$$ by it, the resulting vectors are all also elements of $$\mathbb R^2$$:

$$2\begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 0\end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb R^2$$, $$\frac52\begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5/2 \\ 0\end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb R^2$$, $$e\begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} e \\ 0\end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb R^2$$, etc.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrp6jwbymsh4o", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrp67s1wjpb48f", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456474584, "default_anonymity": "no"}

So shouldn't the answer be srqt(5) * [-1, 2]?"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Norm", "created": "2024-01-22T17:25:30Z", "content": "https://piazza.com/class/lqzes2lznxt50s/post/33When it asks to find norm, should I only tell value of norm or value with vector. For example one of the Mobius question asked to find norm of [-1, 2] to which the answer was sqrt(5). But shouldn't we multiply this with the vector because the formula for norm is (1 / || v||) * v? So shouldn't the answer be srqt(5) * [-1, 2]? "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 109, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T17:30:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T17:30:09Z", "content": "

The norm describes the function with the two bars: $$\| \vec v\|$$ gives the norm of a vector $$\vec v$$. The norm is always real-valued (also known as a scalar) and nonnegative.

The formula you described $$\vec v / \|\vec v \|$$ gives you a unit vector $$\hat v$$ which points in the direction of $$\vec v$$. By definition, unit vectors have a norm of $$1$$, and this is easy to verify here:

$$\left\|\frac{\vec v}{\|\vec v\|}\right\| = \frac{1}{\|\vec v\|}\|\vec v\| = 1$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrp7dgzl7o248", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrp77hsr73w43h", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456477756, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q1"], "nr": 111, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T17:52:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrp86lcvit4s3", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-22T17:52:48Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrp88q9ksc33ib", "to": "lrp86lcs9wi4s2", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-22T17:54:27Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "geometric to algebraic", "created": "2024-01-22T17:52:48Z", "content": "Do we need to know how to convert between the two for the quiz?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 87, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T17:54:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T17:54:27Z", "content": "What specific topic are you referring to that has both geometric and algebraic representations?"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrp88q9hru23i9", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrp86lcs9wi4s2", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456479878, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q1"], "nr": 112, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T18:21:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrp97q4mvlp6sk", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-22T18:21:40Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrp9gvnrsdr2y0", "to": "lrp97q4j3ng6sj", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-22T18:28:47Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "prependicular vectors", "created": "2024-01-22T18:21:40Z", "content": "Since there infinitely many perpendicular vectors to any given vector, is there any relationship between those vectors?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 97, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T18:28:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1697485981}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Bradley Ming Wei Low", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8btlx5d4as", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T18:28:47Z", "content": "

We'll learn more about this topic in the coming weeks, but the short answer is that the most relevant relationships between these vectors are that:

1. they are closed under addition (i.e. if $$\vec v$$ and $$\vec w$$ are both orthogonal to $$\vec u$$, then so is $$\vec v + \vec w$$

2. they are closed under scalar multiplication (i.e. if $$\vec v$$ is orthogonal to $$\vec u$$, then so is $$c \vec v$$ for all $$c \in \mathbb R$$

3. $$\vec 0$$ is orthogonal to everything

These 3 key properties form the definition of subspaces (topic which will be covered in the coming weeks).

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "lkqw8btlx5d4as"], "children": [], "id": "lrp9gvnnbn2xz", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrp97q4j3ng6sj", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456480939, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q1"], "nr": 113, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T18:28:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrp9g71ysi5io", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-22T18:28:15Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrp9j2c2cfj1r", "to": "lrp9g71u33gim", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-22T18:30:29Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "right hand rule", "created": "2024-01-22T18:28:15Z", "content": "

Are we to remember the right-hand rule for the cross-product?

\n

\n

If you forget it but remember the component formula for the cross product, then you can check which way it works by applying the formula to $$\\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\\\ 0 \\\\ 0 \\end{bmatrix}$$ and $$\\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\\\ 1 \\\\ 0 \\end{bmatrix}$$.

For instance by definition, 

$$\text{proj}_{\vec w}(\vec u) = \frac{\vec u \cdot \vec w}{\|\vec w\|^2} \vec w$$

so you don't have to write "by property of projection", but we proved that the perpendicular and a projection of a vector $$\vec v$$ onto $$\vec w$$ are orthogonal (prop 1.6.9 in the course notes), so you should mention it (e.g. "since perp and proj are orth.")

For this question, couldn't we use the fact that $$ ||u \times v|| =||u|| \cdot ||v|| sin \theta$$?

We would end up with $$sin\theta=0$$, which means that the angle between the two vectors is $$n\pi$$, with $$n \in$$ Real Numbers, so they're parallel?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 152, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-22T20:50:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Rosemary Liao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdh2s3927me", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-22T20:50:53Z", "content": "

I think you mean to write the angle is $$n\pi$$, where $$n \in \mathbb Z$$.

In particular, we would know that the angle would work out to either $$0$$ or $$\pi$$ radians, but this doesn't exactly align with the definition of parallel given. This approach would work, but you would still need to show that the angle between two vectors is $$0$$ or $$\pi$$ if and only if they are scalar multiples of each other (this is not hard to do, but don't forget to match your answer with the given definitions).
