{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 123, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-23T13:45:13Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lrqes20av2u1mv", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-23T13:45:13Z"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Recognize the type of object you are working with", "created": "2024-01-23T13:45:13Z", "content": "

 In mathematics it is very important to understand what type of object you are working with.  The type of object will affect what operations are defined and what properties apply. 

 

For the most part in high school all you ever worked with was real numbers.  Then in MATH 135 we introduced $$\mathbb{Z}_n$$ and $$\mathbb{C}$$.  In MATH 136, we now have added the concepts of scalars, vectors and matrices.  You need to recognize when you are using which type of object.  For example, the vector $$\vec{0}$$ and the scalar 0 are very different objects.  This distinction is important.

 

However, it’s also very important for you to realize when you have a single object and when you have a set of objects.  And to also distinguish between different sets of objects.  For example, a student might write $$\text{Span}\{ \vec{u}, \vec{v}\} = a\vec{u} + b\vec{v}$$,  for some $$a, b \in \mathbb{F}$$.  This equation doesn’t make sense because what is written on the left side of the equation is (usually) an infinite set of vectors and what is written on the right side is a single vector which is some linear combination of $$\vec{u}$$ and $$\vec{v}$$.  What the student should have written is $$\text{Span}\{ \vec{u}, \vec{v}\} = \{a\vec{u} + b\vec{v}: a, b \in \mathbb{F}\}$$.   Now both sides are sets and they both refer to the set of all linear combinations of $$\vec{u}$$ and $$\vec{v}$$. 

 

It’s also important to note that if $$\vec{u}$$ and $$\vec{v}$$ are both non-zero vectors, then $$\text{Span}\{ \vec{u}, \vec{v}\} \neq \{ \vec{u}, \vec{v}\}$$.  The left side is an infinite set of vectors.  The right side is a set of 2 vectors. 

 

Also be careful when writing down your solution sets.  Writing something like $$\vec{x} = a\vec{u} + b\vec{v}$$,  for all $$a, b \in \mathbb{F}$$ doesn’t make sense.  What you need to write is that $$\vec{x} \in \{ a\vec{u} +b \vec{v} : a, b \in \mathbb{F}\}$$ or $$ \vec{x} \in \text{Span}\{ \vec{u}, \vec{v}\}$$.   (I will confess to being guilty of doing this at times.)

 

Be clear about the objects you are working with, in your thinking and in your writing.

", "created": "2024-01-25T21:50:26Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "$$i$$ is not (necessarily) equal to $$m$$ in this case. $$i$$ represents a specific vector in a set, not the number of spans. $$i$$ is the subscript for $$\\vec u$$, meaning we are looking at some arbitrary $$\\vec u_i$$ in the set given by $$Span\\{\\vec u_1, \\vec u_2, ... , \\vec u_k\\}$$. So the first thing we check is to see if there is a row with all entries being 0, and if there is a leading 1 appearing in a row and it is also in the column that other entries except for itself are 0s, then this is an RREF right?", "created": "2024-01-25T04:51:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "And add that all zero rows are below all non-zero rows", "created": "2024-01-25T04:53:17Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrsqnoztupf4nf", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-01-25T04:53:17Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

To be in REF you need two things:

1. Zero rows are at the bottom of the matrix.

2. Any leading entry in a row is further to the right than any of the rows above it. 

To be in RREF you need three things:

1.  It needs to be in REF (see above)

2.  All leading entries must be ones.

3. Any column that has a leading entry in it, is all zeros except the leading entry.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 140, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T13:55:16Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lrta0oyq4wy5du", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-25T13:55:16Z"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Breathing Exercises", "created": "2024-01-25T13:55:16Z", "content": "

Today’s tip isn’t a mathematical tip, but rather a life tip.  Like many people I struggle at times with anxiety.  If you are like me, then your mind can easily slip into downward spiraling thoughts.  A small thing can set me off and before I know it, I can feel anxiety.

 

I have found breathing exercises really helpful.   The great thing about breathing exercises is that you can do them pretty much anywhere, even in the middle of an exam!  What I do is sit up straight with my feet on the floor and I place my hands comfortably in my lap.  I usually close my eyes.   Then I take a few deep breaths, breathing in through my nose and out through my mouth.   I focus on my breath and feel my belly move in and out.  As I breathe in, I imagine peace entering my body.  As I breathe out, I imagine stress leaving my body.  I may even say to myself "Peace in" as I breathe in and "Stress out" as I breathe out.  It can also be helpful to picture a place that makes me feel good.  A place that some may call a "happy place".

 

I have found this practice helpful to calm my racing thoughts so that I can think more rationally about the problem that is causing me stress.  It doesn't solve my problem, but it puts my mind in a better state so that I can think about how to solve my problem.

I know in lecture it was said to make the clear distinction between sets and vectors but would this still be valid?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa1"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 185, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T17:15:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Evan Yan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwalxbkor2xk", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-25T17:16:00Z", "content": "

Suppose your scalar field is $$\mathbb{R}$$. Recall the definition of span: $$\mathrm{Span}\{\vec{v_1}, \dots, \vec{v_k}\} = \{c_1\vec{v_1} + \cdots c_k\vec{v_k} : c_1, \dots, c_k \in \mathbb{R}\}$$. So, yes, if you take a vector $$\vec{x}$$ in the span, there exsit coefficients $$c_i$$ that express $$\vec{x}$$ as a linear combination in the form of  $$\vec{x}=c_1\vec{v_1} + \cdots + c_k\vec{v_k}$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa1"], "nr": 147, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T21:45:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrtqsz33w7h78z", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-25T21:45:10Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrtsfl92p525fs", "to": "lrtqsz30oxm78y", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-25T22:30:44Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lrtqsz30oxm78y", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-01-25T22:33:13Z", "cid": "lrtsiruwjbs20e", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "lrtqsz30oxm78y", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-01-25T23:42:09Z", "cid": "lrtuzey1vqi53h"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WA1 question3 (a)", "created": "2024-01-25T21:45:10Z", "content": "Do we have prove the fact that u and z are orthogonal, or o we have to use that to prove span{u,v}=span{u,z}"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa1"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 237, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T22:30:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-25T22:30:44Z", "content": "

You need to show both: that you can choose $$\vec z \in \mathbb R^n$$ so that

a) $$\vec u \cdot \vec z = 0$$, AND

b) $$\text{Span}\{\vec u, \vec v\} = \text{Span}\{\vec u, \vec z\}$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrtsfl8zi3r5fr", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "So FYI, I there is no relevance between a) and b) right?", "created": "2024-01-25T22:33:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "The questions themselves are not related, but you can use (a) to prove (b) if you desire (as you would have proven (a) already).", "created": "2024-01-25T23:42:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrtuzey1vqi53h", "updated": "2024-01-25T23:42:09Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrtsiruwjbs20e", "updated": "2024-01-25T23:42:12Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrtqsz30oxm78y", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456518062, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa1"], "nr": 149, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T23:27:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrtuh7jb93u6d2", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-25T23:27:59Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrtuxx0lcem221", "to": "lrtuh7j7d8j6d1", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-25T23:40:59Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WA1 Question 2 (a)", "created": "2024-01-25T23:27:59Z", "content": "Is i the corresponding number of u or the number of span? For example when i=2 then does it mean it is span{u1, u2} or is it just u2"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa1"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 196, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-25T23:40:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-25T23:40:59Z", "content": "The second statement is asking you to show that for all $$1 \\le i \\le k$$, $$\\vec u_i \\in \\text{Span}\\{\\vec v_1, \\ldots, \\vec v_m\\}$$."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrtuxx0hbsp220", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrtuh7j7d8j6d1", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456520177, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa1"], "nr": 150, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T00:18:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrtw9wrge336k8", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-26T00:18:18Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrtwlprk3dl6tw", "to": "lrtw9wrc4xb6k7", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-26T00:27:29Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WA1 Q3 b)", "created": "2024-01-26T00:18:18Z", "content": "

When I declare $$\\vec{u}$$ and\u00a0$$\\vec{v}$$, can I put a constraint on them? for example: each component for both vectors have to be 1. Or do I have treat them as for all statements, and cannot have any constrains?

\n


Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa1"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 275, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T00:27:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Bowei Zhang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8jvxt565o5", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-26T00:27:29Z", "content": "

Orthogonal just means their dot products are $$0$$, so you cannot impose additional constraints on them.

\n

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8jvxt565o5"], "children": [], "id": "lrtwlprhgoh6tu", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrtw9wrc4xb6k7", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456521238, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa1"], "nr": 151, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T00:26:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrtwkt7kanp2sp", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-26T00:26:46Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrtwn07vnhm204", "to": "lrtwkt7gl6p2so", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-26T00:28:29Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "data": "lrv58jxk9zu457", "to": "lrtwkt7gl6p2so", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-01-26T21:16:57Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WA1 Question 2 (a)", "created": "2024-01-26T00:26:46Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa1"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 201, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T00:28:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-26T00:28:29Z", "content": "

I'm not sure what you mean.

If you are trying to show the contrapositive for one direction, and you wish to demonstrate $$A \subsetneq B$$, then it would suffice to find $$a \in A$$ so that $$a \notin B$$, if that is what you are asking.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrtwn07rx84202", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T21:16:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-26T21:16:57Z", "content": "I think you're thinking of a strict subset."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrv58jxjr0s454", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrtwkt7gl6p2so", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456522370, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 156, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T02:52:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lru1ry1dsrw28x", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-26T02:52:17Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lru23yh7u26245", "to": "lru1ry19tec28w", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-26T03:01:38Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Vectors in Rn", "created": "2024-01-26T02:52:17Z", "content": "Can any vector in Rn be rewritten as a linear combination of two orthogonal vectors? That is that suppose u and v are orthogonal, so Span(u,v) = Rn"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 104, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T03:01:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-26T03:01:38Z", "content": "

No. Consider:

$$\vec u = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$ and $$\vec v = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0\end{bmatrix}$$.

I'll leave it to you to check that they are orthogonal and that $$\text{Span}\{\vec u, \vec v\} \neq \mathbb R^n$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lru23yh4bas244", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lru1ry19tec28w", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456527657, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 157, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T08:19:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrudgl2suv45rj", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-26T08:19:23Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lrunaconzh61c8", "to": "lrudgl2qbvb5ri", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-26T12:54:28Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Solving REF / RREF", "created": "2024-01-26T08:19:23Z", "content": "Hi I just wanted to ask when dealing with REF and RREF, is it ok to do manipulations such as R1 -> 0.5*R1 - R2, will marks be deducted since this step includes multiple EROs?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 111, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T12:54:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Oscar Liu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8wylhqc5n", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-26T12:54:28Z", "content": "I would recommend that you do not do combine steps like this because it will affect things that we do later on when working with determinants.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8wylhqc5n"], "children": [], "id": "lrunacojx541c7", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrudgl2qbvb5ri", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456528717, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa1"], "nr": 158, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T16:56:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lruvxd555tm5c2", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-26T16:56:19Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lruwlv6x9wf452", "to": "lruvxd522wq5c1", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-26T17:15:22Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "perp and projection", "created": "2024-01-26T16:56:19Z", "content": "Hi, I just wanted to ask if we need to prove that perpendicular and projection vectors are orthogonal when we are doing the written assignment, or can we just use it directly?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa1"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 197, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T17:15:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "x275wang@uwaterloo.ca", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwe7qdk3e5qr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-26T17:15:22Z", "content": "

You need not prove it.

\n

\n

You can find a proof of it as proposition 1.6.9 in the course notes.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwe7qdk3e5qr"], "children": [], "id": "lruwlv6uy4c451", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lruvxd522wq5c1", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456529779, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa1"], "nr": 161, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T20:36:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrv3t21gno7fg", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-26T20:36:55Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrv3xetvwcf2aa", "to": "lrv3t21de3cff", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-26T20:40:18Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WA1 question3 (b)", "created": "2024-01-26T20:36:55Z", "content": "Can we just say vector w is a span{u,v,z}?, and how can we use the fact u and v are orthogonal?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa1"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 232, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T20:40:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-26T20:40:18Z", "content": "

I'm not sure what you mean.

$$\text{Span}\{\vec u, \vec v, \vec z\}$$ is a set of vectors, whereas $$\vec w$$ is a vector, so you can't say 

$$\vec w = \text{Span}\{\vec u, \vec v, \vec z\}$$.

As a hint, if you solved (a), how can you use (a) to solve (b)?

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrv3xetsfjx2a9", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrv3t21de3cff", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456532937, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 3, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 163, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-26T22:05:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrv6z8zdma231o", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-26T22:05:42Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "lrvodhj0you1s2", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-01-27T06:12:40Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lsuma3x8st2485", "type": "update", "when": "2024-02-20T17:05:59Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Crowdmark Submission Tip", "created": "2024-02-20T17:05:59Z", "content": "

In crowdmark, we ask you to separate your questions by problem number.

If you compiled all of your questions into 1 pdf, you may find the crowdmark interface unfriendly (dragging pages between questions is always a bit janky).

The best workaround I have for this is to upload your pdf which contains all of the questions to question 1, then to zoom out as much as possible to make it easier to drag the pages between other questions.

--------

To compile only specific pages, such as 3, 4, and 6, one can include '\usepackage[3,4,6]{pagesel}' on the third line before \hypersetup in the WA template. For consistent font size, it is recommended to compile the document twice.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "Crowdmark Submission Tip", "created": "2024-01-27T06:12:40Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa1"], "nr": 167, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-27T02:44:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrvgy5fo4ha2hd", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-27T02:44:47Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrvkf2iscyf4xr", "to": "lrvgy5fkz8x2hc", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-27T04:21:55Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WA1 Q4", "created": "2024-01-27T02:44:47Z", "content": "

Just to clarify,  what does vector a not being on the plane mean algebraically. I can visualize it but do not understand how to use it

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa1"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 216, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-27T04:21:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-27T04:21:55Z", "content": "

We can represent the plane as $$\mathcal P = \{\vec b + r \vec v + s \vec w : r, s \in \mathbb R\}$$, so if $$\vec a \notin \mathcal P$$, this means that there does not exist $$r, s \in \mathbb R$$ so that

$$\vec a = \vec b + r \vec v + s \vec w$$, or alternatively, for all $$r, s \in \mathbb R$$,

$$\vec a \neq \vec b + r \vec v + s \vec w$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrvkf2iput74xq", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrvgy5fkz8x2hc", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456539253, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa1"], "nr": 171, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-27T07:42:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrvrlg0se7o3gb", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-27T07:42:50Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrvs0777lx93a2", "to": "lrvrlg0lfqc3ga", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-27T07:54:19Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lrvrlg0lfqc3ga", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-01-27T20:54:48Z", "cid": "lrwjvx0187v3c9", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "lrvrlg0lfqc3ga", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-01-27T22:41:51Z", "cid": "lrwnpl2dbnm6h1"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "to": "lrvrlg0lfqc3ga", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-01-28T04:18:26Z", "cid": "lrwzqff4u1l8"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WA1 Q1", "created": "2024-01-27T07:42:50Z", "content": "What are the rules for proving an if and only if if I am trying to prove both ways at the same time. As long as the math makes sense backwards that is allowed right?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa1"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 168, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-27T07:54:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-27T07:54:19Z", "content": "Yes.

An if and only if means that both directions are true.

e.g. A iff B means A implies B and B implies A
"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrvs076z6jt3a0", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I think my question was miss understood, I meant to say that am I allowed to prove the => direction, and then state that the <= proof follows the same sequence of arithmetic steps backwards?", "created": "2024-01-27T20:54:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Sure, if each step is clear to see that they all follow (you don\u2019t have to write out the same thing but backwards, if that\u2019s what you are asking).", "created": "2024-01-27T22:41:51Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrwnpl2dbnm6h1", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-01-27T22:41:51Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "is squaring ||x -> y|| reversible?\u00a0", "created": "2024-01-28T04:18:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lrwzqff4u1l8", "updated": "2024-01-28T04:18:26Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrwjvx0187v3c9", "updated": "2024-01-28T04:18:26Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrvrlg0lfqc3ga", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456543462, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa1"], "nr": 172, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-27T12:32:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "data": "lrw1xi8h3082cg", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-27T12:32:09Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lrw9igg8d204", "to": "lrw1xi88l7t2cf", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-27T16:04:24Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lrw1xi88l7t2cf", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-01-28T21:58:50Z", "cid": "lry1m4b4xrw31p", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjobx1y5ag46ny", "to": "lrw1xi88l7t2cf", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-01-29T02:47:23Z", "cid": "lrybx75p2cn5fn"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "subject": "LATEX", "created": "2024-01-27T12:32:09Z", "content": "

Hi,

\n

Since I took a screenshot of my handwriting onto ChatGPT to convert my solution into LATEX code, how do I acknowledge that I'm using it?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 118, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-27T21:55:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Elyn Huang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwa8mrv3il6", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-27T21:55:36Z", "content": "When we state a theorem like this, we mean that it is true for all $$m$$ and $$n$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week3"], "nr": 198, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-28T07:30:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lrx6kszpzss1zj", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-28T07:30:01Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lrx77m06yly2ln", "to": "lrx6kszhnr51zi", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-28T07:47:45Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Free Variable", "created": "2024-01-28T07:30:01Z", "content": "Does a free variable come from a 00..00|0 or can it be 00..00|x where x is any non-zero number? are we only allowed to assign that row to be free if all the values in the row are 0? Also, if it does have the form 00..00|x where x is non-zero, are there no solutions at all?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 129, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-28T07:47:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-28T07:47:45Z", "content": "Remember that in an augmented matrix representation of a system of linear equations, each row corresponds to an equation, so if you have a row of the form $$\\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & \\cdot & 0 & \\mid & x\\end{bmatrix}$$ where $$x$$ is nonzero, then it is clear to see that there is no solution."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lrx77lzyos92lj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lrx6kszhnr51zi", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456571948, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 101, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-28T19:26:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Khushi Jirge", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwc2gwxor57c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-28T19:26:18Z", "content": "

$$A \vec x_i = \vec e_i$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa1"], "nr": 212, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-29T01:22:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lry8w4m1kwk5jh", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-29T01:22:34Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lryb18bua58v5", "to": "lry8w4ltt5c5jg", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-01-29T02:22:32Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lry8w4ltt5c5jg", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-01-29T20:03:45Z", "cid": "lrzcxyt07yk6ef", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "to": "lry8w4ltt5c5jg", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-01-30T13:57:20Z", "cid": "ls0falrglkj5lv"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WA1 Question 3 (a)", "created": "2024-01-29T01:22:34Z", "content": "I\u2019m really unsure on how to even start the proof for this question even with the hint, can someone maybe help me just understand how to go about it?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa1"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 186, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-29T02:22:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Anika Elizabeth Nickel", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw87safwb3ll", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-29T02:22:32Z", "content": "

Try drawing out a diagram.

\n

\n

Given two arbitrary vectors $$\\vec u$$, $$\\vec v \\in \\mathbb R^n$$, what would it look like to have a vector $$\\vec z$$ which is orthogonal to $$\\vec u$$? What would it look like if that vector $$\\vec z$$ had to also maintain the same span (i.e. $$\\text{Span}\\{\\vec u, \\vec v\\} = \\text{Span}\\{\\vec u, \\vec z\\}$$)?

If you are planning to use the insert equation/symbol feature in MS word, I believe MS word may only let you input typsetted characters and a few basic mathematical symbols such as sums (Capital sigma), products (Capital pi), etc.. 

In general, any software that is based on TeX such as Latex or even KaTeX would be much preferred and far easier to implement (I can confidently LaTeX notes faster than I can handwrite after having used it since my first year (2 years ago)).

We provide you the .tex file for the questions and you need only type up your solutions, which is very akin to just type it in MS word or alike, except you put $ signs around your math symbols. Overleaf is a free online software that lets you LaTeX.

-----

As long as the output is clearly understood and easy to read, then you will be awarded the LaTeX bonus.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-29T17:45:04Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 98, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-29T20:32:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-29T20:33:20Z", "content": "

If you are looking for the RREF of $$[A\mid \vec{b}]$$, then you need to consider $$\vec{b}$$. Matrix like

$$ \left[ \begin{array}{cc|c} 1& 1 & 2\\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right] $$

isn't in RREF, though it suffices to tell the solutions (no solution).

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-01-29T20:32:35Z", "content": "

If you are looking for the RREF of $$[A\mid \vec{b}]$$, then you need to consider $$\vec{b}$$. Matrix like

$$ \left[ \begin{array}{cc|c} 1& 1 & 2\\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right] $$

isn't in RREF, though it suffices to solve the equations.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 238, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-01-30T13:44:05Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ls0etkgdoob2zx", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-01-30T13:44:05Z"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Using Correct and Precise Language", "created": "2024-01-30T13:44:05Z", "content": "

We are learning a lot of concepts in this course that are all interconnected.  Based on some of the questions we have seen here on Piazza, a lot of these concepts can end up all jumbled for some students.  Here are some examples of statements that don’t make sense.

 

  1. “This matrix is consistent.”  A matrix is neither consistent nor inconsistent.  We can talk about the system of equations with that matrix as its coefficient matrix as being consistent or inconsistent. 
  2. “This matrix spans $$\mathbb{R}^n$$.” A spanning set for $$\mathbb{R}^n$$ is a set of vectors, so it doesn’t sense to say that the matrix spans $$\mathbb{R}^n$$.  We could talk about the columns of the matrix spanning $$\mathbb{R}^n$$ if the matrix has $$n$$ rows. 
  3. “These vectors have a unique solution.” A system of equations has a unique solution not a set of vectors.
  4. “The rank of these vectors is $$k$$.” A matrix has a rank.  You could form a matrix from these vectors in some way and then you could talk about the rank of that matrix. 

 

As you learn definitions, it’s really important to understand to which objects these definitions apply.  This can be tricky because the objects are often connected to each other.  It is easy to apply a term to some object to which it doesn’t apply.   Think carefully about the terms you use and do your best to use them correctly.  This process will help your understanding and it will definitely improve the proofs you write. 

"}], "type": "note", "tags": ["instructor-note", "pin", "tips"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 215, "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwclm3shhvy"], "id": "ls0etkg5d9t2zw", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456614249, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week2"], "nr": 245, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-01T14:32:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls3bg58zmbwja", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-01T14:32:59Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ls3dli3bnl35ge", "to": "ls3bg58p5snj9", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-01T15:33:08Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ls3dnxc67x42cs", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-01T15:35:01Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "wp2 q5 (recommended)", "created": "2024-02-01T14:32:59Z", "content": "I don't understand why we have to prove any vector orthogonal to u must be a scalar multiple of the vector [−u2 u1] T, such that v and perp u (x) must be scalar multiples of each other. Can't we directly say two vectors with the same direction are scalar multiples with each other because it is obvious that v an perp u (x) are on the same line?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 92, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-01T15:33:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Li Xuanhe", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwej5x9pg6c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-01T15:35:01Z", "content": "

Given that $$\vec{v}$$ and $$\mathrm{perp}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{x})$$ are orthogonal to $$\vec{u}$$, these two vectors may not be on the same line. It would be true if

  • $$\vec{u}$$ is nonzero, and
  • the problem is in $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ (or $$\mathbb{F}^2$$).

As you can see in the proof, it uses the conditions $$\vec{u}\neq \vec{0}$$ and $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ to work out the components explicitily.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-01T15:33:08Z", "content": "

Given that $$\vec{v}$$ and $$\mathrm{perp}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{x})$$ are orthogonal to $$\vec{u}$$, these two vectors may not be on the same line. It would be true if

  • $$\vec{u}$$ is nonzero, and
  • the problem is in $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ (or $$\mathbb{F}^2$$).

As you can see in the proof, it uses the fact of $$\vec{u}\neq \vec{0}$$ and $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ to work out the components explicitily.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwej5x9pg6c"], "children": [], "id": "ls3dli35j485gc", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls3bg58p5snj9", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456621651, "default_anonymity": "no"}

The way you have written things, you are assuming that the planes are parallel since they have the same direction vectors.  That is not necessarily true.

This approach would have to involve a lot of case work as you consider different options for the vectors involved.   I think would you get there eventually but it wouldn't be very pretty.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q2"], "nr": 247, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-01T20:08:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls3nfdczjyc6r6", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-01T20:08:18Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ls3oixdytt03i8", "to": "ls3nfdcrpj86r5", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-01T20:39:03Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ls3ojuduwhg5qw", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-01T20:39:46Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Format for a Transposed Vector", "created": "2024-02-01T20:08:18Z", "content": "

Hi,

I have a quick question. When I'm writing a vector in its transposed form, do I add commas between each values? 

For example, is it valid to write $$[5, 6, 7]^T$$?

Thank you for your time

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 85, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-01T20:39:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nadia Anwar", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdnjctl125", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-01T20:39:46Z", "content": "No, they should be delimited by spaces (i.e. $$\begin{bmatrix} 5 & 6 & 7 \end{bmatrix}^T$$) but sometimes this may be a bit hard to see:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 + i & 34 - 12\end{bmatrix}^T$$

so if it may be ambiguous, it is better to write it as a column vector.

Note for LaTeX: in the \begin{bmatrix} environment, you can use & characters to make spaces."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-01T20:39:03Z", "content": "No, they should be delimited by spaces (i.e. $$\begin{bmatrix} 5 & 6 & 7 \end{bmatrix}^T$$) but sometimes this may be a bit hard to see:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 + i & 34 - 12\end{bmatrix}^T$$

so if it may be ambiguous, it is better to write it as a column vector."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdnjctl125"], "children": [], "id": "ls3oixdqztf3i7", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls3nfdcrpj86r5", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456623770, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 142, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-02T17:24:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-02T17:24:34Z", "content": "

Remember that in RREF, the only nonzero entry in a pivot column can be the pivot itself.

Here, your second row, third column is a pivot, so the entry above it needs to be 0.

You can perform the operation $$R_1 \to R_1 - R_2$$ to zero it out.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week4"], "nr": 256, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-02T23:10:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls59dzdgrnd1il", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-02T23:10:51Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ls5aeomiygn1rq", "to": "ls59dzd8y9d1ik", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-02T23:39:23Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ls59dzd8y9d1ik", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-11T18:31:57Z", "cid": "lshudzclwnu12p", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ls59dzd8y9d1ik", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-11T18:34:44Z", "cid": "lshuhkai4al9b", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "to": "ls59dzd8y9d1ik", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-12T02:53:07Z", "cid": "lsicahke9jb35l"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week 4 practice problems Q4: How to apply the hint?", "created": "2024-02-02T23:10:51Z", "content": "

Hi, 

I am working on Q4 of practice problems week 4. When proving that if $$\vec{x} \in Null(A^TA)$$, then $$\vec{x} \in Null(A)$$, I am not sure how to proceed with the hint. I have attached my work below. I noticed in the solutions that they make reference to the dot product, but I am not sure why that works and how matrix multiplication can be associated with dot product (which produces a scalar). I appreciate the help.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week4", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 142, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-02T23:39:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vikas Nibhanupudi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwenjljntyg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-02T23:39:23Z", "content": "

I'm not sure if you intend what you are writing. 

Think about the type or the size of the vectors. At first, you have $$(A^\top A) \vec x = \vec 0$$.

The matrix $$A^\top A$$ is an $$n \times n$$ matrix, and $$\vec x \in \mathbb R^n$$, so $$(A^\top A) \vec x \in \mathbb R^n$$.

Then, when you "multiply by $$\vec x^\top$$" on the left, you have $$(A^\top A)\vec x \vec x^\top \in M_{n \times n}(\mathbb R)$$

which means that when you denote $$\vec 0$$ on the RHS, that $$\vec 0$$ is actually an $$n \times n$$ matrix of $$0$$s.

Perhaps what you meant is to take the vector $$A^\top A \vec x$$ and to take its dot product with $$\vec x$$:

$$\vec x \cdot (A^\top A \vec x) = \vec x \cdot \vec 0 = 0$$.

As a hint for continuing from here, remember that a different way to write the dot product $$\vec a \cdot \vec b$$ as a matrix-vector product is $$\vec a ^\top \vec b$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwenjljntyg"], "children": [], "id": "ls5aeomazjy1rp", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Do you know where we got the idea that "dot product a→⋅b→ as a matrix-vector product is a→⊤b→."?", "created": "2024-02-11T18:31:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Oh wait, is this referring to like taking the linear combination of the columns of a matrix where the scalars are the entries of the vector?", "created": "2024-02-11T18:34:44Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lshuhkai4al9b", "updated": "2024-02-11T18:34:44Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "It comes from the similarity between the way a dot product is calculated and the way matrix multiplication is performed. ", "created": "2024-02-12T02:53:07Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lsicahke9jb35l", "updated": "2024-02-12T02:53:07Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lshudzclwnu12p", "updated": "2024-02-13T16:07:11Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": ["krvaikp4js87pd"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls59dzd8y9d1ik", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456633320, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I'm confused how we know that rank([A|b]) is 2. I understand rank(A) is 2, but how do they know rank([A|b]) is also 2?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week3", "q3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 100, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-03T21:15:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-03T21:15:55Z", "content": "

Check proposition 3.6.4 in the course notes.

The idea is that if $$\text{rank}(A) < \text{rank}( [A \mid \vec b])$$, then augmenting $$A$$ with $$\vec b$$ must yield 1 new pivot in $$\vec b$$'s column. This clearly shows that the system is inconsistent, and you can check that the backward direction also holds.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week4"], "nr": 267, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-03T21:30:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls6l94fgz37cu", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-03T21:30:46Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ls6larr4wb4g5", "to": "ls6l94f6m3a7ct", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-03T21:32:02Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "null space", "created": "2024-02-03T21:30:46Z", "content": "To be clear, is finding a nullspace, is it finding the solution that makes the Matrix homogeneous?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 141, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-03T21:32:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1697485981}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-03T21:32:02Z", "content": "

The nullspace of $$A$$ refers to the set of all solutions $$\\vec x$$ so that $$A\\vec x = \\vec 0$$. That is:

\n

\n

$$\\vec x \\in \\text{Null}(A) \\iff A \\vec x = \\vec 0$$

Are pivots always 1? Moreover, is the system of linear equation somehow related to matrix multiplication?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q2", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Saivenkat Jilla", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdteqeyu1zj", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 108, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-04T17:36:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-04T17:39:07Z", "content": "

I think the convention is that the first column in a matrix corresponds to $$x_1$$, the second column to $$x_2$$, and so on, $$x_n$$ is a basic variable if its column has a pivot point in it. 

Pivots are not always 1, you turn them into 1 when you are turning the matrix into the reduced row echelon form.

I don't know if there is some other relation, but I think systems of linear equations are related to "matrix" multiplication in this way:

$$\begin{bmatrix} a&b&c \\ d&e&f \\ g&h&i\end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} ax_1+bx_2+cx_3 \\dx_1+ex_2+fx_3 \\gx_1+hx_2+ix_3 \end{bmatrix}$$

and then you can set the resulting matrix equal to the vector with the constant values for each equation to represent the system of linear equations

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-04T17:38:49Z", "content": "

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-04T17:36:58Z", "content": "

I think the convention is that the first column in a matrix corresponds to $$x_1$$, the second column to $$x_2$$, and so on, $$x_n$$ is a basic variable if its column has a pivot point in it. 

Pivots are not always 1, you turn them into 1 when you are turning the matrix into the reduced row echelon form.

I don't know if there is some other relation, but I think systems of linear equations are related to "matrix" multiplication in this way:

$$\begin{bmatrix} a&b&c \\ d&e&f \\ g&h&i\end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} ax_1+bx_2+cx_3 \\dx_1+ex_2+fx_3 \\gx_1+hx_2+ix_3 \end{bmatrix}$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-04T17:36:31Z", "content": "

Pivots are not always 1, you turn them into 1 when you are turning the matrix into the reduced row echelon form.

I don't know if there is some other relation, but I think systems of linear equations are related to "matrix" multiplication in this way:

$$\begin{bmatrix} a&b&c \\ d&e&f \\ g&h&i\end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} ax_1+bx_2+cx_3 \\dx_1+ex_2+fx_3 \\gx_1+hx_2+ix_3 \end{bmatrix}$$

Are you referring to the middle paragraph? It is proving that for any $$\vec{w}\in \mathbb{R}^2$$ and $$\vec{w}$$ is orthogonal to $$\vec{u}\neq 0$$, then $$\vec{w}$$ is a multiple of $$\begin{bmatrix} -u_2\\ u_1\end{bmatrix}$$.

Putting it into use, since both $$\mathrm{perp}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{x})$$ and $$\vec{v}$$ are orthogonal to $$\vec{u}\neq 0$$ in $$\mathbb{R}^2$$, $$\mathrm{perp}_{\vec{u}}(\vec{x})$$ and $$\vec{v}$$ are multiples of $$\begin{bmatrix} -u_2\\ u_1\end{bmatrix}$$ and consequently multiples of each other.

When writing the EROs that we're performing while working with a matrix:

Say we're multiplying R1 by -2 and adding it to R2, is it okay if we write it in the form "R2 - 2R1" instead of "R2 -> -2R1 + R2". I know the latter it only a little longer, but it is much easier for me to think about it in the first form while doing the ERO.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Writing EROs", "created": "2024-02-04T21:18:17Z", "content": "

How are these equivalent? Did we multiply the direction by 5? If so, how did the vector [1 -3/5 0] become [3 -1 2]?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week2", "q2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 143, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-04T22:23:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-04T22:23:15Z", "content": "You extract $$2\begin{bmatrix}1\\-1/5\\1\end{bmatrix}$$ from $$t\begin{bmatrix}1\\-1/5\\1\end{bmatrix}$$. As $$t$$ runs over all real numbers, so does $$(t-2)$$. Same for $$(t-2)/5$$."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwclm3shhvy"], "children": [], "id": "ls82kgzczl7di", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Wait so we add 2[1−1/51] to [1−3/50], and then divide  t[1−1/51] by 5?", "created": "2024-02-05T03:27:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

>>we add 2[1−1/51] to [1−3/50],

Right! Think of $$\{1+2k: k \in \mathbb{Z}\}=\{5+2k: k\in \mathbb{Z}\}$$. They are the same set.

>>then divide  t[1−1/51] by 5

It's not dividing by 5. You rewrite it as $$t\begin{bmatrix}a\\b\\c\end{bmatrix} = \tfrac{t}{5}\begin{bmatrix}5a\\5b\\5c\end{bmatrix}$$, and do a variable change since $$t/5$$ (call it new $$t$$) is still running over all reals.

Think of $$\{r: r\in \mathbb{R}\} = \{r/5 : r\in \mathbb{R}\}$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q2"], "nr": 298, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T00:08:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls86b7sz7ywlf", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-05T00:08:01Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ls86h6obmk9782", "to": "ls86b7spdfpld", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-05T00:12:40Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "What's the difference between these two definitions?", "created": "2024-02-05T00:08:01Z", "content": ""}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 98, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T00:12:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ruohan Jin", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwd3322255l", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T00:12:40Z", "content": "

The first one tells you a way of expressing vectors with terminal points on the plane.

The second one is the set of vectors whose terminal points are on the plane.

--------------

For example, 

  • All even numbers can be written as $$n=2k$$ for some integer $$k$$. 
  • The set of all even numbers is $$\{2k: k\in \mathbb{Z}\}$$.
"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwd3322255l"], "children": [], "id": "ls86h6o4c7u780", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls86b7spdfpld", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456677863, "default_anonymity": "no"}

According to textbook definition, rank must be calculated in RREF form. So the example for 5d given would contain a row of zeroes. Then 5e would be true since a matrix with r < m, must have 1 or more rows of zeroes. 

So what would be the solution here? Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q2", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Smeet Shah", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwda7cwkc6ez", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Li Xuanhe", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwej5x9pg6c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 102, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T05:47:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T05:47:27Z", "content": "A matrix with less than full rank doesn't have to have a row of zeroes, but its RREF must have a row of zeroes."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ls8ifq51xg328t", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "So the rank in RREF is just the max/full rank of an equivalent RREF matrix? {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q2", "practice_week2"], "nr": 304, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T14:16:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "ls90mlknb4t5sm", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-05T14:16:41Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ls92860j944ec", "to": "ls90mlkfaxz5sl", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-05T15:01:27Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ls928ln36ka5dm", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-05T15:01:47Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ls90mlkfaxz5sl", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-05T15:59:09Z", "cid": "ls94adhc50044y", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "to": "ls90mlkfaxz5sl", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-05T16:01:09Z", "cid": "ls94cy2lr481bx"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "WP2 Q4 (Warm Up)", "created": "2024-02-05T14:16:41Z", "content": "

I completed this question by finding the scalar equations of both planes, then solving for $$x$$ and $$y$$ in terms of $$z$$ to form a vector equation of a line, however I'm confused how the answers have this last step:

I stopped at the equation with the fractions inside. I understand that the second vector was multiplied by 5 but I'm not sure what operation was performed on the first vector. Would be grateful if someone could elaborate on this, thanks! 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week2", "q2", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sam Lee", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4dyzuzt6qr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 102, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T15:01:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T15:01:47Z", "content": "

Think of $$\{1+t7: t\in \mathbb{Z}\}$$. The parameter is over $$\mathbb{Z}$$. Adding any integral multiples of 7 to 1 does not change the set, say $$\{15+t7: t\in \mathbb{Z}\}$$.

Now you have $$\{\vec{x} + t\vec{v}: t\in \mathbb{R}\}$$, where the parameter is over $$\mathbb{R}$$. Adding any real multiples of $$\vec{v}$$ to $$\vec{x}$$ does not change the set.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T15:01:27Z", "content": "

Think of $$\{1+t7: t\in \mathbb{Z}\}$$. The parameter is over $$\mathbb{Z}$$. Adding any integral multiples of 7 to 1 does not change the set, say $$\{15+t7: t\in \mathbb{Z}\}$$.

Now you have $$\{\vec{x} + t\vec{v}: t\in \mathbb{R}\}$$, where the parameter is over $$\mathbb{R}$$. Adding any real multiples of $$\vec{v}$$ to $$\vec{x}$$ does not change the set.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q2", "practice_week2"], "nr": 305, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T14:33:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "ls917zsmu432mx", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-05T14:33:19Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "kjobx1y5ag46ny", "data": "ls93qti34xc6wt", "to": "ls917zsedmj2ms", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-05T15:43:57Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "WP2 Q5 warm-up -- Assume domain in the Reals?", "created": "2024-02-05T14:33:19Z", "content": "

I was writing the solution set for Q5, and I noticed that nowhere does the question say I am working exclusively over the reals. All of the constants are real numbers so I assume we are working in $$\\mathbb{R}$$-- is it okay to assume this if the domain isn't specified? Or should I use $$\\mathbb{C}$$ as the domain to be safe?\u00a0

\n

\n

I also assume that the quiz will be more specific but I figured I would ask in case I'm missing something. Thanks!\u00a0

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week2", "q2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 97, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T15:43:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kjobx1y5ag46ny", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T15:43:57Z", "content": "When not mentioned, and all constants are real, it is safe to assume the domain to the reals. The caveat is that some systems can be put into REFs using only integers, whilst others will have the leading 1 with the rest of the numbers as a mix of integers and fractions."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["krvaikp4js87pd"], "children": [], "id": "ls93lmggpjp7kr", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I thought you could put any system into RREF as well, what is the counterexample?", "created": "2024-02-05T16:49:10Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Correct me if I'm wrong but, you can put any system into "RREF", but some RREFs are REFs. So you can think of it as a matrix being in one of two states, either it is an RREF, or it isn't. Below is an example of two RREFs, but the right one is a true RREF, while the left one is a REF. 

", "created": "2024-02-05T17:18:38Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ls974kxadjg6ui", "updated": "2024-02-05T17:18:38Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

You are right that every matrix can be put into RREF, and all RREF are also REF.

However, the two matrices you illustrated are both in RREF. There is no such thing as a "true RREF"; either it is in RREF or it isn't.

The left matrix does not have a pivot in the third column, while the right matrix does have a pivot in the third column.

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["q2"], "nr": 313, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T17:32:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls97m6nfexw567", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-05T17:32:19Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ls97mk2vtaq67m", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-02-05T17:32:36Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ls97rqgs8va2b2", "to": "ls97m6n7l2h566", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-05T17:36:38Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "By the System Rank Theorem,", "created": "2024-02-05T17:32:36Z", "content": "If rank of A is r= m, then is that a spanning set for $$\\mathbb{R}^m$$"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "By the System Rank Theorem,", "created": "2024-02-05T17:32:19Z", "content": "If rank of A is r= m, then is that a spanning set for $$\\mathbb{R}^m$$"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 89, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T17:36:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Shihan Sharar", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1702155408, "lpvj0xmshic497": 1706729797}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdbxatel6pr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T17:36:38Z", "content": "Yes!

By system rank theorem, if $$\\text{rank}(A) = m$$, then the system $$A \\vec x = \\vec b$$ is consistent for every $$\\vec b \\in \\mathbb R^m$$, which means that $$\\mathbb R^m \\subseteq \\text{Col}(A)$$ (4.1.2), hence the columns of $$A$$ must be a spanning set for $$\\mathbb R^m$$."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdbxatel6pr"], "children": [], "id": "ls97rqgmij32b1", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls97m6n7l2h566", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456693779, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q2"], "nr": 316, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T17:46:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls984raaifr3yy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-05T17:46:45Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ls984ra1af73yx", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-05T17:49:30Z", "cid": "ls988aaxoui3fc", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ls989aetfxc3pa", "to": "ls984ra1af73yx", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-05T17:50:17Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "w3pp q5e)", "created": "2024-02-05T17:46:45Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 98, "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "nevermind i got it. the rank is 1 because the RREF form has rank 1. and the question asks for A, not RREF(A)", "created": "2024-02-05T17:49:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["krvaikp4js87pd"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls988aaxoui3fc", "updated": "2024-02-05T17:50:24Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T17:50:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T17:50:17Z", "content": "

To determine the rank of a matrix, we must look at how many pivots it has in its RREF. It doesn't matter what the current matrix looks like, we have to row reduce it first.

$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \overset{R_2 \to R_2 - R_1}\longrightarrow \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

which is in RREF (you should check this yourself). Then, we can see that there is only 1 pivot in the RREF, hence the rank of $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ is 1.

Perhaps where this is confusing you is that the answer would be different if the question asked for the number of zero rows in the RREF, as opposed to in its current form.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 317, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T17:50:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls989yo0zup4u2", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-05T17:50:48Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ls98doay8op6l6", "to": "ls989ynewm44u1", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-05T17:53:41Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Identity Matrix", "created": "2024-02-05T17:50:48Z", "content": "For identity matrix, does it matter which of the diagonals are all 1s? Can a matrix with two such diagnals be an identity matrix?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 71, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T17:53:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Junyan Ye", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwb17ooi55le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T17:53:41Z", "content": "

The identity matrix $$I_{n, m}$$ has

$$I_{n, m}(i, j) = \begin{cases} 1, & i = j \\ 0, & i \neq j\end{cases}$$

where $$I_{n, m}(i, j)$$ denotes the entry at the $$i$$-th row and $$j$$-column.

This is to say that if you start at the top left-corner, there is a $$1$$ there, and you keep moving down-right. That diagonal is full of $$1$$s, and every other entry is $$0$$.

You should check that this satisfies the properties of the identity matrix.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwb17ooi55le"], "children": [], "id": "ls98doar6pm6l5", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls989ynewm44u1", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456698006, "default_anonymity": "no"}
