"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 98, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T18:18:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Khushi Jirge", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwc2gwxor57c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T18:18:26Z", "content": "

You are arbitrarily given two vectors $$\vec u, \vec v$$, of which you only know that they are orthogonal.

You can't change the value of $$\vec u$$ by setting it equal to $$\text{perp}_{\vec v}(\vec a)$$, but you are on the right track. As a hint, try picking an arbitrary vector $$\vec a$$ and look at:

$$\text{perp}_{\vec v}(\vec a) = \vec a - \text{proj}_{\vec v}(\vec a)$$

What does this equation tell you about how you can express $$\vec a$$?

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwc2gwxor57c"], "children": [], "id": "ls999hkk9yq6tm", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls98w8x8v2u66w", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456699068, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q2"], "nr": 319, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T18:33:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls99seiw5lc2zw", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-05T18:33:08Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ls9afurk21f3ln", "to": "ls99seim5zq2zt", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-05T18:51:22Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Terminal points V and W", "created": "2024-02-05T18:33:08Z", "content": "

The terminal points, 𝑉 and 𝑊, associated with the vectors, #»𝑣 and #»𝑤, are not usually on the plane. In fact, 𝑉 is a point on the plane if and only if #»𝑢 ∈ Span{ #»𝑣 , #»𝑤}; that is, if and only if 𝑈 lies on the plane through the origin that contains 𝑉 and 𝑊.

Could someone explain this part?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 87, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-05T18:51:22Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Shihan Sharar", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1702155408, "lpvj0xmshic497": 1706729797}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdbxatel6pr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-05T18:51:22Z", "content": "

The plane being described has directional vectors $$\vec v, \vec w$$ i.e. has the form

$$P = \{ \vec u + s \vec v + t \vec w : s, t \in \mathbb R\}$$.

the set $$\{s \vec v + t \vec w : s, t \in \mathbb R\}$$ already defines a plane which passes through the origin (by taking $$s, t = 0$$), so if you add $$\vec u$$ to every element in this plane, it shifts the plane by that vector $$\vec u$$. Then, the terminal points $$V, W$$ corresponding to $$\vec v, \vec w$$ can only be on $$P$$ if $$\vec u \in \text{Span}\{\vec v, \vec w)\}$$, as otherwise they would have been shifted away.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdbxatel6pr"], "children": [], "id": "ls9afurdtki3lm", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ls99seim5zq2zt", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456700127, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 334, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-06T04:50:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ls9vtxploup3fn", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-06T04:50:11Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ls9wfjnr71t6ic", "to": "ls9vtxpelaa3fm", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-06T05:07:00Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "understanding class note", "created": "2024-02-06T04:50:11Z", "content": "Hi, I am a bit of confuse how do we get e1 e2…here by having the eros. Could someone explain it?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 92, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-06T05:07:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Erin Fan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwayddv4r53q", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-06T05:07:00Z", "content": "

I think there is a typo. Between the second and third matrix in the line of 5 matrices, the row operation performed should be $$R_2 \to R_2 - 3R_1$$.

To find a matrix which corresponds to a row operation, you can apply that row operation to the identity matrix as a matrix on the left (you should really try this out with a few and check that it makes sense).

For instance, in the example above, the first step is to swap $$R_1 \leftrightarrow R_2$$. If we apply this operation to the identity matrix, we get $$\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$, so

$$\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

Then, we apply the row operation of $$R_2 \to R_2 - 3R_1$$, which, if we apply this to the identity matrix, we get $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ -3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$, hence

$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & -6 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ -3 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

To see why this is true, we can try by picking any ERO. Write out the identity as a bunch of row vectors:

$$I = \begin{bmatrix} \vec v_1 ^\top \\ \hline \vdots \\ \hline \vec v_m^\top \end{bmatrix}$$, $$\vec v_i \in \mathbb R^m$$.

Then, for each row operation, write out how that would change $$I$$ (e.g. if we wanted to do $$\vec v_i^\top \to \vec v_i^\top + \vec v_j^\top$$, then we can write our new matrix as

$$J := \begin{bmatrix} \vec v_1^\top \\ \hline \vdots \\ \hline \vec v_i ^\top+ \vec v_j^\top \\ \hline \vdots \\ \vec v_m^\top \end{bmatrix}$$

and then check that $$JA$$ gives the desired row operation on $$A$$ (you should convince yourself of this part).

I don't follow your logic, but you are confusing matrices with augmented matrices. Matrices aren't consistent or inconsistent because they don't represent systems of linear equations. "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 110, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-07T16:16:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Taehyeon Kim", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwehero027lg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "kjobx1y5ag46ny", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-07T16:16:18Z", "content": "This may happen when within the list of vectors that you are spanning there is one or more vectors that can be written as a combination of the other. So, if $$\\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\\\ 0 \\\\ -1\\end{bmatrix}$$ could be spanned from the other two, including it on the spanning list will not make a difference.

Another example is Span{$$\\vec{e}_1, \\vec{e}_2, \\vec{0}$$} = Span{$$\\vec{e}_1, \\vec{e}_2$$}. The zero vector being included in the spanning set will clearly not generate any different vectors via liner combinations, since it is a combination of the other two, i.e., $$0\\cdot\\vec{e}_1+0\\cdot\\vec{e}_2 = \\vec{0}$$."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehero027lg"], "children": [], "id": "lsbzs4inogv1pd", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "do I need to write down like that when I take a test?\u00a0", "created": "2024-02-07T16:17:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "In a test, to show that the spans are the same you would have to present some argument, which could be similar to one above in the sense that you have to show how that vector is a linear combination of the other two. Otherwise, we can't be sure that we can indeed checked why the two sets are the same.", "created": "2024-02-07T16:20:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Taehyeon Kim", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwehero027lg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "kjobx1y5ag46ny", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwehero027lg"], "id": "lsbzwwkikc2253", "updated": "2024-02-07T16:20:21Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsbzt3aivkp5ym", "updated": "2024-02-07T20:38:05Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsbzkuk2ws52qd", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456725502, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 344, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-07T17:42:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsc2vj9tnb3h2", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-07T17:42:56Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lsc34t2g5uv3eg", "to": "lsc2vj9mx3b3h1", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-07T17:50:08Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "week 4 practice problem", "created": "2024-02-07T17:42:56Z", "content": "

what does this mean? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 109, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-07T17:50:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Taehyeon Kim", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwehero027lg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-07T17:50:08Z", "content": "

The $$\vphantom{}^\top$$ or $$\vphantom{}^T$$ gives the transpose of a matrix, which flips it along the main diagonal (@24), so the left $$\vec u^\top \vec v$$ represents matrix-vector multiplication (where $$\vec u^\top$$ is a $$1 \times n$$ matrix). Writing out 
$$\vec u = \begin{bmatrix} u_1 \\ \vdots \\ u_n\end{bmatrix},\vec v = \begin{bmatrix} v_1 \\ \vdots \\ v_n\end{bmatrix}$$

you should check that the matrix multiplication is the same as the dot product.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehero027lg"], "children": [], "id": "lsc34t28hub3ef", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsc2vj9mx3b3h1", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456726561, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week4"], "nr": 345, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-07T20:26:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsc8qbkd4vn3xg", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-07T20:26:50Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lsc90b64mqw5f9", "to": "lsc8qbk2al03xe", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-07T20:34:36Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lsc8qbk2al03xe", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-07T22:22:19Z", "cid": "lsccuu9dycc2am", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "lsc8qbk2al03xe", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-08T18:11:29Z", "cid": "lsdjc3sqrhm2sn"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Question 1d) Practice Problem", "created": "2024-02-07T20:26:50Z", "content": "

For the solution to the recommended question 1d), what is the significance of b = [5 1 0]^T  / how did they find it?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 83, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-07T20:34:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-07T20:34:36Z", "content": "

$$\vec b = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{bmatrix}$$ is just a vector in the solution set.

They found that $$x_3 = 1, x_2 = t, x_1 = 5 - 4t$$ parameterizes the solution, so taking $$t = 0$$ yields a point, which happens to be the easiest point to find.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsc90b5y3r45f8", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

s = t+1 implies that t = s-1 right? But when doing that substitution, I don't get the result of S2.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 349, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-08T12:59:39Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lsd872ztlfz27z", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-08T12:59:39Z"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "A More Visual Approach to Linear Algebra", "created": "2024-02-08T12:59:39Z", "content": "

I would like to recommend a series of YouTube videos called "The Essence of Linear Algebra" produced by Grant Sanderson on his 3Blue1Brown channel. 

https://www.3blue1brown.com/essence-of-linear-algebra-page

Sanderson makes use of a lot of great visualizations that I think are helpful and way beyond my video production skills.  These visualizations are helpful to make some of the abstract ideas of linear algebra more concrete.  The challenge is that the order of material presented in the videos doesn't correspond exactly to the order of the material in our course so when you watch a video on a topic we have covered in our course already, it may include things that we haven't yet covered.   I do believe that the first video on vectors doesn’t introduce anything that we haven’t talked about.  https://www.3blue1brown.com/lessons/vectors

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 171, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-08T20:09:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-08T20:09:07Z", "content": "This is not true. We have $$\left(\vec{u}^T\vec{v}\right)_{1,1}=\vec{u}\cdot\vec{v}$$. This is just matrix multiplication. Try it!"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["krvaikp4js87pd"], "children": [], "id": "lsdnjdrywqq4o3", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "L.H.S gives a vector but R.H.S gives a scalar.", "created": "2024-02-08T20:36:00Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "The left-hand side gives a vector/matrix with value $$\begin{bmatrix}\vec{u}\cdot\vec{v}\end{bmatrix}$$.", "created": "2024-02-08T20:37:17Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lsdojm4pre11k2", "updated": "2024-02-08T20:37:17Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsdohy91l0s5uq", "updated": "2024-02-08T20:37:17Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-08T23:10:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-08T23:10:35Z", "content": "

The student answer is correct, but the matrix multiplication $$\vec u ^\top \vec v$$ gives a $$1 \times 1$$ matrix, which we often canonically associate with the value inside of that $$1 \times 1$$ matrix.

i.e. if we ever write $$\vec u^\top \vec v \in \mathbb R$$ or in any other way implicitly assuming that $$u^\top v$$ is a real-value or complex-value, then we actually mean to write $$(\vec u^\top \vec v)_{1, 1}$$.

We choose to write $$\vec u^\top \vec v$$ because writing $$(\vec u^\top \vec v)_{1, 1}$$ is very pedantic and conveys almost no extra meaning.

Is there supposed to be a photo attached? I don’t see one

----

Edit:

The theorem states that if you have a solution set to a homogenous system, and you wish to derive a solution set to a non-homogenous system, then if $$\vec x_p$$ satisfies $$A \vec x_p = \vec b$$, then you know that $$\vec x_p + \vec x$$, $$\vec x \in S$$ is also a solution to the non-homogenous system, because

$$A(\vec x_p + \vec x) = \underbrace{A \vec x_p}_{= \vec b} + \underbrace{A \vec x}_{= \vec 0} = \vec b$$

Also I think the same thing applies to Q9d if I'm not mistaken"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T04:04:09Z", "content": "Yeah I think it might be wrong was about to put up a post about this."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsfjy4z7uyo98", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T05:58:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T05:58:20Z", "content": "

I believe you have your dimensions mixed up.

When we say a matrix is of size $$m \times n$$, it has $$m$$ rows and $$n$$ columns. In general, when we perform matrix multiplication, for $$A \in M_{m \times n}(\mathbb F), B \in M_{n \times p}(\mathbb F)$$, the product $$AB$$ has size $$m \times p$$.

Note that the second dimension of $$A$$ and the first dimension of $$B$$ must be the same (otherwise you are taking the dot product of two things of different dimension).

Lastly, recall that in matrix multiplication (say $$AB$$), we are taking the dot product of rows of $$A$$ with columns of $$B$$.

The solution given is correct (I just verified it, too).

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsfo0zabdctdx", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "But isn't it A + B = 3 x 2 matrix and then the transpose of that is 2 x 3 so then C being a 3 x 2 matrix the size is 2 x 2 with m = 2, n = 3, p =2.", "created": "2024-02-10T06:02:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

You are correct in that $$A + B$$ has size $$3 \times 2$$, and $$(A + B)^\top$$ has size $$2 \times 3$$, but the matrix product is $$3 \times 2$$ by $$2 \times 3$$. The second number of the first matrix and the first number of the second matrix have to line up, and the size of the resulting matrix is given by the first number of the first matrix and the second number of the second matrix.

This is to say in general, for a matrix product that is $$m \times n$$ by $$n \times p$$, the resulting matrix will have size $$m \times p$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 358, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T07:57:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsfs9o428ux7mt", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T07:57:04Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lsg1q10fur342e", "to": "lsfs9o3tlha7ms", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-02-10T12:21:44Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Struggling a lot with turning a matrix into REF, RREF", "created": "2024-02-10T07:57:04Z", "content": "

I seem to be struggling a lot with getting the correct elementary row operations for me to turn a matrix/system of equations into REF or RREF quickly. I would often have to do SO many operations (and often stray the wrong way while I'm doing all of them), so what I am doing is probably inefficient. I don't think I have a good intuitive grasp of what I need to do when I see a matrix like this with so many coefficients and terms:

How can I get better at doing these quickly?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "tips"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 92, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T12:21:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T12:21:44Z", "content": "

my strategy is to try to get each pivot to equal 1 (starting with the one in position 1,1) one column at a time so it's easier to use ERO to eliminate all other coeffs in that column. i like to start off with making the coefficient in position 1,1 equal to 1 as i can then get rid of the rest of the coefficients in column 1 using elementary row operations. i would then simplify, and repeat the process with the next column that can have a pivot.

for a question like this, if i want the coeff at 1,1 to equal 1, i could swap r4 and r1. i'd then use ERO: r2 -> r2-4r1, r3 -> r3+3r1, r4 -> r4-2r1. after simplifying, r2=r3=r4, so using ERO: r3 -> r3-r2, r4 -> r4-r2, so we end up with two zero rows. after this step, the next possible column with a pivot is column 3, so you could repeat this process there. i hope this makes a little bit of sense :,)))) 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4"], "children": [], "id": "lsg1q104q2x42d", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsfs9o3tlha7ms", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456741390, "default_anonymity": "no"}

>>How does this imply that A is the zero matrix?

This follows from Lemma Column Extraction (p100) in the course notes. 

>>I'm confused how this differs from just assuming that any system has a homogenous solution to find nullspace.

Quanfications are different! As you said, every homogenous system has at least one solution, but not evrey system has the solution set being the whole space. This question is saying that fix a system of linear equation, if nullspace is the whole space then the coefficient matrix is zero matrix.

When I used the formula I got a different answer than if I were to use the algorithm"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 62, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T17:37:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Zhenchao Ge", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1700800406_200.jpg", "id": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/llux8psc8tj5zh/1700800406_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T17:37:17Z", "content": "Yes, you can use the algorithm. Both should give you the same answer. In fact, the formula comes from doing the algorithm on a general 2x2 matrix, $$\begin{bmatrix} a \ b \\ c \ d \end{bmatrix}$$."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["llux8psc8tj5zh"], "children": [], "id": "lsgczu85n3n42x", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "When I try to find the inverse of $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2\\ 3&5 \end{bmatrix}$$ I would get $$\begin{bmatrix} 3 & -1\\ -9/5& 4/5 \end{bmatrix}$$ using the algorithm rather than the right answer, but I can't see where the mistake occurred. ", "created": "2024-02-10T17:43:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I think it should look like this:


\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 & 0 \\ 3 & 5 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}

$$R_{2} \rightarrow R_{2} - 3R_{1}$$

\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & -3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}

$$R_{1} \rightarrow R_{1} + 2R_{2}$$

\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -5 & 2 \\ 0 & -1 & -3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}

$$R_{2} \rightarrow -R_{2}$$

\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -5 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 & 3 & -1 \end{bmatrix}

So, the inverse is $$\begin{bmatrix} -5 & 2 \\ 3 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$$.

For a vector to be orthogonal to $$\text{span}\{\vec v , \vec w\}$$, it needs only to be orthogonal to both $$\vec v, \vec w$$, so if we want to find such a $$\vec u$$, set

$$\vec u \cdot \vec v = 0, \vec u \cdot \vec w = 0$$.

You can write out both systems and solve for the $$\vec u$$ (in general, there should be many, many free variables, assuming $$n > 0$$).

Alternatively, you can take an arbitrary vector $$\vec w$$ and take $$\text{perp}_{\vec v}(\text{perp}_{\vec u}(\vec w))$$ (you should take a look at the solutions to WA1 q3b if you haven't, as they discuss the orthogonality of this vector to $$\vec u, \vec v$$.

This is asking for a smallest spanning set that can span a given space. 

For instance, to span $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ one needs at least two vectors. One vector isn't sufficient and three or more vectors may be redundant. Not arbitrarily two vectors could span $$\mathbb{R}^2$$. You need to take them smartly.

In this problem, you want to find such a set that spans $$\mathrm{Col}(A)$$. The algorithm tells you that (1) reduce $$A$$ to $$\mathrm{REF}(A)$$; (2) Take the original columns of $$A$$ cooresponding to the pivot positions. 

>>why do we keep the columns of A with basic variables?

This is a great question! We will learn the proof very soon. If you are interested in it, you can read Prop 8.3.6 (p201) in the course notes.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T18:38:06Z", "content": "

This is asking for a smallest spanning set that can span a given space. 

For instance, to span $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ one needs at least two vectors. One vector isn't sufficient and three or more vectors may be redundant. Not arbitrarily two vectors could span $$\mathbb{R}^2$$. You need to take them smartly.

In this problem, you want to find such a set that spans $$\mathrm{Col}(A)$$. The algorithm tells you that (1) reduce $$A$$ to $$\mathrm{REF}(A)$$; (2) Take the original columns of $$A$$ cooresponding to the pivot positions. 

>>why do we keep the columns of A with basic variables?

This is a great question! We will learn the proof very soon. If you are interested in it, you read Prop 8.3.6 (p201) in the course notes.

What's the difference between 0 and $$\vec{0}$$

Is it wrong if I say $$\vec{u}$$ and $$\vec{v}$$ is orthogonal if $$\vec{u}$$ . $$\vec{v}$$ = $$\vec{0}$$, not 0

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 72, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T18:46:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T18:46:01Z", "content": "Yes, as 0 is a scaler while the zero "vector" is a vector, the basic physics definition between a scaler and a vector is that a scaler has only magnitude "size" while a vector has both magnitude and direction.

Our usage of the vector arrows over letters is merely a convention to allow the reader to easily infer which variables are vectors and others are scalars.

Writing $$\vec u \cdot \vec v = \vec 0$$ is technically not incorrect, because $$\vec 0$$ could be the vector in the vector space $$\mathbb R$$, but in general we want to reserve the vector arrow for elements of $$\mathbb R^n$$ (such as $$\vec u, \vec v$$, and we don't write the vector arrow for elements of $$\mathbb R$$ (such as $$\vec u \cdot \vec v$$).

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Wania Saqib", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwekj0scwfe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 80, "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

im confused about that question too, why not a matrix like [0 1 | 7]

                                                                                             [1 0 | 8]

", "created": "2024-02-10T21:27:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Check @457", "created": "2024-02-12T15:50:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "kjobx1y5ag46ny", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lsj41k7t5ufq1", "updated": "2024-02-12T15:50:00Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsgl7ubub7i6ad", "updated": "2024-02-12T15:50:01Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T22:28:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T22:28:46Z", "content": "

Note that the system specifies that all solutions are exclusively integer points.

The set of all integer points $$\begin{bmatrix} n \\ m \end{bmatrix}, n, m \in \mathbb Z$$ might satisfy a system

$$\mathcal O_{2 \times 2} x = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

but a lot of non-integer points such as $$\begin{bmatrix} 1.5 \\ 0.5 \end{bmatrix}$$ also satisfy this system.

Something to note is that for $$A \in M_{m \times n}(\mathbb R), \vec b \in \mathbb R^m$$, if $$\vec u, \vec v \in \mathbb R^n$$ satisfy $$A \vec u = \vec b, A \vec v = \vec b$$, then the midpoint of $$\vec u$$ and $$\vec v$$, given by

$$\vec z = \frac 12 \vec u + \frac 12 \vec v$$ also satisfies

$$A(\vec z) = A\left(\frac12 \vec u + \frac12 \vec v \right) = \frac 12 A\vec u + \frac 12 A\vec v = \frac 12 \vec b + \frac 12 \vec b = \vec b$$

hence $$\vec z$$ is also a solution for the linear system $$A \vec x = \vec b$$. From here, you can easily derive that no solution to any linear system can be exclusively the set of all integer points.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsgneovb2ju5b3", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwekj0scwfe"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsgkk3npl6pjg", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456756207, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 374, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T21:17:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgkuwwf2c54a0", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T21:17:24Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lsgnmwcqzto5ta", "to": "lsgkuww7tm49z", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-10T22:35:09Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "terminal points on the plane", "created": "2024-02-10T21:17:24Z", "content": "

I don't understand why "terminal points of $$\vec{v}$$ and $$\vec{w}$$ are on the plane iff plane goes through the origin"

Isn't plane infinite so it could contain any points?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 60, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T22:35:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T22:35:09Z", "content": "

If you have a plane of the form $$\vec p = \vec u + \alpha \vec v + \beta \vec w$$, where $$\vec u \notin \text{span}\{\vec v, \vec w\}$$, then note that if $$\vec u = \vec 0$$, then the plane clearly passes through the origin because you can take $$\alpha, \beta = 0$$. Then, if we take $$\vec u \neq \vec 0$$ with $$\vec u \notin \text{span}\{\vec v, \vec w\}$$, adding $$\vec u$$ to every point on the plane "shifts" that plane by the vector $$\vec u$$. You can think of this as moving the plane (keeping it parallel) until it reaches the terminal point of $$\vec u$$. From here, you can clearly see that neither of the terminal points of $$\vec v, \vec w$$ still remain on the plane.

To show this algebraically, for the forward direction, you would show that $$\vec u \in \text{span}\{\vec v, \vec w\}$$, and for the backward direction, you would show that you must have $$\vec u \in \text{span}\{\vec v, \vec w\}$$ because you can write 

$$\vec 0 = \vec u + \alpha \vec v + \beta \vec w$$ for some $$\alpha, \beta \in \mathbb R$$ since $$\vec 0$$ is on the plane.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsgnmwcktnj5t9", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsgkuww7tm49z", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456758362, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Week4 Q2b", "created": "2024-02-10T21:30:55Z", "content": "For this question: , is it good enough to explain that the ith row is multiplied by xi, and the ith column is multiplied by yi (and the reverse for the right side), and explaining how it implies that the rows and columns of the Matrix are the same?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 80, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T22:39:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T22:39:31Z", "content": "

I don't follow your description of your idea: how does this imply that the "rows and columns [...] are the same"? (and what does it mean for a row and column to be the same?)

Recall that if $$\vec e_j$$ is the $$j$$-vector of the standard basis vector (i.e. has a $$1$$ at the $$j$$-th entry and $$0$$s everywhere else), then $$A \vec e_j$$ gives the $$j$$-th column of $$A$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsgnsibl6gmfd", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "How does that prove the statement for all $$\vec{y}$$ and $$\vec{x}$$ if we assume that it's only for the standard basis vector?", "created": "2024-02-10T23:35:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

The assumption is that equality hold for all vectors $$\vec{x}$$ and $$\vec{y}$$.  This is our assumption and not what we are trying to prove.  If it's true for all vectors, then it is definitely true for the standard basis vectors. 

They then use these special cases of the assumption to prove that $$a_{ij}= a_{ji}$$ and so $$A=A^T$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 379, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T22:07:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgmn1jml7y6dy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T22:07:16Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lsgo03fhy7s6a7", "to": "lsgmn1jeel66dx", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-10T22:45:25Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Confusion about finding the scaler eq. of a plane", "created": "2024-02-10T22:07:16Z", "content": "

Hi, I'm confused about how we get to the second last step for finding a scaler equation for the plane. Why are we using the cross product vector with the (x - 1) etc...

Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 77, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T22:45:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "camariut@uwaterloo.ca", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8gwt19q556", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T22:45:25Z", "content": "

For scalar equations of the form $$ax + by + cz = 0$$, it is clear to see that $$a, b, c$$ is a normal of the plane because

$$\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{bmatrix} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} = a x + by + cz$$

hence any point $$(x, y, z)$$ on the plane satisfies that it is orthogonal to the normal vector. Moreover, you will note that $$(0, 0, 0)$$ is on a plane of the form $$ax + by + cz = 0$$. If instead we know of a different point such as $$(\alpha, \beta, \gamma)$$ which is on the plane, then we can "shift" the plane, following the same idea as shifting functions:

$$a(x - \alpha) + b(y - \beta) + c(z - \gamma) = 0$$ shifts this plane so that $$(\alpha, \beta, \gamma)$$ is on the plane. After this step, we can expand and simplify

This follows from the equivalent definition of the dot product:

$$\vec u \cdot \vec v = \|\vec u\| \|\vec v\| \cos \theta$$ where $$\theta$$ measures the angle between $$\vec u, \vec v$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsgo10f974z8w", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "And it is x + y because they are multiplying it by the 0 0 1 matrix given?", "created": "2024-02-10T22:47:10Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 381, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T22:45:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgo0qmb3awbw", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T22:45:55Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lsgo8g1zza267m", "to": "lsgo0qlmdjybt", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-10T22:51:55Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lsgo8lsuxew6k3", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-10T22:52:02Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Question regarding null space and span", "created": "2024-02-10T22:45:55Z", "content": "

I had the following two questions: 

(1) Is the null space of a matrix always a span of vectors? Is there a way to find of how many vectors it's a span of?

(2) If we are given a solution set to a system how do we find the general solution (i.e. the solution to the corresponding homogenous system)?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 62, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T22:51:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Arav Sharma", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ktn8lt6g2yi515", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T22:52:02Z", "content": "

Good questions!

(1) Yes! We will cover more on this in later weeks, and we will provide a more rigorous meaning of "how many vectors" it is a span of. The short answer is that it is the nullity of the matrix, and the long answer has to do with linear independence of vectors (you can look this up yourself if you would like) and the fact that the nullspace of a matrix is a vector space itself, and has a dimension, which measures exactly the least number of vectors needed to span its entire set. It turns out the nullity of a matrix is exactly the dimension of the nullspace.

(2) You should take a look at 3.11.9 in the course notes.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q1"], "nr": 386, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T23:33:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgpq67xysq3rp", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-10T23:33:41Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lsgpyzxsbrm3qb", "to": "lsgpq67q79u3ro", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-10T23:40:33Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Q1 T/F Question", "created": "2024-02-10T23:33:41Z", "content": "My question was asked at @223, but I still can't wrap my head around this T/F question. Wouldn't the perpendicular of a perpendicular just be the projection?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q1", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 74, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-10T23:40:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-10T23:40:33Z", "content": "

Suppose we have $$\vec u, \vec v$$ where $$\vec u \cdot \vec v = 0$$, i.e. $$\vec u, \vec v$$ are orthogonal.

Then, $$\text{perp}_{\vec v}(\vec u) = \vec u$$ (draw out a diagram and check that this is true).

So, when you try to take the perpendicular of a vector onto an orthogonal vector, you get the same vector back.

Since $$\text{perp}_{\vec v}(\vec u)$$ is always orthogonal with $$\vec v$$, we can conclude that taking the perpendicular of $$\text{perp}_{\vec v}(\vec u)$$ onto $$\vec v$$ should return itself, i.e. 

$$\text{perp}_{\vec v}(\text{perp}_{\vec v}(\vec u)) = \text{perp}_{\vec v}(\vec u)$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lsgpyzxlilb3q9", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsgpq67q79u3ro", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456771234, "default_anonymity": "no"}

This is the definition of $$\\text{Col}(A)$$:

\n

\n

$$\\text{Col}(A) = \\{\\vec y \\in \\mathbb R^m : \\exists\\ \\vec x \\in \\mathbb R^n, A \\vec x = \\vec y\\}$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw91fw8w2x8"], "children": [], "id": "lsgq2wi0kq23d5", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lsgq1ev8yhy3w0", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456772340, "default_anonymity": "no"}

$$\vec u \times \vec v = \vec 0$$ does not imply that $$\vec u = \vec 0$$ or $$\vec v = \vec 0$$ (consider if $$\vec u = \vec v$$).

The proof assumed that $$u_1 \neq 0$$, so remember that since $$u_1, v_1$$ are real valued, the $$u_1$$ is a real number, so

$$\frac{v_1}{u_1} u_1 = \frac{u_1}{u_1}v_1 = v_1$$

$$\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 0\\0\end{bmatrix}$$ $$\begin{bmatrix} 4\\ 0\\0\end{bmatrix}$$ and see for yourself

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 389, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T00:02:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lsgqqqltjdz3fs", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-11T00:02:07Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lsgqzo7kb7q15q", "to": "lsgqqqlln7z3fq", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-11T00:09:04Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lsgqqqlln7z3fq", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-11T00:10:56Z", "cid": "lsgr2277udfei", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "lsgqqqlln7z3fq", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-11T00:55:07Z", "cid": "lsgsmw5n56g1nw"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "How did they come to the conclusion that s+r(t-s) is a solution.", "created": "2024-02-11T00:02:07Z", "content": ""}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 79, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T00:09:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Shihan Sharar", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1702155408, "lpvj0xmshic497": 1706729797}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdbxatel6pr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T00:09:04Z", "content": "

Write $$A\vec x = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}$$ so that it represents the system.

$$\vec s, \vec t$$ solve the system, so

$$A \vec s = A \vec t$$. Then,

$$A(\vec s + r(\vec t - \vec s)) = A \vec s + r \underbrace{(A \vec t - A \vec s)}_{=0} = A \vec s$$

hence $$\vec s + r(\vec t - \vec s)$$ also solves the system for all $$r \in \mathbb R$$.

Note that since $$\vec s \neq \vec t$$, taking different $$r$$ parameters indeed yields different solutions.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 87, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T00:26:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T00:26:13Z", "content": "

I believe the issue here is that you are using the points as vectors for your cross product. When using it to find a normal vector, cross product only applies to two, non parallel vectors which lie on the plane.

The strategy here is to get two vectors by subtracting our points. Think $$\vec{v}=A-B$$ and $$\vec{u}=C-B$$.

This will give you the vectors which link these points, which should then lie on the plane. Then just do exactly what you did above, take the cross product, then dot product the result with a point :)

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["krvaikp4js87pd"], "children": [], "id": "lsgrlpst4185yx", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T01:01:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T01:01:14Z", "content": "

The student answer is correct. $$A$$ and $$B$$ are on the plane, but the vectors corresponding to $$A$$ and $$B$$ don't have to be directional vectors of the plane. In fact, this happens if and only if the plane does not pass through the origin (think about why).

Thus, the normal you computed is not necessarily a normal for the plane.

I'm not sure I understand the backwards implication proof here. How does having the augmented matrix R with the standard basis imply that the system is inconsistent? And also how does doing "reverse ERO" get you back to the b vector?

For more context, this is what being proven and the beginning of the proof 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 69, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T16:46:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T16:46:42Z", "content": "

$$R$$ has at least one row of zeros at the bottom (the $$m$$-th row).  So the bottom row of $$[R|\vec{e}_m]$$ is of the form $$[0 \cdots 0|1]$$.  Therefore the system is inconsistent. 

A series of EROs got us to the RREF.  For every ERO done, there is an ERO that "undoes" it.  If we do all the EROs that undo all the EROS that we did to get to the RREF, then we will get back to $$A$$ on the LHS and some vector $$\vec{b}$$ on the RHS. 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lshqmmxfkjn1hc", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 402, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T12:49:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lshi56sdrd1su", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-11T12:49:11Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lshqpntbptx6ne", "to": "lshi56s415x1st", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-11T16:49:03Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "purpose homogenous systems", "created": "2024-02-11T12:49:11Z", "content": "what is the purpose of putting a system into a homogenous state? is it purely to get the nullspace? or are there other reasons and significant behind the solution set that is obtained?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 61, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T16:49:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1697485981}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T16:49:03Z", "content": "

The solution set to all systems of equations which have the coefficient matrix $$A$$ can be expressed in terms of the solution set to the homogeneous system with coefficient matrix $$A$$.\u00a0

\n

\n

This week we will look at how the nullspace tells us something about the linear transformation that is determined by $$A$$.\u00a0

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt"], "children": [], "id": "lshqpnt56316nc", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lshi56s415x1st", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456788199, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 403, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T12:51:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lshi8669mmb4hv", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-11T12:51:30Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lshqu4ic82k68w", "to": "lshi8660idd4hu", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-11T16:52:31Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "spanning sets", "created": "2024-02-11T12:51:30Z", "content": "if you have a spanning set of 4 vectors does that imply that is spans R5? and to generalize that question more does having n vectors in a spanning set imply that that set spans R(n+1), given that all the vectors in that set are not parallel?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 64, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T16:52:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1697485981}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T16:52:31Z", "content": "

The number of vectors in a spanning set doesn't tell us anything.\u00a0 For example,\u00a0 if we add another vector to the spanning set which is a scalar multiple of the vectors in the spanning set, then we will have another spanning set for the same space, but it has more than one vector.\u00a0

\n

\n

However, if none of these vectors are linear combinations of each other, then we will be able to say something more about the span of these vectors and it has something to do with the dimension of the space.\u00a0 However, we haven't got to the formal idea of dimension yet.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 404, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T13:08:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lshitfunq9u13p", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-11T13:08:03Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lshr3y689sm5j8", "to": "lshitfuf1kv13o", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-11T17:00:10Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Ax = e => rank(A) = m proof", "created": "2024-02-11T13:08:03Z", "content": "

I'm not sure that I understand the proof after they say using the scalar and lineary of vector, matrix multiplication. Also what is the point of introducing xi and b? and adding to that why is showing that Ax = b is consistent relative to the solution when xi is said to be the solution?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 62, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T17:00:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1697485981}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T17:00:10Z", "content": "

They are making use of part b) of the System-Rank Theorem which says that if $$A \vec{x} = \vec{b}$$ is always consistent no matter what $$\vec{b}$$ we choose, then the rank of $$A$$ is $$m$$. 

So they show that the hypothesis of this statement leads to $$A \vec{x} = \vec{b}$$ always being consistent no matter what $$\vec{b}$$ is chosen. 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt"], "children": [], "id": "lshr3y61np35j6", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lshitfuf1kv13o", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456790325, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week4"], "nr": 407, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T15:22:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lshnlwqnupv3qq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-11T15:22:09Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lshr8uyapf75ek", "to": "lshnlwqgoun3qo", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-11T17:03:59Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lshnlwqgoun3qo", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-06T23:23:29Z", "cid": "luoq0qzwanc7od", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "to": "lshnlwqgoun3qo", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-07T00:59:15Z", "cid": "luotfx2lqon53y"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "to": "lshnlwqgoun3qo", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-07T16:00:32Z", "cid": "luppmysrgkw523"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Proof of Recommended Problems Q2a) & Q2b)", "created": "2024-02-11T15:22:09Z", "content": "

For the proof in question  2b), by proving it true and let $$\vec{x} = \vec{e_i}$$ and $$\vec{y} = \vec{e_j}$$. Isn't there a loss of generality because it is no longer for all $$\vec{x}, \vec{y} $$?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week4", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1697485981}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 102, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T17:03:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T17:03:59Z", "content": "Notice that we have a "for all" in the hypothesis.  (Remember MATH 135!)  If the hypothesis is true for all vectors  $$\vec{x}$$ and $$\vec{y}$$, then it will still be true when $$\vec{x}$$ and $$\vec{y}$$ are standard basis vectors. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lshr8uy4rh65ej", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "For 2.b) If $$\vec{x}=\vec{y}=\vec{0},$$ then wouldn't it hold for all matrices A so $$A\neq A^T$$ ?", "created": "2024-04-06T23:23:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "When $$\vec{x}= \vec y = \vec 0$$, the hypothesis gives us no useful information about the relationship between $$A$$ and $$A^T$$ because the equation just becomes $$0=0$$. ", "created": "2024-04-07T00:59:15Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luotfx2lqon53y", "updated": "2024-04-07T00:59:16Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I find matrices a little hard to conceptualize sometimes, so here's an analogous example that might help this make more sense:

Say I have $$\alpha \cdot x = 0$$ for all $$x\in \mathbb{R}$$ (assume $$\alpha \in \mathbb{R}$$ too). So what number can $$\alpha$$ be?

I know this statement holds for all $$x$$, so if I choose $$x=0$$ I find that $$\alpha$$ can be any real number. But if I choose any other $$x$$ I get that $$\alpha$$ must be $$0$$. So the $$x=0$$ case doesn't narrow down the possibilities, but I find other values of $$x$$ that do.

It's a similar concept here where we can use any vectors and the statement will be true, so I choose particular vectors that will help me get the result I need: exclude all other possibilities until only one is left! 

", "created": "2024-04-07T16:00:32Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4"], "id": "luppmysrgkw523", "updated": "2024-04-07T17:27:06Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luoq0qzwanc7od", "updated": "2024-04-10T12:33:05Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lshnlwqgoun3qo", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714456793591, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hello,

I was just wondering why when solving this problem and taking $$(A^2)^T$$, why do we say that this is equal to $$(A^T)^TA^T$$ as opposed to $$A^T(A^T)^T$$, as I know that the order is important? When transposing a product, do we first reverse the order within the brackets, then transpose each term?

Any clarification that you can provide would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 412, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T17:33:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lshsah89d9v67t", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-11T17:33:14Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "lshupyrc2n86iu", "to": "lshsah82uc767q", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-11T18:41:16Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lshsah82uc767q", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-11T19:09:36Z", "cid": "lshvqeo9xgu72w", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "to": "lshsah82uc767q", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-02-11T19:11:02Z", "cid": "lshvs97i3chyd"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Question about column and row space", "created": "2024-02-11T17:33:14Z", "content": "

If A ~~~ B by ERO's, then it is true that:


Row(A) = Row(B)
Col(A^T) = Row(B)

Col(B^T) = Row(A)

But is it always true that

Col(A) ≠ Col(B) ?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 80, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T18:41:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T18:41:16Z", "content": "

>>But is it always true that Col(A) ≠ Col(B) ?

This is not necessarily true.

If A=B, then clearly A, B are row equivalent and Col(A)=Col(B).

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwclm3shhvy"], "children": [], "id": "lshupyr6wsh6it", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "so are Col(A^T) and Col(B^T) equal?", "created": "2024-02-11T19:09:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Again, necessarily equal. It is not true in general, so we don't have such a property.

----------

Edit: It depends on what condition you have.

  • If $$A^T$$ and $$B^T$$ are row equivalent, then we may not have Col(A^T)=Col(B^T)
  • If $$A$$ and $$B$$ are row equivalent, then $$A^T$$ and $$B^T$$ are column equivalent. This implies Col(A^T)=Col(B^T)!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["midterm"], "nr": 414, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T18:33:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lshug2jjkvs3sr", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-11T18:33:34Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "lshvcu0xqmo6l4", "to": "lshug2j4o413so", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-11T18:59:03Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Complex pivot", "created": "2024-02-11T18:33:34Z", "content": "How to convert a complex pivot into 1 and the other non-pivot positions into 0? Also will the questions on the midterm involve any complex values?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 98, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T18:59:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T18:59:03Z", "content": "

If you have a complex pivot $$a+bi$$ (hence nonzero), to normalize it you may multiply the row by $$\frac{1}{a+bi}=\frac{a-bi}{a^2+b^2}$$. 

>>Also will the questions on the midterm involve any complex values?

Probably. The numbers on the test will be simple enough for you to complete within 110mins.

Hello,

I noticed that in a lot of proofs we are given that the matrix we are working with is nxn, or square. I often feel like this is included for a reason (as opposed to a regular mxn) but I never know how to make use of this in proofs.

I was wondering if there are any noteworthy properties or theorems that you can apply specifically to square matrices to help in proofs.

Thank you!

Hello,

I noticed that in a lot of proofs we are given that the matrix we are working with is nxn, or square. I often feel like this is included for a reason (as opposed to a regular mxn) but I never know how to make use of this in proofs.

I was wondering if there are any noteworthy properties or theorems that you can apply specifically to square matrices to help in proofs.

Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Calista Besseling", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8bbhomj47g", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 82, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T19:03:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Zhenchao Ge", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": "1700800406_200.jpg", "id": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/llux8psc8tj5zh/1700800406_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750, "llazq0fual03ej": 1702407827, "global": 1707613189}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1697485981}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Calista Besseling", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8bbhomj47g", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T22:52:01Z", "content": "You can multiply square matrices in any order and that will be valid, whereas if you have not square matrices, you need to pay attention to the order of multiplication.

This is relevant in repeated multiplication (hence why $$A^2$$ is only defined for square matrices).

Also, transpose of square matrices is also square, which may be handy when you may need to write $$(AB)^\top = B^\top A^\top$$.
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T19:03:17Z", "content": "You can multiply square matrices in any order and that will be valid, whereas if you have no square matrices, you need to pay attention to the order of multiplication.

This is relevant in repeated multiplication (hence why $$A^2$$ is only defined for square matrices).

Also, transpose of square matrices is also square, which may be handy when you may need to write $$(AB)^\top = B^\top A^\top$$.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["midterm", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 93, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-11T20:23:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-11T20:23:37Z", "content": "

I don't think we are allowed to make the assumption that if $$A\vec{v}=0$$, then either $$A$$ or $$\vec{v} = 0$$. There's a section in the course notes:


Property 2 (I think you used this one), does not apply to matrix arithmetic, and since a vector is just a nx1 matrix, this won't apply to matrix-vector multiplication either. So I don't think the argument works.

In W4 Q4, we are asked for null, column, and row space. In the solutions, they basically just rip out the columns/rows and turn them into spans as the answer:

However my prof had told us in class that this is a bad answer (especially for column space), and when we did something similar in class we took the transpose of the matrix and computed the row space to get the column space of the original.


On a test which method should we use for situations where we need column/row space? I wouldn't want to take time reducing the transposed matrix into RREF if I didn't have to.

Thanks!
