{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa2"], "nr": 612, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-27T21:24:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelx8tr9o0", "data": "lt4vlekoivf1hm", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-27T21:24:25Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lt4vmnw15zs536", "to": "lt4vlekfuh41hl", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-27T21:25:23Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelx8tr9o0", "subject": "What does Ker(T) mean?", "created": "2024-02-27T21:24:25Z", "content": "What does Ker(T) mean? It's in question 5."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa2"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 111, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-27T21:25:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-27T21:25:23Z", "content": "

$$\\text{Ker}(T)$$ denotes the kernel of $$T : \\mathbb R^n \\to \\mathbb R^m$$:

\n

\n

$$\\text{Ker}(T) := \\{\\vec x \\in \\mathbb R^n : T(\\vec x) = \\vec 0\\}$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lt4vmnvsw6q535", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lt4vlekfuh41hl", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457011140, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa2"], "nr": 613, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-27T21:40:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelx8tr9o0", "data": "lt4w63mdlex4y6", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-27T21:40:30Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lt4w8u1sc6t5lr", "to": "lt4w63m3bd74y4", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-27T21:42:38Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelx8tr9o0", "subject": "What does one-to-one and onto mean?", "created": "2024-02-27T21:40:30Z", "content": "What does one-to-one and onto mean? It's in Q5 c)."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa2"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 93, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-27T21:42:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-27T21:42:38Z", "content": "

A function $$f : \\mathbb R^n \\to \\mathbb R^m$$ is one-to-one (also know as injective) if $$f(a) = f(b) \\implies a = b$$.

\n

\n

A function $$f : \\mathbb R^n \\to \\mathbb R^m$$ is onto (also known as surjective) if for all $$\\vec y \\in \\mathbb R^m$$, there exists $$\\vec x \\in \\mathbb R^n$$ so that $$f(\\vec x ) = \\vec y$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lt4w8u1lt6f5lp", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lt4w63m3bd74y4", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457012200, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 617, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-27T22:22:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lt4xnjsol5m2w7", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-27T22:22:04Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lt4y41uzz9tba", "to": "lt4xnjsgjir2w5", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-02-27T22:34:54Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lt4y4m407mo1r6", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-02-27T22:35:20Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Are all non-nilpotent matrix invertible?", "created": "2024-02-27T22:22:04Z", "content": "If so, then saying a matrix isn't nilpotent is the same as saying $$A\vec{x}=\vec{b}$$ is consistent/has a solution $$A^{-1} \vec{b}$$ for all $$\vec{b} \in \mathbb{F}^{n}$$?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 93, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-27T22:34:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-27T22:35:20Z", "content": "

That is a very interesting question!

The answer is no. 

This is the converse of one of the questions on the homework. If it was true, then we would have another characterization of invertibility (not nilpotent), but unfortunately this is not true.

Consider the $$x$$-line at $$y = 0$$ in $$\mathbb R^2$$:

$$\mathcal L := \{(x, 0) \in \mathbb R^2 : x \in \mathbb R\}$$

Consider the projection $$\text{proj}_{\mathcal L}$$ of $$(x, y)$$ onto $$\mathcal L$$:

$$\text{proj}_{\mathcal L}((x, y)) = (x, 0) = \text{proj}_{\vec e_1}((x, y))$$

When we repeatedly apply this projection function, we should expect that future applications don't change it (when you project a vector into itself, it doesn't change). This is to say:

$$\text{proj}_{\mathcal L}(\text{proj}_{\mathcal L}((x, y))) = \text{proj}_{\mathcal L}((x, y))$$

We know that the projection is a linear function, so we can find a matrix $$T$$ for this transformation. Then,

$$T^2\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = T\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}$$ for all $$\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb R^2$$

Then, we can conclude that $$T^2 = T$$.

From here, I will leave the rest for you to figure out:

- How does this show that $$T$$ is not nilpotent?

- How do we know that $$T$$ is not invertible?

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-27T22:34:54Z", "content": "

That is a very interesting question!

The answer is no. 

This is the converse of one of the questions on the homework. If it was true, then we would have another characterization of invertibility (not nilpotent), but unfortunately this is not true.

Consider the $$x$$-line at $$y = 0$$ in $$\mathbb R^2$$:

$$\mathcal L := \{(x, 0) \in \mathbb R^2 : x \in \mathbb R\}$$

Consider the projection $$\text{proj}_{\mathcal L}$$ of $$(x, y, z)$$ onto $$\mathcal L$$:

$$\text{proj}_{\mathcal L}((x, y)) = (x, 0) = \text{proj}_{\vec e_1}((x, y))$$

When we repeatedly apply this projection function, we should expect that future applications don't change it (when you project a vector into itself, it doesn't change). This is to say:

$$\text{proj}_{\mathcal L}(\text{proj}_{\mathcal L}((x, y))) = \text{proj}_{\mathcal L}((x, y))$$

We know that the projection is a linear function, so we can find a matrix $$T$$ for this transformation. Then,

$$T^2\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} = T\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix}$$ for all $$\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb R^2$$

Then, we can conclude that $$T^2 = T$$.

From here, I will leave the rest for you to figure out:

- How does this show that $$T$$ is not nilpotent?

- How do we know that $$T$$ is not invertible?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa2"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 100, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-28T05:33:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-28T05:33:24Z", "content": "

I'm not sure what you're describing.

In your screenshot, the $$\vec a_i$$ are all column vectors.

In general, for $$A \in M_{m \times n}(\mathbb F)$$, and $$B \in M_{n \times k}(\mathbb F)$$, $$AB \in M_{m \times k}(\mathbb F)$$.

We can check the dimensions of $$\vec v$$ ($$n \times 1$$ matrix) and $$A$$ ($$m \times n$$ matrix) to see that $$\vec vA$$ is not well defined.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-02-28T05:33:14Z", "content": "

Im not sure this is correct and is very messy but here is a rough idea I have:

since we can represent row operations by elementary matrices, we can multiply $$A$$ by some matrix $$B$$ to get to $$BA=\text{RREF}(A)=R$$ so we have that $$BA\vec{x}=BA\vec{y}$$ or $$R\vec{x}=R\vec{y} \implies \vec{x}=\vec{y}$$ for all $$\vec{x},\vec{y}\in\mathbb{F}^n$$. Assume for a contradiction that $$A$$ is not invertible, this means that $$\text{rank}(A)=\text{rank}(R)

Now suppose that one $$r_x\neq0$$ for some $$1\leq x\leq n$$. Then, there must exist a pivot column $$\vec{r_{x'}}=\vec{e}_x$$ in $$R$$ to the left of $$x_n$$ in the matrix (as otherwise this term would be a pivot). Here is a picture of an example of what I mean:

    each non-zero thing in the non-pivot column has another column with just that thing

Now, we arrive at a contradiction as $$R\vec{0}=R\vec{y}$$  where  $$\vec{y}=\vec{e}_x - r_x\vec{r_{x'}}$$. 

If there are more entries in $$\vec{r}_k$$ that are non-zero, we can do this same process to also arrive at a contradiction

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 642, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-02-29T13:39:36Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lt79vcnu1ld5kt", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-02-29T13:39:36Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "to": "lt79vcnmyv15kq", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-29T13:50:04Z", "cid": "lt7a8tpnuqf55h"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lt79vcnmyv15kq", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-02-29T13:53:28Z", "cid": "lt7ad6g5o9036q", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Making Use of Office Hours", "created": "2024-02-29T13:39:36Z", "content": "

I did some polling of a few of my fellow instructors about their office hours.\u00a0 From my polling it seemed that office hours weren\u2019t all that busy.\u00a0 There could be a few reasons for that:

\n
  1. You understand all the material and are not having any difficulties.\u00a0 If that's the case, then this is great!
  2. You are too shy to ask questions.\u00a0 If that describes you, then I would strongly encourage you to confront your fear and ask your questions.\u00a0 Most instructors love talking about math with their students.\u00a0 Our job is to provide you with support as you learn the material.\u00a0 Of course, we can't learn the material for you, but we'll gladly answer questions that you have.\u00a0
  3. You don't have time to come to office hours.\u00a0 If that's the case, then I would encourage you to organize your time differently.\u00a0 When I was a student, I organized my time around my instructors' office hours.\u00a0 I made sure to start assignments or exam preparation early enough so that I could ask questions.\u00a0 I did my best to review the material early on so that I could clear up the problems than I had.\u00a0
  4. The office hours don't work with your schedule.\u00a0 If you have time conflicts with your instructor's office hours, then they may be open to appointments at a different time. It\u2019s worth at least asking to see if this is a possibility.\u00a0 \u00a0\u00a0

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 79, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-01T17:49:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Junyan Ye", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwb17ooi55le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-01T18:57:43Z", "content": "

If $$T$$ is onto/surjective, then yes, $$\text{Range}(T) = \mathbb R^2$$.

However, this is not always the case. What if there is some vector $$\vec b \in \mathbb R^2$$ so that for all $$\vec x \in \mathbb R^3$$, $$T(\vec x) \neq \vec b$$? (this would show that $$\vec b$$ is not in the range of $$T$$, even though it is in the codomain).

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-01T17:49:13Z", "content": "

If $$T$$ is onto/surjective, then yes, $$\text{Ran}(T) = \mathbb R^2$$.

However, this is not always the case. What if there is some vector $$\vec b \in \mathbb R^2$$ so that for all $$\vec x \in \mathbb R^3$$, $$T(\vec x) \neq \vec b$$? (this would show that $$\vec b$$ is not in the range of $$T$$, even though it is in the codomain).

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwb17ooi55le"], "children": [], "id": "lt8y87gkf81701", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

"history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-02T09:25:56Z", "content": "

Assuming your question is how to actually show the criteria in order to show that something is onto/one-to-one

From one-to-one criteria:

for (b), you basically just want to find the nullspace of $$A$$.  This will let you see if the only element in the nullspace is the zero vector. In the case that you are given a linear transformation and not the corresponding matrix for it, you would need to first find the matrix. (c is essentially the same as d)

For onto criteria:

Showing that $$\text{Col}(A)=\mathbb{F}^m$$ means to show that the columns of $$A$$ span all of $$\mathbb{F}^m$$. One way to do this would be to show that each of the basis vectors $$\vec{e}_1, \dots, \vec{e}_m$$ can be expressed as a linear combination of the columns of $$A$$.

If you are asking why the criteria other than rank work, there are proofs in the course notes that should give an idea to why they make sense. summary:

for one-to-one, the only solution to $$T_A(\vec{b})=\vec{0}$$ is $$\vec{b}=\vec{0}$$ is important in showing that if $$T_A(\vec{a})=T_A(\vec{b})$$, then $$\vec{a}=\vec{b}$$. This is because we can rearrange this into $$T_A(\vec{a})-T_A(\vec{b})=T_A(\vec{a}-\vec{b})=\vec{0} \implies \vec{a}-\vec{b} = \vec{0}$$ as the only vector such that $$T_A(\vec{b})=\vec{0}$$ is the zero vector by assumption. So $$\vec{a}=\vec{b}$$. If there were another solution to $$T_A(\vec{b})=\vec{0}$$, we could not conclude that $$\vec{a}-\vec{b}=\vec{0}$$

for onto, $$T_A(\vec{b}) = A\vec{b}$$, so the column space of $$A$$ represents the range of $$T_A$$, onto means the range of $$T_A$$ is all of $$\mathbb{F}^m$$, so it is the same as showing the column space is all of $$\mathbb{F}^m$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-02T09:25:39Z", "content": "

Showing that $$\text{Col}(A)=\mathbb{F}^m$$ means to show that the columns of $$A$$ span all of $$\mathbb{F}^m$$. One way to do this would be to show that each of the basis vectors $$\vec{e}_1, \dots, \vec{e}_m$$ can be expressed as a linear combination of the columns of $$A$$.

If you are asking why the criteria other than rank work, there are proofs in the course notes that should give an idea to why they make sense. summary:

for one-to-one, the only solution to $$T_A(\vec{b})=\vec{0}$$ is $$\vec{b}=\vec{0}$$ is important in showing that if $$T_A(\vec{a})=T_A(\vec{b})$$, then $$\vec{a}=\vec{b}$$. This is because we can rearrange this into $$T_A(\vec{a})-T_A(\vec{b})=T_A(\vec{a}-\vec{b})=\vec{0} \implies \vec{a}-\vec{b} = \vec{0}$$ as the only vector such that $$T_A(\vec{B})=\vec{0}$$ is the zero vector by assumption. So $$\vec{a}=\vec{b}$$. If there were another solution to $$T_A(\vec{b})=\vec{0}$$, we could not conclude that $$\vec{a}-\vec{b}=\vec{0}$$

for onto, $$T_A(\vec{b}) = A\vec{b}$$, so the column space of $$A$$ represents the range of $$T_A$$, onto means the range of $$T_A$$ is all of $$\mathbb{F}^m$$, so it is the same as showing the column space is all of $$\mathbb{F}^m$$

Hello,

I was wondering if someone could provide a hint for how to solve 8b) on WP5?

Would it be correct to start with using a variation of the hint in part a), wherein $$A\epsilon M_{3 x 3}(\mathbb{R})$$ such that $$A^3 = - I^{_{3}}$$ (that's a subscript - the equation editor is just not working with the I)?

Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-03T00:10:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-03T00:10:13Z", "content": "For starters, we would be interested in $$A \in M_{3 \times 3}(\mathbb R)$$ so that $$A^2=-I$$.

For further hints, my solution for this question requires a lot of content we haven’t covered yet, so it may be a good idea to leave this aside and come back when we have covered a bit more material (eigenvalues).
"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltara1gb1fl36x", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Nevermind I found another solution 😀

Hint: if $$A^2 = -I_3$$, then

$$\text{det}(A^2) = \text{det}(-I_3)$$

", "created": "2024-03-03T00:17:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

does that not imply that  

det(A)det(A) = -1

(det(A))^2 = -1

Kernel and Span", "created": "2024-03-03T02:00:16Z", "content": "

How is range and span connected? How does the number of vectors inside the span element related to the field of the range?

For example, if we let Range(T)=F^2 and why does Span have 2 vectors. I mean Span{[a,b]^T [c,d]^T} is an example of span with 2 vectors. 

The other question why if the Kernel is a span, then one-to-one test fails?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 77, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-03T03:20:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-03T03:20:02Z", "content": "

If we are considering a linear transformation  $$T$$, then range of $$T$$ is equal to the column space of its standard matrix.  The column space of a matrix is the span of its columns.  So at this point, that's the connection that we have between the range of a linear transformation and the span of a set of vectors.  Later in chapter 8 we will see more connections between these concepts. 

At this point we haven't developed any ideas about the number of vectors in a spanning set and the span of those vectors.  This connection will also be explored in chapter 8. 

I think you are mixing up the idea of a spanning set and the span of the vectors in the spanning set.  The span is the set of all linear combination of the vectors in the spanning set.  

The kernel of a linear transformation is all vectors that are mapped to the zero vector of the codomain.  We know for certain that the zero vector of domain is in the kernel because for a linear transformation the zero vector of the domain is always mapped to the zero vector of the codomain.  However, if there are more vectors in the domain which map to the zero vector of the codomain, then the transformation will not be one-to-one because there will be distinct vectors which map to the same vector.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week5"], "nr": 671, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-03T02:39:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltawm5sc1z34lc", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-03T02:39:37Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltaxvoth1p91eb", "to": "ltawm5s2fah4lb", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-03T03:15:01Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "wp5 q5(b)", "created": "2024-03-03T02:39:37Z", "content": "I'm confused about this question, can anyone explain it to me? Thanks!!!"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 82, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-03T03:15:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Li Xuanhe", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwej5x9pg6c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-03T03:15:01Z", "content": "

Recall a certain factoring identity:

$$1 - x^k = (1 - x)(1 + x + x^2 + \cdots + x^{k - 1})$$

Hence since $$A^k = \mathcal O$$,

$$1 = (1 - x)(1 + x + x^2 + \cdots + x^{k - 1})$$

Of course, for real numbers $$x$$, it makes sense to say

$$\dfrac 1 {1 - x} = 1 + x + x^2 + \cdots + x^{k - 1}$$

But it is nonsensical to write

$$\dfrac 1 {1 - A} = 1 + A + A^2 + \cdots + A^{k - 1}$$

because we don't have division of matrices.

However, the factoring identity still gives

$$1 = (1 - A)(1 + A + A^2 + \cdots + A^{k - 1})$$

Which is what we wanted.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwej5x9pg6c"], "children": [], "id": "ltaxvot6p5l1e8", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltawm5s2fah4lb", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457073600, "default_anonymity": "no"}

", "created": "2024-03-03T16:02:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltbpajzedwx5mi", "updated": "2024-03-03T16:03:01Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I don't know how to calculate det(A) nor det(B)", "created": "2024-03-03T16:44:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltbqsgs5l8u6n0", "updated": "2024-03-03T16:44:19Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I presume it would be the same idea as a square matrix", "created": "2024-03-03T16:50:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltbr0ekceqhij", "updated": "2024-03-03T16:50:30Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Probably not because there would be no such thing as having a base case (2x2 matrix) if we do not have a square matrix", "created": "2024-03-03T16:52:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltbr3citrwg52x", "updated": "2024-03-03T16:52:47Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

The idea is that no matter how you define the determinant of a nonsquare matrix, you reach a contradiction.

If you want the determinant to uphold the same properties, then we must have

$$\text{det}(AB) = \text{det}(A)\text{det}(B) = \text{det}(B)\text{det}(A) = \text{det}(BA)$$

However,

$$AB = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$ and $$BA = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\  0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

Hence

$$1 = \text{det}(AB) = \text{det}(BA) = 0$$, which is a contradiction, so the intermediate values $$\text{det}(A), \text{det}(B)$$ cannot exist.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week6", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 71, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-03T17:03:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Li Xuanhe", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwej5x9pg6c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-03T17:03:19Z", "content": "

Do you mean $$\text{Range}(T_2 \circ T_1)$$? $$T_1 \circ T_2$$ is not necessarily defined.

In this case, if $$\text{Range}(T_2) \neq \mathbb F^p$$, we cannot have that $$\text{Range}(T_2 \circ T_1) = \mathbb F^p$$. This is because

$$\text{Range}(T_2 \circ T_1) = \{ \vec b \in \mathbb F^p : \exists \vec y, (T_2 \circ T_1)(\vec y) = \vec b\}$$

So if $$\vec b \in \text{Range}(T_2 \circ T_1)$$, then

$$(T_2 \circ T_1)(\vec y) = \vec b \iff T_2(T_1(\vec y)) = \vec b$$, hence there exists $$\vec z \in \mathbb F^m$$ (namely, $$\vec z = T_1(\vec y)$$) so that

$$T_2(\vec z) = \vec b$$

This shows that $$\vec b \in \text{Range}(T_2)$$, so

$$\text{Range}(T_2 \circ T_1) \subseteq \text{Range}(T_2)$$.

The intuition behind this is that the range of $$T_2 \circ T_1$$ is the range of $$T_2$$, but restricting the input of $$T_2$$ to the output of $$T_1$$:

If on the a test we need to prove that a transformation is linear, can we also find its standard matrix and say since it is determined by matrix, so it is linear?

Thank you

", "created": "2024-03-03T23:01:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Yes, if you can find a matrix which represents the transformation, then this proves that the transformation is linear. 

If you know it's linear then you can find its standard matrix by applying the linear transformation to the standard basis vectors and then using those vectors as the columns of the standard matrix. 

However, you can't do this process if you don't know the transformation is linear.  So be careful that your argument doesn't become a circular argument.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 71, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-03T18:21:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Daniel Kostenko", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwatgzzdt48x", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-03T18:21:25Z", "content": "

$$\vec y = T(S(\vec y))$$ because $$T$$ is invertible and $$S$$ is its inverse.

This shows that $$\vec y \in \text{Range}(T)$$ because there exists $$\vec z \in \mathbb F^n$$ (namely $$\vec z = S(\vec y)$$ so that

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week6", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 92, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-03T19:43:49Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Landon Trinh", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcmng7k212i", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-03T19:43:49Z", "content": "

A function $$T$$ is injective or one-to-one if $$T(\vec x) = T(\vec y) \implies \vec x = \vec y$$.

This is to say that if $$T$$ is injective, then whenever $$T(\vec x) = T(\vec y)$$, then you must have $$\vec x = \vec y$$.

Another way to think of injectiveness is by thinking of it as a uniqueness of output: that any output $$T(\vec x)$$ is unique in that no other value $$\vec y$$ gets mapped to $$T(\vec x)$$: i.e.

If $$\vec y\neq \vec x$$, then $$T(\vec y) \neq T(\vec x)$$ (this is actually the contrapositive).

To show that a function is injective, you should start by saying "suppose $$T(\vec x) = T(\vec y)$$ for some $$\vec x, \vec y \in \mathbb F^n$$". Then, you should conclude by showing that $$\vec x = \vec y$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwcmng7k212i"], "children": [], "id": "ltbx7awxh9s5ps", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I see, then how would you provde if a function is surjective in this case then with:", "created": "2024-03-03T19:53:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Would this type of question disregard the criteria and just looks for an appropriate input for the output?", "created": "2024-03-03T19:55:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltbxltxp84i5jk", "updated": "2024-03-03T19:55:07Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I'm not sure what you mean by "disregard the criteria".

To show that a function is surjective, you should start by saying "Let $$\vec y \in \mathbb F^m$$" and conclude by showing that there is a vector $$\vec x \in \mathbb F^n$$ so that

$$T(\vec x) = \vec y$$

", "created": "2024-03-03T19:55:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltbxmoir6lf5fz", "updated": "2024-03-03T19:55:47Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Oh I see, I meant that this type of question doesn't really have to do anything with the criteria and focuses on the definition (that every output in the codomain is possible)?", "created": "2024-03-03T19:57:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltbxoosal7s3fy", "updated": "2024-03-03T19:57:20Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Do you mean criteria as in invertibility criteria (either 4.6.7 or 5.4.7)?

However, matrices and linear transformations are very closely related, so you could use that if you wanted to, but it's also a good practice to go through the definitions of injective and surjective and make sure you understand them.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q3"], "nr": 688, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-03T21:04:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltc036ula5s57", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-03T21:04:36Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltc06yofw3c4in", "to": "ltc036ue19l56", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-03T21:07:32Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "What’s the difference between Ta and T?", "created": "2024-03-03T21:04:36Z", "content": "In WP5 Q8A it tells us to find a T, transformation, that satisfies a condition. But the hint talks about an A value, so would that mean T and Ta are the same?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 85, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-03T21:07:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Brooke Joseph", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1697485981}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8rpo1vu6yt", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-03T21:07:32Z", "content": "

$$T_A$$ and $$T$$ are both linear transformations.

$$T_A$$ is the linear transformation that is explicitly defined from the matrix $$A$$, by defining

$$T_A(\vec x) = A \vec x$$

whereas $$T$$ is just some linear transformation (aka linear function) that is not defined using a matrix.

It turns out that every linear transformation can be defined with a matrix, and every matrix defines a linear transformation (5.5), so writing $$T_A$$ or $$T$$ is just for notation.

For WP5 Q8, if you find such a matrix that satisfies the hint, what happens when you take $$T_A$$ for that $$A$$?

Yes.

If $$T$$ is injective/one-to-one, then $$T \vec x = T \vec y \implies \vec x = \vec y$$.

Then, if $$T \vec x = \vec 0$$, then since $$T \vec 0 = \vec 0$$,

$$T \vec x = T \vec 0$$, so we must have $$\vec x = \vec 0$$.

This shows that any vector which is a solution to the homogenous system $$T \vec x = \vec 0$$ must be exactly the zero vector.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8rpo1vu6yt"], "children": [], "id": "ltc0agryo1b5g2", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "thank you! So being one-to-one implies consistency but I'm assuming the converse isn't true?", "created": "2024-03-03T21:11:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

If you mean consistency for the homogenous system, then linear systems are always consistent for the homogenous system because $$T \vec 0 = \vec 0$$.

You are right that the converse is not true because every linear transformation is consistent for the homogenous system (again because $$T \vec 0 = \vec 0$$ but clearly not every linear transformation is injective/one-to-one).

Onto or surjectivity describes transformations, not matrices.

\n

\n

To show a transformation is surjective, you should show that $$\\text{Range}(T) = \\mathbb F^m$$.

"llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-03T23:08:26Z", "content": "

We alway say a standard matrix of a linear transformation T. 

Using only the definition, to show $$T:\mathbb{F}^m\to \mathbb{F}^n$$ is onto, you need to check every element in $$\mathbb{F}^n$$ and show that it has preimage under $$T$$. (This is difficult.)

Using the standard matrix of $$T:\mathbb{F}^m \to \mathbb{F}^n$$, you can do algebra (like EROs) on $$[T]_{\mathcal{E}}$$ (an $$n\times m$$ matrix) and figure out its rank. If $$\mathrm{rank}([T]_{\mathcal{E}})=n$$ (full row rank) then it is onto. (Onto Criteria)

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-03T23:07:30Z", "content": "

For a general linear transformation $$T$$, if $$T$$ is NOT one-to-one, then $$T$$ can NOT be invertible. (Definition)

If $$T$$ is one-to-one, $$T$$ may NOT be invertible. (Definition)

If $$T_A$$, determined by a SQUARE matrix $$A$$, is one-to-one, then $$T_A$$ is invertible. (Invertibility Criteria)

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-03T22:45:30Z", "content": "

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q3"], "nr": 695, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-04T02:33:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelx8tr9o0", "data": "ltcbus4yrq3fi", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-04T02:33:59Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwe9bk4si65f", "data": "ltcc60n4wf9278", "to": "ltcbus4opm3fg", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-04T02:42:44Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltcepkqx4h36pg", "to": "ltcbus4opm3fg", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-04T03:53:55Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelx8tr9o0", "subject": "Question about differences in notation", "created": "2024-03-04T02:33:59Z", "content": "What's the difference between the verticle vector [1 2] and [1, 2]^T?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q3", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 88, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-04T02:42:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwe9bk4si65f", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-04T02:42:44Z", "content": "

verticle vector[1, 2] represents a column vector, it is the standard way to write a vector in linear algebra, and [1,2]^T is another way to represent it use transpose, with a horizontal array of numbers, but it is also a column vector. You can use transpose to get one from another one, they are refer to the same thing, same vector, just different way to represent the vector.

\n

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4"], "children": [], "id": "ltcc60mvo2k277", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-04T03:53:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-04T03:53:55Z", "content": "We use the notation $$[1,2]^T$$ for the sake of space so that we can write the vector horizontally and not take up a lot of space"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltcepkqtq9z6pe", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltcbus4opm3fg", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457099105, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week6"], "nr": 696, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-04T02:56:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltcco6t1zls131", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-04T02:56:51Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltceuvogemk1wv", "to": "ltcco6stpp8130", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-04T03:58:03Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltcco6stpp8130", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-04T12:24:08Z", "cid": "ltcwxpnkdfw3uz", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "to": "ltcco6stpp8130", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-04T13:11:28Z", "cid": "ltcymksk2066vg"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "[WP6 Q6 a]", "created": "2024-03-04T02:56:51Z", "content": "Hi, wanna ask why we can directly let S(y) = x. (why is this well-defined). Thanks
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week6", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 100, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-04T03:58:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zhirui Lyu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": "1700080244_200.jpg", "id": "lkqwehdad3p7l6", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lkqwehdad3p7l6/1700080244_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-04T03:58:03Z", "content": "We have a one-to-one and onto transformation $$T$$.\u00a0 That means for every $$\\vec{y}$$ in the codomain there is exactly one $$\\vec{x}$$ in the domain such that $$T(\\vec{x})=\\vec{y}$$.\u00a0 Therefore, to define $$S$$ we say $$S(\\vec{y})$$ is equal to the vector which $$T$$ maps to $$\\vec{y}$$.\u00a0 Since $$T$$ is onto there is always such an $$\\vec{x}$$ and there is only one.\u00a0 So $$S$$ is well-defined for its domain (which is the co-domain of $$T$$).\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehdad3p7l6"], "children": [], "id": "ltceuvoa9pu1wu", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Oh, I understand better now. Just want to make sure that S(y) = x is just how we define it and we don't need to show that S is also onto and one-to-one right?", "created": "2024-03-04T12:24:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Yes, $$S(\\vec y)=\\vec x$$ is how we are defining $$S$$ as a transformation.\u00a0 If we wanted we could go on to try to prove that $$S$$ is also one-to-one and onto.\u00a0", "created": "2024-03-04T13:11:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zhirui Lyu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": "1700080244_200.jpg", "id": "lkqwehdad3p7l6", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lkqwehdad3p7l6/1700080244_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwehdad3p7l6"], "id": "ltcymksk2066vg", "updated": "2024-03-04T14:38:59Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltcwxpnkdfw3uz", "updated": "2024-03-04T14:38:54Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltcco6stpp8130", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457100167, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week6"], "nr": 704, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-04T16:55:04Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltd6m4wl3buz4", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-04T16:55:04Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltda5b5fccd20p", "to": "ltd6m4wca53z1", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-04T18:33:57Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Wp6 Q5", "created": "2024-03-04T16:55:04Z", "content": "

This is the solution for Q5 and why do we know we should use [0v2-0v3, 1v3-0v1, 0v1-1v2]^T ? According to the cross rule, shouldn't it be [0v2-0v3, -(1v3-0v1), 1v2-0v1]^T?  

In addition, can someone also explains how do they prove that T is a linear transformation? I cannot really get this part too. Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week6", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-04T18:33:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Heyun Cai", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwarf9r4h3w4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-04T18:33:57Z", "content": "

By Proposition 1.9.5, we know that the cross product is linear in the second argument. This means that

1. $$\vec x \times (\vec y + \vec z) = \vec x \times \vec y + \vec x \times \vec z$$ for all $$\vec x, \vec y, \vec z \in \mathbb R^3$$; and,

2. $$\vec x \times (c \vec y) = c(\vec x \times \vec y)$$ for all $$\vec x, \vec y \in \mathbb R^3$$, $$c \in \mathbb R$$

This also means that the function $$T : \mathbb R^3 \to \mathbb R^3$$ defined by

$$T(\vec x) = \vec v \times \vec x$$ is linear for all fixed vectors $$\vec v$$.

The cross product

$$\vec v \times \vec x := \begin{bmatrix}  v_2x_3 - v_3x_2 \\ -(v_1x_3 - v_3x_1) \\ v_1x_2 - v_2x_1 \end{bmatrix}$$

so taking $$\vec x = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0\end{bmatrix}$$, find

$$\vec v \times \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ v_3 \\ - v_2 \end{bmatrix}$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwarf9r4h3w4"], "children": [], "id": "ltda5b59lmy20o", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltd6m4wca53z1", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457108635, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa3"], "nr": 714, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-05T01:18:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltdol0khy6421l", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-05T01:18:05Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltdrgm8du381n1", "to": "ltdol0k85b921h", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-05T02:38:38Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Q3", "created": "2024-03-05T01:18:05Z", "content": "What does  entries of each row of A add to zero means"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa3"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 218, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-05T02:38:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-05T02:38:38Z", "content": "

It means if

$$A = \begin{bmatrix} A_{11} & A_{12} & \cdots & A_{1n} \\ A_{21} & \ddots & \ddots & A_{2n} \\ \vdots & \ddots & \ddots & \vdots \\ A_{m1} & A_{m2} & \cdots & A_{mn} \end{bmatrix} $$

Then

$$\sum_{i = 1}^n A_{ij} = 0$$, for all $$1 \le j \le m$$

i.e.

$$A_{11} + A_{12} + \cdots + A_{1n} = 0$$

and

$$A_{21} + A_{22} + \cdots + A_{2n} = 0$$

and so on.

In my experience of teaching MATH 136 for many years I would say that chapters 7-10 are the hardest part of this course.\u00a0 I don\u2019t say this to scare you, but rather to encourage you to really set up good study habits for these next few weeks. Hopefully your midterms are over now and you can really focus on the day-to-day learning of material.\u00a0 Go to class, ask lots of questions, read the course notes, really wrestle with the practice problems, and ask questions at the tutorial centre, on Piazza or during office hours.\u00a0 Everything we have learned in the course will continue to tie together even more and I think we will see some really cool results.\u00a0\u00a0

\n

\u00a0

\n

So don\u2019t be discouraged if you find the material in the next few weeks challenging.\u00a0 Many students do.\u00a0 But know that it\u2019s not impossible.\u00a0 It will take some work to understand things, but I believe you can do it.\u00a0

Or is it an eigenvector with $$\lambda$$ = 1?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 99, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-05T18:19:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zheng Pei", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwel6ti3pjs", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-05T18:20:18Z", "content": "

The zero vector is always a fixed point in any linear transformation (because a linear transformation $$T$$ must satisfy $$T(\vec 0) = \vec 0$$).

Thus, since it is always a fixed point, we specify that eigenvectors are always nontrival (we are not interested in trivial cases); i.e. $$\vec 0$$ is not an eigenvector.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-05T18:19:55Z", "content": "

So we specify that eigenvectors are always nontrival; i.e. $$\vec 0$$ is not an eigenvector.

This was made using AI.

Alone in the tutoring center I wait,

For MATH 136 help that's now too late.

The sheets on the desk remain untouched,

As I sit here feeling quite crushed.

The tutor's chair sits empty and bare,

No one to answer my questions and share.

My mind races with confusion and doubt,

As I struggle to figure this math problem out.

Oh, how I wish for someone to appear,

To guide me through this problem and clear.

But alas, I sit here all alone,

With no one to help me on my own.

The MATH 136 tutoring center sits still,

A reminder of my struggles and uphill.

I'll try again another day,

And hope for help to come my way.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips", "other"], "nr": 719, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-06T02:36:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltf6twsufz13f7", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-06T02:36:39Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ltf7r05tomj17z", "to": "ltf6twsnkw83f6", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-06T03:02:23Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltfu3r6a43u44c", "to": "ltf6twsnkw83f6", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-06T13:28:10Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "minimizing distractions", "created": "2024-03-06T02:36:39Z", "content": "I am not efficient with my time. I get easily distracted during time I am supposed to be studying and it has become quite a problem. So the time I put in does not always have a strong linear association with my results. Of course I do have quite a lot of other problems too, but this is one that is the most concerning. The solution to this problem is obviously just to focus and not get distracted, but only I don't focus. Sounds so easy but I just can't do it. I have tried to go to the library instead of staying in my room, tried setting a schedule to force myself to get certain things done within a reasonable time frame, but I still find that I am quite distracted by youtube, social media and random stuff that is not related to what I should be doing. Thank you for taking the time to read this I would really appreciated if you could share with me how you guys stay focused not to get distracted and what you think I should do to start the progress  towards minimizing distractions."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student", "tips"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Simran Matharu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ljdjnuz5nmh4uj", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 139, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-06T03:02:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Ah Von Tyler", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwedobfp16ww", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-06T03:02:23Z", "content": "Highly recommend the pomodoro technique (or animedoro if you’re into anime). Also, it helps to set smaller goals since they help you feel more accomplished, and I know for me personally feeling accomplished makes it easier to continue working. A final tip would be to study to understand content, and to not be so strict with giving yourself a fixed time to study. The first 10-15 minutes of studying is usually the hardest to do, but once you’re engaged in whatever you’re studying time flies easier. Best of luck with your studying :)"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l6at4v5pzre7le", "idt8cfyuv993c4", "lkqwedobfp16ww", "kggoe9bxe5d42u"], "children": [], "id": "ltf7r05mln717y", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-06T13:28:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-06T13:28:10Z", "content": "

The student answer gives some great advice.  I have never used the pomodoro technique myself but I went to a workshop about cognitive science and learning and it was strongly recommended. 

I wonder if it would be helpful to print out the problems you were working on (assignment or practice problems) and work completely on paper.  Then your device wouldn't be a distraction. 

Another suggestion is to study with a partner and monitor each other's behaviour.  You don't have to talk to each other but you can support each other in keeping yourself on task.

I learned an efficient way for calculating determinant of 3x3 matrices so I'm wondering if I can jump to the numer answer of det(A)"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa3"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 174, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-06T04:30:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yilin", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwam6q3i52z9", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-06T04:30:08Z", "content": "

If your method is efficient, then it shouldn't take too much time to write it down. Can you post an example of your method?

\n

\n

If the question is not fill-in-the-blank, we expect to see as many details as possible, especially the key steps of the calculation. Performing two or multiple EROs at once is fine. It's important to illustrate how you deduce the answer and which tools you use. If you are expanding the determinant along a row or column, you need to specify which row or column. If performing EROs, specify what EROs you are using and how you are obtaining a triangular matrix.

I'm not sure what you mean. What are these "arbitrary column entries" referring to and what are the "constant vectors from the coefficient matrix"?

\n

\n

Cramer's rule states that when $$A$$ is invertible, the (necessarily unique) solution to $$A \\vec x = \\vec b$$ is given by a particular vector.

today\u2019s world and the more diversity that there is in the people working in these fields the more potential there is for positive impact.\u00a0 Unfortunately, woman and those whose gender identity is outside the gender binary have been historically under-represented in these fields.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 This under-representation continues at the University of Waterloo and two of the Hello,

I was wondering if it is true that a linear transformation $$T : \mathbb{R}^n\to \mathbb{R}^n$$ will always be determined by a nxn matrix. I feel like it makes sense but I'm not sure if it is 100 true so I wanted to ask.

Yes this is true!

I found these parts in the course notes, not sure if your question is entirely proven by these definitions, but they can at least provide some confirmation:

(Definition 5.1.1 -- Function Determined by a Matrix, if you can't see the screenshot)

Note that the definition uses m and n to specify both the matrix and the linear transformation in a deliberate way. ($$A_{mxn} \Rightarrow T_A: \mathbb{F}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{F}^m$$)

We also know from 5.5 that every linear transformation is determined by a matrix, and you can see in 5.5.5 that they use the same conventions of m and n:

Everything is very well-organized with all of the relevant proofs right there, and if you have been attending lectures, they may provide a different insight to specific topics than how your professor may have motivated it.

", "created": "2024-03-09T03:04:55Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Yes, because $$\vec{u}$$ is a unit vector. ", "created": "2024-03-09T13:36:26Z", "bucket_order": 6, "bucket_name": "Last week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltk4py32a64fc", "updated": "2024-03-09T13:36:26Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

How do we know that $$\vec{u}^T \vec{u}$$ is a 1 * 1 matrix? shouldn't it be a n * n matrix? How can be guaranteed that n is 1? Thank you

", "created": "2024-03-10T02:13:20Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltkvrbsc6rs7en", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-03-10T02:13:20Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

We know that $$\vec u$$ is a vector, so it is essentially an $$n\times 1$$ matrix ($$n$$ rows and $$1$$ column). 

Having said that, $$\vec u^T$$ is then a $$1\times n$$ matrix. 

So the product $$\vec u^T \vec u$$ is defined since $$n=n$$ and is given by a $$1\times 1$$ matrix. 

You can see this from the definition:

I like to think of it as the "inner" variables ensure the product is defined, and the "outer" variables are what dictates the size of the product. (although you should come up with something that works for you!)

Does that help?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa3"], "nr": 744, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-08T11:08:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltijzekhv3429z", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-08T11:08:09Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "ltin1iqtzi4sk", "to": "ltijzekadtw29y", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-08T12:33:47Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltiohg77i5v6tq", "to": "ltijzekadtw29y", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-08T13:14:09Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ltiwc6w5kby12n", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-08T16:54:01Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltijzekadtw29y", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-08T17:28:09Z", "cid": "ltixk33y2z54", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "to": "ltijzekadtw29y", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-08T18:47:19Z", "cid": "ltj0dwnsd865m5"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WA3", "created": "2024-03-08T11:08:09Z", "content": "If a matrix is one-to-one, can we just say it is also onto by invertibility criteria second version? "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa3"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 188, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-08T12:33:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-08T16:54:01Z", "content": "

I love that theorem, everything is equivalent so if you have one condition you have all of them. 

HOWEVER, be careful because this criteria only applies to square matrices 
If it is square, you can do that no problem! If it isn’t, you’ll have to go about proving in a different way. 

(in fact, if it's not a square matrix, being one-to-one implies that it's not onto!)
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-08T12:33:47Z", "content": "I love that theorem, everything is equivalent so if you have one condition you have all of them. 

HOWEVER, be careful because this criteria only applies to square matrices 

If it is square, you can do that no problem! If it isn’t, you’ll have to go about proving in a different way.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa3"], "nr": 745, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-08T11:13:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltik5u6siiaph", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-08T11:13:09Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "ltimyuin91930g", "to": "ltik5u6juu8pg", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-08T12:31:42Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltiol000c2l2ac", "to": "ltik5u6juu8pg", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-08T13:16:55Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltik5u6juu8pg", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-08T13:17:46Z", "cid": "ltiom2zc2zs663", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "[WA3] Q5(b) Dot product or multiplication?", "created": "2024-03-08T11:13:09Z", "content": "I almost have the solution for Q5(b) however I'm having trouble with the dot product part in the last line, if it is that. On the LHS of what we're trying to prove we have matrix multiplication so we have a matrix. However on the other side we have what looks like a dot product, meaning we have a scalar. These can't be equal to each other (and in my working I'm just getting the scalar multiplication of det(A) and the standard basis vector for j). Is this meant to be multiplication or a dot product?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa3"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 187, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-08T12:31:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nyx Kucharski", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwd7vlnh75zu", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-08T12:31:42Z", "content": "The left side is actually matrix vector multiplication ($$A\\vec x$$) and the right side is scalar multiplication of a vector ($$c \\vec x$$) so they will both yield a vector\u00a0

I agree that it could be misleading with the dot on the right side, since historically we\u2019ve been careful about giving that the specific meaning of the dot product.\u00a0

Does that make more sense?
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwd7vlnh75zu"], "children": [], "id": "ltimyuih8c430f", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-08T13:16:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nyx Kucharski", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwd7vlnh75zu", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-08T13:16:55Z", "content": "Yeah, I can see why this is confusing.\u00a0 The notation $$\\cdot$$ was used to show that we are multiplying $$\\vec{e}_j$$ by the scalar $$\\det(A)$$.\u00a0 What is meant is $$(\\det(A))\\vec{e}_j$$.\u00a0 Does that help?"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwd7vlnh75zu"], "children": [], "id": "ltiokzzxhtn2ab", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Yes that's perfect - I assumed so but wanted to double check to make sure. Thanks for the help!

\n

Thanks"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa3"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nathan McGregor", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdgm8kam7jk", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 249, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-08T13:39:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zhirui Lyu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": "1700080244_200.jpg", "id": "lkqwehdad3p7l6", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lkqwehdad3p7l6/1700080244_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-08T13:39:43Z", "content": "I recommend considering the standard matrices of $$S$$, $$T$$ and $$S \\circ T$$.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehdad3p7l6"], "children": [], "id": "ltipebjwcft3jh", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Wondering if I can state SoT is invertible since it is a square matrix and it is onto.", "created": "2024-03-08T14:16:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

You should have another step in there to make this claim.\u00a0

\n

\n

Note that it doesn't make sense to say that $$S \\circ T$$ is a square matrix.\u00a0 I assume you mean that its standard matrix is square.\u00a0

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa3"], "nr": 754, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-08T18:39:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelx8tr9o0", "data": "ltj03coxo9a3ow", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-08T18:39:07Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltj051fsp1b5r1", "to": "ltj03copofl3ov", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-08T18:40:26Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "ltj110fh1kh1ef", "to": "ltj03copofl3ov", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-08T19:05:17Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelx8tr9o0", "subject": "How do you express a n*n matrix where very element is one?", "created": "2024-03-08T18:39:07Z", "content": "How do you express a n*n matrix where very element is one?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa3"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 155, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-08T18:40:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-08T18:40:26Z", "content": "

I would say

"Let $$A \in M_{n \times n}(\mathbb R)$$ be the $$n \times n$$ matrix with all $$1$$s; that is, let

$$A := \begin{bmatrix} 1 & \cdots & 1 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots \\ 1 & \cdots & 1 \end{bmatrix}$$"

Assuming you're asking about question 5 on WA3,

its the vector with every entry equal to 0 except the j'th entry which is 1

$$\begin{equation}\vec{e}_j=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ \vdots \\ 1 \\\vdots\\0\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^n\end{equation}$$

in summary just a vector with n rows where the j'th row's entry is 1 and the other entries are 0

Or can non-invertible matrix also result in non-zero determinants?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa3"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 211, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-09T17:37:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-09T17:37:07Z", "content": "A matrix $$A$$ is invertible if and only if det$$(A) \\neq 0$$. If I can, how to prove it?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 92, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T05:47:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T05:55:05Z", "content": "

Good question. We do have $$\mathrm{rank}(AB)\leq \min\{\mathrm{rank}(A), \mathrm{rank}(B)\}$$, but this is not in the course notes. There are various ways to prove it. Since we haven't learned dimension or linear independence, so far the only method is solving system of linear equations and counting pivots.

Hint: Compare the nullspaces of $$AB$$ and $$B$$. Also you need to use the fact that nullity is equal to the number of free parameters (and System Rank Theorem).

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T05:53:38Z", "content": "

Hint: Compare the nullspaces of $$AB$$ and $$B$$. Also you need to use the fact that nullity is equal to the number of free parameters (and System Rank Theorem).

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T05:49:46Z", "content": "

I don't know what you are trying to obtain. Do you want $$\sum_{j} C_{jk}(A) = C_{jk}(A)$$ for some $$j$$ or for all $$j$$? Neither is possible if you have a sum like $$1+2+3+4=10$$, $$10 \neq 1 ,2,3,4$$.

To solve this problem you need to use the row/column expansion of a determinant into linear combinations of cofactors.

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 789, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T15:05:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltlnc9wwehf35s", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-10T15:05:27Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltlrqc74c0q1hi", "to": "ltlnc9wom7435r", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-10T17:08:21Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "data": "ltlt8nhkyfz6fw", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-03-10T17:50:36Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Fixed points and eigenvectors", "created": "2024-03-10T17:50:36Z", "content": "

1)Why do we care about fixed points in a linear transformation?
2) Fixed points are not always eigenvectors. since the zero vector is always a fixed point but cannot be an eigenvector.

Is my understanding in 2) correct?

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Fixed points and eigenvectors", "created": "2024-03-10T15:05:27Z", "content": "

1)Why do we care about fixed points in a linear transformation?
2) Fixed points are always not eigenvectors. since the zero vector is always a fixed point but cannot be an eigenvector.

Is my understanding in 2) correct?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 66, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T17:08:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T17:08:21Z", "content": "

Your understanding 2) is correct.

Fixed points of a transformation are inputs that are unaffected by the linear transformation.  They give us some understanding of the geometry of the transformation. 

We won't do much more with fixed points in this course, but they do show up in future mathematics.  You can read more here to get some examples:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixed_point_(mathematics)

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa3"], "nr": 790, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T15:23:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltlnz5czx8r1su", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-10T15:23:14Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ltlrp84c3c136", "to": "ltlnz5cry5e1st", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-10T17:07:30Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ltlrrxjqueh3k1", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-10T17:09:36Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "[Invertibility Criteria]", "created": "2024-03-10T15:23:14Z", "content": "

Hi, will I get marks deducted if I use invertible criteria after determining the square matrix is onto and one-to-one?


(Instead of using the invertibility criteria -- second version directly, b/c I was unsure about whether it was right to do so at that time)

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa3"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 145, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T17:07:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zhirui Lyu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": "1700080244_200.jpg", "id": "lkqwehdad3p7l6", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lkqwehdad3p7l6/1700080244_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T17:09:36Z", "content": "

First, we don't say a sqaure matrix is one-to-one or onto. One-to-one and onto are properties for maps. So you can say $$T_A$$ (a linear transformation defined by $$\vec{x}\to A\vec{x}$$) is one-to-one or onto.

Yes, once you have shown that $$T_A$$ is one-to-one or onto, using invertibility criteria, you can conclude that $$A$$ is invertible.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T17:07:30Z", "content": "

Yes, once you have shown that $$T_A$$ is one-to-one or onto, using invertibility criteria, you can conlude that $$A$$ is invertible.
