{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 791, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T15:30:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltlo92cdgwi4hf", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-10T15:30:57Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ltlqo8jr14q3pa", "to": "ltlo92c5tg24he", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-10T16:38:44Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "roots of a polynomial vs roots of a equation", "created": "2024-03-10T15:30:57Z", "content": "Are the roots of a equation the same as the root of a polynomial? I assume that polynomial and equation mean the same thing?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 71, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T16:38:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T16:38:44Z", "content": "

Roots of a polynomial $$p(x)$$ are the\u00a0solutions of the equation $$p(x)=0$$.

\n

\n

Equation has to have an equal sign. If you set a polynomial equal to zero you have a polynomial equation, i.g. quadratic equation, cubic equation, etc. If you set a trigonometric function equal to zero you have an trig equation.\u00a0

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l6at4v5pzre7le"], "children": [], "id": "ltlqo8jkzkh3p9", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltlo92c5tg24he", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457200890, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week8"], "nr": 792, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T16:47:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltlqztyan9a6bz", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-10T16:47:45Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltlr3din3cm2p8", "to": "ltlqzty0q066by", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-10T16:50:30Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdtnab74211", "data": "ltqw6q6emep76e", "to": "ltlqzty0q066by", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-14T07:11:55Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WP8 Q9 Recommended", "created": "2024-03-10T16:47:45Z", "content": "

Hello,

The question asks "Is there a matrix $$A \in M_{3 \times 3}(\mathbb{R})$$ that has exactly two real eigenvalues?".

Does exactly two real eigenvalues include repeated roots? For example, I found 

$$A = \left[\begin{matrix} 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 & 0  \end{matrix}\right]$$ to have eigenvalues $$\lambda_1 = 2, \lambda_2 = -1, \lambda_3 = -1$$. If the repeated eigenvalue -1 is only counted once, then $$A$$ would satisfy the criteria of having exactly two real roots. Would this be a valid example?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 110, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T16:50:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vikas Nibhanupudi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwenjljntyg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T16:50:30Z", "content": "Repeated eigenvalues are counted as well, so your example would count 3 real eigenvalues."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwenjljntyg"], "children": [], "id": "ltlr3difmjp2p7", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-14T07:11:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdtnab74211", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-14T07:11:55Z", "content": "

$$C_{A}(λ) = c_3λ^3+c_2λ^2+c_1λ+c_0$$

Because A has exclusively real entries I believe we could apply Conjugate Root Theorem, since $$C_{A}(λ)$$ is of degree 3 there are 3 roots, CJRT says that if a complex number $$z$$ is a root so is $$\bar{z}$$ having exactly 2 real roots would imply that the third in final root is complex which is a contradiction as complex roots come in pairs for polynomials with real coefficients

I could be extremely wrong though and I'm open to anyone elses ideas

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["krvaikp4js87pd"], "children": [], "id": "ltqw6q6ausp76d", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltlqzty0q066by", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457201949, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 802, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T21:15:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltm0kr5b9lq406", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-10T21:15:57Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ltm1zz8fq2k1ko", "to": "ltm0kr51mzq405", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-10T21:55:47Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Characterisitc polynomial and eigenvalue over c", "created": "2024-03-10T21:15:57Z", "content": "

\n

\n

I am wondering if the fact that the sum of eigenvalue over = trace(A) true for eigenvalue over R as well or is it just for eigenvalue over C.\u00a0

Also we know the product of complex eigenvalue is equal to the determinant. Is the product of real eigenvalues equal to the determinant as well?\u00a0

I looked at a few examples and so far both seemed to be true at least for the examples we have looked at. If both are true why are they true? How can I prove it?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 72, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T21:55:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T21:55:47Z", "content": "See @803."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltm1zz8ab7u1kn", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltm0kr51mzq405", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457212521, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 803, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T21:21:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltm0s6qskw83ls", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-10T21:21:44Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ltm1ispq3q6sy", "to": "ltm0s6qk18m3lr", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-10T21:42:26Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ltm27sxzgpi48", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-10T22:01:52Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ltm2b55w9b7695", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-10T22:04:28Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "ltm2las96xulv", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-10T22:12:22Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "coefficent of characterisitc polynomial", "created": "2024-03-10T21:21:44Z", "content": "

Is it still true that Cn = (-1) ^ (n) where n is the highest degree of the polynomial if we are looking at the characteristic polynomial over C?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 87, "children": [{"history_size": 4, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-10T21:42:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-10T22:12:22Z", "content": "

Yes. This formula holds for all square matrices over all field $$\mathbb{F}$$, including $$\mathbb{F}=\mathbb{C}$$.

You need to be careful that the eigenvalues are found over $$\mathbb{C}$$. Sometimes, from a real matrix, you may obtain characteristic equation $$\lambda^2+1=0$$ with no real eigenvalues, but it has two complex eigenvalues over $$\mathbb{C}$$. This formula works for eigenvalues over $$\mathbb{C}$$.

>>Is the product of real eigenvalues equal to the determinant as well? 

If an $$n\times n$$ matrix $$A$$ has $$n$$ real eigenvalues then it is true. 

If you are interested in the proof, search Vieta's formulas.

Since the vector is a unit vector, by definition, if multiplied, you would get 1, no?", "created": "2024-03-10T23:54:12Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

It doesn't matter what the entries of $$\vec u$$ are.

By definition, $$\vec u$$ is a unit vector if and only if $$\|\vec u\| = \sqrt{u_1^2 + \cdots + u_n^2} = 1$$.

How can you show that $$\vec u^\top \vec u = [1]$$?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week7"], "nr": 813, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-11T06:36:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltmkl8wwo1j28o", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-11T06:36:13Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "data": "ltmkrrrgmkx2hg", "to": "ltmkl8wnd3528n", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-11T06:41:17Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "data": "ltmksvcd47t3sd", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-11T06:42:08Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Effect of EROs on the Determinant - "Row Subtraction"", "created": "2024-03-11T06:36:13Z", "content": "

Hello,

I'd like get some clarification on the effect of Row Addition on determinants. According to the course notes, "If B is obtained from A by adding a non-zero multiple of one row to another row, then the determinants of A and B are the same." 

Here are two example EROs:

1. $$R_1 \rightarrow -R_3 + R_1$$ 

2. $$R_1 \rightarrow -R_1 + R_3$$

Will the second one produce a different determinant?

Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 114, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-11T06:41:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xing Liu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcf5nkeh7gy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-11T06:42:08Z", "content": "Yes, the second one affects the determinant since it is not an elementary row operation. You are first scaling $$R_1$$ by -1, then adding $$R_3$$ to $$R_1$$, so the determinant is multiplied by -1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-11T06:41:17Z", "content": "No, the second one is not an elementary row operation since "row subtraction" is not actually an ERO. You are first scaling $$R_1$$ by -1, then adding $$R_3$$ to $$R_1$$."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwcf5nkeh7gy", "idt8cfyuv993c4"], "children": [], "id": "ltmkrrral122hf", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltmkl8wnd3528n", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457224202, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 821, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-11T21:58:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltnhj4ntrku77k", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-11T21:58:21Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "ltnhk4yra8673t", "to": "ltnhj4nm9uc77j", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-11T21:59:08Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltnhkwhr4d87je", "to": "ltnhj4nm9uc77j", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-11T21:59:44Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Typo in course notes?", "created": "2024-03-11T21:58:21Z", "content": "

shouldn't the matrix A-3I be $$\begin{bmatrix} -2 & -1\\ -1 & -2 \end{bmatrix}$$?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 107, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-11T21:59:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Blake Madill", "endorser": {"k9331uw283xts": 1596238489}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "hbsg02xli8p54o", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Khushi Jirge", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwc2gwxor57c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-11T21:59:08Z", "content": "We’re not subtracting 3 from each entry, only the ones on the diagonal"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["hbsg02xli8p54o", "lkqwc2gwxor57c"], "children": [], "id": "ltnhk4ylt5a73s", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-11T21:59:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Khushi Jirge", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwc2gwxor57c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-11T21:59:44Z", "content": "

Recall the identity matrix is a diagonal matrix with $$1$$s in the diagonal and $$0$$s everywhere else.

$$A - 3I = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 2 & 1\end{bmatrix} - 3 \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -2 & 2 \\ 2 & -2\end{bmatrix}$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwc2gwxor57c"], "children": [], "id": "ltnhkwhleii7jc", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltnhj4nm9uc77j", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457232777, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 825, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-12T21:51:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltowqs2jzs252n", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-12T21:51:59Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltox1410o521h8", "to": "ltowqs2cyk652m", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-12T22:00:01Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "question from class", "created": "2024-03-12T21:51:59Z", "content": "This is an example from class. I'm confused with the question why we can get that there are 3 eigenvalues in total. Thanks!"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "camariut@uwaterloo.ca", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8gwt19q556", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 90, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-12T22:00:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Li Xuanhe", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwej5x9pg6c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-12T22:00:01Z", "content": "For an $$n \\times n$$ matrix $$A$$, the characteristic polynomial $$C_A(\\lambda)$$ has degree $$n$$. Recall that we define the characteristic polynomial as a function of $$\\lambda$$, the eigenvalues we are searching for, by setting

$$C_A(\\lambda) = \\text{det}(A - \\lambda I)$$

If you expand $$\\text{det}(A - \\lambda I)$$ using cofactor expansion, you can find the highest degree of $$\\lambda$$ is $$n$$. Thus, for this example, we should expect the characteristic polynomial $$C_A(\\lambda)$$ to be cubic, so we can expect 3 eigenvalues $$\\lambda_1, \\lambda_2, \\lambda_3$$.
"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwej5x9pg6c"], "children": [], "id": "ltox140srq11h7", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqw8gwt19q556"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltowqs2cyk652m", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457237083, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 827, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-14T12:27:19Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltr7gbd199jua", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-14T12:27:19Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltrcljpvfzb290", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-03-14T14:51:21Z"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Mathie Wellness Handbook", "created": "2024-03-14T14:51:21Z", "content": "

Happy Pi Day!  I hope you will get the chance to eat some pie and enjoy the day when a lot of the world celebrates mathematics. 

As students of the math faculty you may feel like math consumes your life.  As much as your studies are a huge part of your life right now, I hope it's not all of your life.  The Math faculty has a resource called the Mathie Wellness Handbook that helps you look at many dimensions of your life. You can visit https://uwaterloo.ca/math/mathie-wellness to download it (just scroll to the end). 

Wellness has many dimensions and all of these dimensions are equally important.  This handbook includes A LOT of great advice, including practical suggestions, on nine dimensions of wellness. 

  1. CULTURAL WELLNESS
  2. EMOTIONAL WELLNESS
  3. ENVIRONMENTAL WELLNESS
  4. FINANCIAL WELLNESS
  5. INTELLECTUAL WELLNESS
  6. PHYSICAL WELLNESS
  7. RELATIONAL (SOCIAL) WELLNESS
  8. SPIRITUAL WELLNESS
  9. VOCATIONAL (OCCUPATIONAL) WELLNESS

Check it out and enjoy your Pi Day!

We won't ask you questions that will specifically require the usage of some derived standard matrix (such as reflections, rotations, etc.).

For this question, it is necessary to justify the distance between the transformed vertices like this. It may be intuitively obvious that a reflection won't change the distance between consecutive vertices, but the whole point of the computation is to verify that that idea is actually correct.

I cannot find an easier way. You don't know the solution until you solve it. 

Quadratic formula is fine. The difficulty is to find the square root of the discriminant $$-1-4(2+10i)=-9-40i$$. You may set it equal to $$(a+bi)^2=a^2-b^2+2abi$$, which gives $$ab=-20$$ and $$a^2-b^2=-9$$. Now you have a real quadratic equation. Solving it gives $$\sqrt{-9-40i} = a+bi = 4-5i$$.

Yes, you have the right idea.

Most of the time, we use WLOG when there is a lot of symmetry in our proofs.

For instance, if we know that one of $$\vec x$$ or $$\vec y$$ has a specific property, but we don't care which of $$\vec x$$ or $$\vec y$$ it is, then we will write "WLOG, suppose $$\vec x$$ has [that property]". You know it is safe to use WLOG if a proof for if $$\vec y$$ had that property instead would be the exact same.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l6at4v5pzre7le"], "children": [], "id": "lts2ppfeoa6ys", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "In the case that it would be technically a little different but the general idea is the same in each case, can we still use WLOG, or would we need to write out the whole proof, or would it be okay to write something like "the case where __ is similar except ____"", "created": "2024-03-15T08:35:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {"lqzlhgdj56n6xt": 1710434473}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

It would depend on the technicality and how "similar" the cases are.

A correctness proof for WLOG generally goes:

Let's suppose we want to prove $$P(x)$$ for all $$x \in T$$. We want to say that it suffices WLOG to show that $$P(x)$$ is true for all $$x \in S \subseteq T$$. Then, we need to show

$$P(x), \forall\  x \in S \implies P(x), \forall\ x \notin S$$

This completes the proof of correctness for the WLOG, and we can resume the rest of your proof, which is to show that $$P(x)$$ is true for all $$x \in S$$.

For instance, I claim that $$x^2 \ge 0$$ for all $$x \in \mathbb R$$. WLOG, I claim that it suffices to show this result for $$x \ge 0$$. Here, the hypothesis $$P(x)$$ is $$x \ge 0$$, and the set $$T$$ is $$\mathbb R$$, the set $$S$$ is $$[0, \infty)$$.

The proof of correctness would be to show that

$$x^2 \ge 0, \forall \ x \ge 0 \implies x^2 \ge 0, \forall\ x < 0$$

For any $$x < 0$$, we know that $$x^2 = (-x)^2$$. In the latter term, we know that $$-x$$ is nonnegative, so by the WLOG hypothesis, we know that $$(-x)^2 \ge 0$$. From here, we conclude that $$x^2 = (-x)^2 \ge 0$$, thus completing the proof of correctness of the WLOG.

From here, I would proceed to prove that $$x^2 \ge 0, \forall \ x \ge 0$$.

Of course, this is very pedantic and usually when we use a WLOG, it is because the proof of correctness is extremely obvious. For nonobvious cases, it is good practice to give the proof of correctness of the WLOG, or simply prove both cases.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week7", "q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 96, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-15T14:48:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zhirui Lyu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": "1700080244_200.jpg", "id": "lkqwehdad3p7l6", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lkqwehdad3p7l6/1700080244_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-15T15:08:39Z", "content": "

Yes, we know that $$n$$ is odd, so $$(-1)^n = -1$$. Then, $$\text{det}(A) = -\text{det}(A)$$, which implies that $$\text{det}(A) = 0$$ ($$0$$ is the only number which is both nonnegative and nonpositive).

---

To add on, you are right that we can conduct $$n$$ ERO by multiplying each row by $$k$$, hence

$$\text{det}(kA) = k^n \text{det}(A)$$

Then, $$\text{det}(A) = -\text{det}(A)$$, which implies that $$\text{det}(A) = 0$$ ($$0$$ is the only number which is both nonnegative and nonpositive)."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehdad3p7l6"], "children": [], "id": "ltsrxhwsyxe2ya", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltsrlfsn1692ea", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457247638, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week7", "q4"], "nr": 836, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-15T18:47:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltt0gq6iopr1oy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-15T18:47:13Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltt0tezzi4p1rw", "to": "ltt0gq699si1ox", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-15T18:57:05Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "ltt0uutrkpo6jn", "to": "ltt0gq699si1ox", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-15T18:58:12Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "PP7 Q6", "created": "2024-03-15T18:47:13Z", "content": "Hi, wondering if it is correct to conduct R1-> R1+R3-R2, R2-> R2+R1-R3, and R3-> R3+R2-R1 these 3 steps at the same time, which gives us$$\begin{bmatrix} 2a & 2p & 2u\\ 2b & 2q & 2v\\ 2c & 2r & 2w \end{bmatrix}$$. (however, I think I am doing it wrongly because
I can not deduce the det($$\begin{bmatrix} 2a & 2p & 2u\\ 2b & 2q & 2v\\ 2c & 2r & 2w \end{bmatrix}$$) into 2det$$\begin{bmatrix} a & p & u\\ b & q & v\\ c & r & w \end{bmatrix}$$ directly)

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week7", "q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 88, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-15T18:57:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zhirui Lyu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": "1700080244_200.jpg", "id": "lkqwehdad3p7l6", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lkqwehdad3p7l6/1700080244_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-15T18:57:05Z", "content": "

You need to be careful about doing multiple row operations at the same time if you are using rows which have been modified.

When you perform $$R_1 \to R_1 + R_3 - R_2$$ and $$R_2 \to R_2 + R_1 - R_3$$, it is unclear what the resulting matrix is, because the first operation depends on $$R_2$$, and the second row operation depends on $$R_1$$, so the order of row operation here matters.

Moreover, I believe what you are describing is using the pre-modified value of $$R_1$$ in the row operation $$R_2 \to R_2 + R_1 - R_3$$. This isn't permitted, and where your error comes from.

In short, when you are modifying many rows, you should only do it if the order in which row operations are performed do not change the outcome (e.g. $$R_1 \to \alpha R_1$$ and $$R_2 \to R_2 + R_3$$ can be performed together because they do not influence each other).

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehdad3p7l6"], "children": [], "id": "ltt0tezri301rv", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-15T18:58:12Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Zhirui Lyu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": "1700080244_200.jpg", "id": "lkqwehdad3p7l6", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lkqwehdad3p7l6/1700080244_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-15T18:58:12Z", "content": "Yeah, you cannot perform all these operations at the same time. This will (likely or definitely? Not sure.) lead to a different result (as you have seen here). 

Your way would result in bringing a 2 out from each row, so you would have $$8\cdot \det$$

If you want some intuition for why this doesn’t work, I’d be happy to expand on my ideas for that 
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["krvaikp4js87pd", "lkqwehdad3p7l6"], "children": [], "id": "ltt0uutnitj6jm", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltt0gq699si1ox", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457248695, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["practice_week8"], "nr": 839, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T01:31:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lttewl1d5iq5qq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-16T01:31:27Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lttewtamd7g6cx", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-03-16T01:31:38Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lttf1cy4eu14ix", "to": "lttewl15xi65qp", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-16T01:35:10Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Row scaling and determinanent", "created": "2024-03-16T01:31:38Z", "content": "

How multiplying a 2 gives equality? Isn't the circled 2 an 1/2 because we multiply 1/2 to row 1? But wouldn't multiplying a 2 gives twice the determinant?

\n

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Row scaling and determinanent", "created": "2024-03-16T01:31:27Z", "content": "How multiplying a 2 gives equality? But wouldn't multiplying a 2 gives twice the determinant?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 62, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T01:35:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Junyan Ye", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwb17ooi55le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-16T01:35:10Z", "content": "Th\u00e9 effect of row scaling on the determinant is kind of like \u00ab undoing \u00bb what you did, so you multiply by the inverse.\u00a0

Say A is the original matrix and B is the one we got from performing a row scale operation:\u00a0
$$\\det(B) = c\\det(A)$$

So if we want to solve for A, the original matrix, we have to rearrange:

$$\\det(A) = \\frac{1}{c}\\det(B)$$
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4", "lkqwb17ooi55le"], "children": [], "id": "lttf1cxw1iy4iv", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lttewl15xi65qp", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457251857, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Thanks!!"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 89, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T05:00:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Li Xuanhe", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwej5x9pg6c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-16T05:00:35Z", "content": "

We want to find a matrix $$A$$ that has no real eigenvalues, but $$A^3$$ has real eigenvalues. By Q4, we know that if $$\\lambda$$ is an eigenvalue of $$A$$, then $$\\lambda^3$$ is an eigenvalue of $$A^3$$. Thus, we want to choose $$\\lambda$$ as some non-real value, but we also want to make it so $$\\lambda^3$$ is real. Thus, we look to the roots of unity, and we try to manipulate the characteristic polynomial so that we can fit a third root of unity as an eigenvalue.

\n

\n

Here is another approach you could take. My first example of a matrix with no real eigenvalues is a rotation matrix (by a nontrivial rotation). Can you pick a rotation matrix so that $$A^3 = I$$? Why would such a rotation matrix have nonreal eigenvalues, and how does this imply that $$A^3$$ has real eigenvalues? You should try writing out the rotation matrix.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwej5x9pg6c"], "children": [], "id": "lttmdix8m1b39j", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lttkfem8vvn1kk", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457252915, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa5", "final"], "nr": 843, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T14:50:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltu7gr6bocs3zh", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-16T14:50:58Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltu9gtdq3un67", "to": "ltu7gr62ena3zg", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-16T15:47:00Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltu7gr62ena3zg", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-16T16:33:54Z", "cid": "ltub550ena67fc", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Linear transformation is a function", "created": "2024-03-16T14:50:58Z", "content": "

We have looked at the idea of a linear transformation being onto, onep-to-one and having a range. Could I think about linear transformation as just a function? If they are the same, is there a reason why we use the word transformation and not function.

If they are not the same, is what is the difference between them that makes a function a function, a linear transformation a linear transformation?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student", "wa5"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 92, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T15:47:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {"lqzlhgdj56n6xt": 1710434473}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-16T15:47:00Z", "content": "

Yes, a linear transformation is a function.  It is a function between two vector spaces (a term we will define in chapter 10)  that preserves addition and scalar multiplication. 

Not all functions are between vector spaces whereas linear transformations are between vector spaces. 

So linear transformations are a subset of functions. 

(The words transformation and function are pretty much synonyms, but a transformation usually has some sort of geometric understanding connected to it.)

Maybe some of the other instructors will chime in here to add more.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 844, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T16:23:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltuasb0igilou", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-16T16:23:55Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltub7uoxubx6d", "to": "ltuasazsxb6ot", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-16T16:36:01Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Characteristic polynomial over C", "created": "2024-03-16T16:23:55Z", "content": "

So we include repeated lambda values when we are calculating Cn and C0? I'm having a little bit of trouble understanding the last paragraph of this definition.\u00a0

\n

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 54, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T16:36:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Branca Xing", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8zcl4pgki", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-16T16:36:01Z", "content": "

When calculating the sum in (a) and the product in (b) you need to calculate the sum and the product of all the roots of the polynomial including repetition.\u00a0

\n

For example,\u00a0 you have may roots of the polynomial as 2, 2, and 3.\u00a0 This means the eigenvalue 2 was repeated twice.\u00a0 So the sum of the eigenvalues is 7 and the product of the eigenvalues is 12.\u00a0 So $$c_2= 7$$ and\u00a0 $$c_0=12$$.\u00a0

$$(-1)^3(\\lambda-2)^2(\\lambda-3)= -\\lambda^3+7\\lambda^2-16\\lambda+12$$ has roots 2, 2, and 3 and the coefficients match what we have above.\u00a0

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8zcl4pgki"], "children": [], "id": "ltub7uorr456b", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltuasazsxb6ot", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457257141, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 848, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T18:26:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "data": "ltuf5ahwket3rr", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-16T18:26:00Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltuj6wf4obn42f", "to": "ltuf5ahnj2s3rq", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-16T20:19:13Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltujbv3l9sg4sr", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-16T20:23:05Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "subject": "Adjugate and Determinant", "created": "2024-03-16T18:26:00Z", "content": "Does the determinant of the adjugating function give you the same determinant as the original function?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 65, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T20:19:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-16T20:23:05Z", "content": "

$$\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\right) = ad - bc = da - (-c)(-b) = \text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a\end{bmatrix}\right)$$

so yes, same determinant for $$2 \times 2$$.

In general, we know that

$$A \text{adj}(A) = \text{det}(A) I_n$$

Hence taking determinants on both sides:

$$\text{det}(A)\text{det}(\text{adj}(A)) = \text{det}(A \text{adj}(A)) = \text{det}(\text{det}(A) I_n) = \text{det}(A)^n$$

hence we can conclude that if $$\text{det}(A) \neq 0$$, then

$$\text{det}(\text{adj}(A)) = \text{det}(A)^{n-1}$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-16T20:19:13Z", "content": "

$$\text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\right) = ad - bc = da - (-c)(-b) = \text{det}\left(\begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a\end{bmatrix}\right)$$

so yes, same determinant.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltuj6wexrme42d", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltuf5ahnj2s3rq", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457261358, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 853, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T21:39:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltum2kmwb4s2i1", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-16T21:39:50Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltum3dhmgqd6pg", "to": "ltum2kmpnrc2i0", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-16T21:40:28Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Why is the following matrix invertible", "created": "2024-03-16T21:39:50Z", "content": "

The inverse of 

\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} 

is

\begin{bmatrix} 1 & -1 \\ -1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} 

But the first matrix clearly doesn't have it's RREF = $$I_2$$

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 855, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T22:48:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "data": "ltuoio90gc55we", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-16T22:48:21Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lturx4oeb4d69b", "to": "ltuoio8tuge5wd", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T00:23:34Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "subject": "Eigenvector", "created": "2024-03-16T22:48:21Z", "content": "If we have a repeated eigenvalue, does it mean we also have a repeated eigenvector, where repeated ones count?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 51, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T00:23:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {"lqzlhgdj56n6xt": 1710434473}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T00:23:34Z", "content": "

In general, we don't tend to count eigenvectors because for each eigenvalue $$\lambda$$, if $$\vec v$$ satisfies

$$A \vec v = \lambda \vec v$$, then

$$A (c \vec v) = \lambda c \vec v$$ for all $$c \in \mathbb R$$

hence $$c \vec v$$ is also an eigenvector for that associated eigenvalue.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l6at4v5pzre7le"], "children": [], "id": "lturx4o682i69a", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltuoio8tuge5wd", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457268761, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 856, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-16T22:57:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "data": "ltuouze07802bq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-16T22:57:55Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lturzvt4ypk37z", "to": "ltuouzdrd342bn", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T00:25:42Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "subject": "Eigenspace and Characteristics Polynomial", "created": "2024-03-16T22:57:55Z", "content": "Is it true that the difference between eigenspace and characteristics polynomial lies on the fact that eigenspace only uses nullspace, not determinant, whereas characteristics polynomial uses determinant. I want to ensure that I accurately distinguish between the two?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 60, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T00:25:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T00:25:42Z", "content": "

There is a big difference between eigenspaces and characteristic polynomials.

The characteristic polynomial is a polynomial function that tells you about the eigenvalues of a specific $$n \times n$$ matrix $$A$$; specifically, that the roots of the characteristic polynomial are the eigenvalues. The characteristic polynomial is calculated through the use of the determinant.

An eigenspace for an eigenvalue $$\lambda$$ is the set of all associated eigenvectors for $$\lambda$$. To solve for the eigenspace, you would solve the homogenous system $$(A - \lambda I)\vec x = \vec 0$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lturzvsyzq537y", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltuouzdrd342bn", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457269820, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week8"], "nr": 860, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T02:01:49Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltuvfhg3cp46d8", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-17T02:01:49Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltuvpkygxlx3zy", "to": "ltuvfhfus596d7", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T02:09:40Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Eigenpairs for repeated eigenvalue", "created": "2024-03-17T02:01:49Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 63, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T02:09:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {"lqzlhgdj56n6xt": 1710434473}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T02:09:40Z", "content": "If you choose any values for $$t$$ and $$u$$, you will get an eigenvector corresponding to $$\lambda=2$$.  There are an infinite number of eigenpairs. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l6at4v5pzre7le"], "children": [], "id": "ltuvpky73wc3zx", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltuvfhfus596d7", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457274049, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 861, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T04:23:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltv0hs08fdq5xg", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-17T04:23:34Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltv1i33pybj39j", "to": "ltv0hrzyvnd5xf", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T04:51:48Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "[007] Lecture 24 - Diagonalization", "created": "2024-03-17T04:23:34Z", "content": "

How are we able to say that Q^-1 * P^-1 = (PQ)^-1? Wouldn't swapping the positions of Q^-1 and P^-1 not be equivalent because matrices are not commutative? Or is there a proposition in the textbook or elsewhere that I missed?

I know that with transposes Q^T P^T = (PQ)^T but I am not sure if a result like that is even relevant to this problem.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 73, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T04:51:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T04:51:48Z", "content": "

Think about the inverse of the matrix $$PQ$$, if $$P^{-1}$$ and $$Q^{-1}$$ both exist.

Using associativity of matrix multiplication, we can evaluate

$$Q^{-1}P^{-1}PQ = I$$ and $$PQ Q^{-1}P^{-1} = I$$

so by the uniqueness of an inverse matrix, we can conclude that the matrix $$Q^{-1}P^{-1}$$ is exactly the inverse of $$PQ$$. That is, that

$$(PQ)^{-1} = Q^{-1}P^{-1}$$

(keep in mind that this is only true if $$P^{-1}$$ and $$Q^{-1}$$ both exist).

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltv1i33jyns39i", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltv0hrzyvnd5xf", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457275127, "default_anonymity": "no"}

This is the only case where a fixed point is not also an eigenvector. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 863, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T15:52:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "data": "ltvp3rd69ua4zl", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-17T15:52:31Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "ltvp7r4tjnd4w2", "to": "ltvp3rcxfi04zk", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T15:55:37Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "subject": "Eigenpair and eigenspace", "created": "2024-03-17T15:52:31Z", "content": "What is the difference between eigenpair and eigenspace?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 52, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T15:55:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xinhao Wang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwelvposqnn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T15:55:37Z", "content": "

The eigenpair is just a way for us to group an eigenvalue and a corresponding eigenvector together

The eigenspace is a subspace that contains all the eigenvectors associated to a given eigenvalue (and it contains $$\vec 0$$, which is not an eigenvector but allows the eigenspace to be a subspace)

Does that answer your question?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 869, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T17:11:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "data": "ltvrxv90v3p17p", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-17T17:11:55Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "data": "ltvrybsn7f4238", "to": "ltvrxv8s2wj17n", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T17:12:16Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "to": "ltvrxv8s2wj17n", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-17T17:23:38Z", "cid": "ltvscy2lbq81wk"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltvsnnibpr160u", "to": "ltvrxv8s2wj17n", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T17:31:58Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "subject": "eigenvalue and eigenvector", "created": "2024-03-17T17:11:54Z", "content": "Is it true that we only use determinant to find eigenvalue, and finding eigenvector doesn't need eigenvector?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 62, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T17:12:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqweg63r8w7db", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T17:12:16Z", "content": "What I meant is that finding eigenvector doesn't require finding determinant?"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltvrybsg9zi237", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

You don't need the determinant to find the eigenspace (and hence all the eigenvectors).

You just need a particular eigenvalue $$\lambda$$ and the matrix $$A$$

To find the eigenspace, solve $$(A-\lambda I_n)\vec x = \vec 0$$, which looks kinda weird with the variables in it, but it's the same as solving our other matrices (row reduce, find the solution set, voila!)

", "created": "2024-03-17T17:23:38Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltvscy2lbq81wk", "updated": "2024-03-17T17:23:40Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T17:31:58Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T17:31:58Z", "content": "

If you have an eigenvalue $$\lambda$$, and you want to find an eigenvector for $$\lambda$$, then you want to find a nonzero vector $$\vec v$$ so that

$$A \vec v = \lambda \vec v$$

To solve this, you can solve the system

$$(A - \lambda I)\vec v = \vec 0$$.

So you do not need to take any determinants.

You have the wrong theorem.

The theorem should state

$$A$$ is invertible if and only if $$0$$ is not an eigenvalue.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q4"], "nr": 871, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T17:55:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltvti2oq3364le", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-17T17:55:37Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "ltvzu158xjd4cu", "to": "ltvti2oi9or4ld", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T20:52:52Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltw21ruls2v3k0", "to": "ltvti2oi9or4ld", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-17T21:54:53Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "nxn matrix has at most n eignenvalues", "created": "2024-03-17T17:55:37Z", "content": "Could I just state that a nxn matrix have at most n eigenvalues without proof?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 90, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T20:52:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T20:52:52Z", "content": "

Seems fair enough to me.

If you want to be really rigorous about it, you can cite 7.3.4 to say that the characteristic polynomial is an nth degree polynomial, then you would have to backtrack to math 135 with Proposition CPN on page 185 to say that means there would be $$n$$ complex roots. 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4"], "children": [], "id": "ltvzu14xbe84ct", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T21:54:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {"lqzlhgdj56n6xt": 1710434473}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T21:54:53Z", "content": "Yes, you can simply state that the characteristic polynomial is of degree $$n$$ and has at most $$n$$ roots. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l6at4v5pzre7le"], "children": [], "id": "ltw21ruhtg93jz", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltvti2oi9or4ld", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457285698, "default_anonymity": "no"}

$$A$$ and $$B$$ can be different matrices, but we assume that $$\vec v$$ is an eigenvector for both of them. So we state two different eigenvalues ($$\lambda$$ and $$\mu$$) that correspond with $$\vec v$$, but for different matrices. 

I believe you are correct that a given eigenvector will only have 1 corresponding eigenvalue, but I am not 100% sure. 

Does that answer your question? If not, could you be more specific about where in the solution they appear to have done what you suggested?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week8", "q4", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 99, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T00:12:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zhirui Lyu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": "1700080244_200.jpg", "id": "lkqwehdad3p7l6", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lkqwehdad3p7l6/1700080244_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T00:12:13Z", "content": "I'm not sure I understand your question.\u00a0 They make a claim that $$\\lambda_1=\\lambda_3$$ and $$\\lambda_2=\\lambda_3$$ and then prove that claim.\u00a0 By proving that claim, they have proved that $$\\lambda_1=\\lambda_2$$.\u00a0 (The proof by contradiction is their proof of the claim.)"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehdad3p7l6"], "children": [], "id": "ltw6ye6rk9t51", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltvyqdv34rl4bh", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457288882, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 99, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-17T23:28:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Landon Trinh", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcmng7k212i", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-17T23:28:20Z", "content": "

I can sort of see where you're coming from here, and you are correct that $$\det(A+B)\neq \det(A) + \det(B)$$, however that is not what is going on here

We know that $$\det(A)=\det(A^T)$$, however that can't help us directly since we need $$\det(A-\lambda I)$$. Conveniently, we also have that $$(B+cD)^T=B^T+cD^T$$.

So we can use both of these facts at the same time:

$$\det(A-\lambda I) = \det((A-\lambda I)^T)$$ (I assume we agree up to here)

$$= \det(A^T-(\lambda I)^T)$$ (using the $$(B+cD)^T$$ property stated above)

$$=\det(A^T-\lambda I)$$      (since $$(\lambda I)^T$$ is just $$\lambda I$$ because $$I$$ is diagonal)

Reading this over, it seems like I repeated exactly what the solution says, so not sure if this is entirely helpful, but just as an extra note:

$$\det(A) = \det(A^T) \not\Rightarrow A=A^T$$. We are only allowed performing this operation inside the determinant. 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4", "lkqwcmng7k212i"], "children": [], "id": "ltw5dyj6x281vb", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Factor by grouping:

$$a^3-3a+2 = a^3-a-2a+2=a(a^2-1)-2(a-1)=a(a+1)(a-1)-2(a-1)=(a-1)(a^2+a-2)=(a-1)(a-1)(a+2)=(a-1)^2(a+2)$$

Im not really sure where the (a-3) came from as well

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week8"], "nr": 881, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T00:50:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltw8baixoor734", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-18T00:50:15Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "ltw9ibfluc1hx", "to": "ltw8baioqqa733", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-18T01:23:42Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "ltw9iqapqw93j9", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-18T01:24:01Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "MP8: How to go from row reduce to general solution?", "created": "2024-03-18T00:50:15Z", "content": "

Hi! I I get how to go to the RREF form, yet I don't know how it proceeds to the general solution.

I understand how $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\0 \end{bmatrix}$$ would be part of the span, but where did the $$\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\0 \end{bmatrix}$$ come from?

Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 79, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T01:23:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Julia Qiu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwax6b6y44vy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T01:24:01Z", "content": "Picking up from the RREF form, we have that the nullity(A) = n - rank(A) = 2 which we also know is the number of parameters 

So we have 2 parameters, and one fixed value. Now, I’ll just take the matrix and put it back into equation form:

Row 1: $$0x_1 + 0x_2 + 1x_3 = 0$$. From this we know that $$x_3 = 0$$

Then, we have two rows of just 0’s, so it doesn’t matter what we make $$x_2$$ and $$x_1$$. So, we make them parameters! Let $$x_1 = t$$ and $$x_2 = s$$. So we write out the span as 

$$Span\{\begin{bmatrix}{t \\ 0 \\ 0}\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}{0 \\ s \\ 0}\end{bmatrix}\}$$ which then simplifies to what they have as the span!

Basically it’s a matter of how many parameters we have
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T01:23:42Z", "content": "Picking up from the RREF form, we have that the nullity(A) = n - rank(A) = 2 which we also know is the number of parameters 

So we have 2 parameters, and one fixed value. Now, I’ll just take the matrix and put it back into equation form:

Row 1: $$0x_1 + 0x_2 + 1x_3 = 0$$. From this we know that $$x_3 = 0$$

Then, we have two rows of just 0’s, so it doesn’t matter what we make $$x_2$$ and $$x_1$$. So, we make them parameters! Let $$x_1 = t$$ and $$x_2 = s$$. So we write out the span as 

$$Span{\begin{bmatrix}{t \\ 0 \\ 0}\end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}{0 \\ s \\ 0}\end{bmatrix}}$$ which then simplifies to what they have as the span!

Basically it’s a matter of how many parameters we have

And in terms of the notation - does the double sigma mean that the summation depends on two variables (i and j in this case), or is there an 'inner' and 'outer' sum that we are dealing with?", "created": "2024-03-18T03:37:40Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

The summation is dependent on both variables.

If you are familiar with the concept of for loops in programming, this is very similar to something like

int sum = 0

for (i = 1 to i = n):

  for (j = i to j = n):

       sum += a_ij b_ji

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week7"], "nr": 887, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T06:26:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "data": "ltwkc50g6rk2y7", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-18T06:26:50Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "ltwkf1xacqx4zk", "to": "ltwkc507cxy2y6", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-18T06:29:06Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "Cramers rule question", "created": "2024-03-18T06:26:50Z", "content": "

Is there any easy way of doing this, or are we just supposed to calculate every determinant?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week7", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 110, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T06:29:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Matthew WenYue Liu", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1695658850, "global": 1701470489, "lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1702143473, "lqzes2lznxt50s": 1707071031, "lr148a6jm3j40f": 1709849396}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T06:29:06Z", "content": "

Realistically, you would use an online calculator to compute this (if this is for practice for using Cramer's rule; better would be to directly use an online calculator to solve the system), but if I had to compute this by hand, I would calculate the determinants of all of the $$3 \times 3$$ and then $$4 \times 4$$ minors of $$A$$ to make this easier.

We will never ask you to compute the determinant of a $$5\times 5$$ matrix or larger, unless there is a pattern to the matrix.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdweou4p2j4"], "children": [], "id": "ltwkf1x1ans4zj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltwkc507cxy2y6", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457302606, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week8"], "nr": 889, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T14:05:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "ltx0pvcpuvg2x9", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-18T14:05:24Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltx0ry0gj9u3mp", "to": "ltx0pvci8ca2x8", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-18T14:07:01Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltx0pvci8ca2x8", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-18T14:08:13Z", "cid": "ltx0thnxt3ri4", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "to": "ltx0pvci8ca2x8", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-18T14:10:41Z", "cid": "ltx0wnivisx1hr"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltx0pvci8ca2x8", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-18T14:13:00Z", "cid": "ltx0zncpw13m0", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "to": "ltx0pvci8ca2x8", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-18T14:21:17Z", "cid": "ltx1aaeujmv4s0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltx0pvci8ca2x8", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-18T14:24:11Z", "cid": "ltx1e0w7yiy4qj", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "to": "ltx0pvci8ca2x8", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-18T14:25:24Z", "cid": "ltx1fl5kgq64kv"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltx0pvci8ca2x8", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-18T14:27:59Z", "cid": "ltx1iwysc1r3rq", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "to": "ltx0pvci8ca2x8", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-18T16:13:49Z", "cid": "ltx5b0gafpg6hu"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwe9bk4si65f", "to": "ltx0pvci8ca2x8", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-18T16:14:09Z", "cid": "ltx5bfjnqn05ay"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Do determinants being equal imply that the Eigenvalues are equal?", "created": "2024-03-18T14:05:24Z", "content": "

For this question, why must the Eigenvalues be the same? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 88, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-18T14:07:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T14:07:01Z", "content": "If the matrices have the same characteristic polynomial, then the roots of this polynomial are the eigenvalues of both matrices.  In other words, the matrices have the same eigenvalues. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "ltx0ry087vg3mn", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "How would you know if the matrices have the same characteristic polynomial? Isn't the characteristic polynomial the result of expanding the determinant?", "created": "2024-03-18T14:08:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "In the proof we have that $$\det(A-\lambda I)= \det(A^T-\lambda I)$$.  That's how we calculate the characteristic polynomial.", "created": "2024-03-18T14:10:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltx0wnivisx1hr", "updated": "2024-03-18T14:11:28Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "So it's because the determinants are equal the characteristic polynomials are also equal? Sorry, I'm still not really understanding. ", "created": "2024-03-18T14:13:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltx0zncpw13m0", "updated": "2024-03-18T14:13:00Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

If you want to find the eigenvalue of $$A$$ you need to find the values of $$\lambda$$ such that  $$\det(A-\lambda I)=0$$.  To find the eigenvalue of $$A^T$$ you need to find the values of $$\lambda$$ such that  $$\det(A^T-\lambda I)=0$$.

However, we can prove that  $$\det(A-\lambda I)= \det(A^T-\lambda I)$$.  Is this where you are getting stuck?  Do you not see why this is true? 

", "created": "2024-03-18T14:21:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltx1aaeujmv4s0", "updated": "2024-03-18T14:21:17Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Yeah, I'm having trouble understanding why the solutions for lambda would be the same for both sides of the equation", "created": "2024-03-18T14:24:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltx1e0w7yiy4qj", "updated": "2024-03-18T14:24:11Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Well if the polynomials are the same, then their roots must be the same. ", "created": "2024-03-18T14:25:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltx1fl5kgq64kv", "updated": "2024-03-18T14:25:24Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "So matrices with the same determinant will have the same characteristic polynomial thus have the same Eigenvalues? ", "created": "2024-03-18T14:27:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltx1iwysc1r3rq", "updated": "2024-03-18T14:27:59Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

No.  If $$\det(A-\lambda I) = \det(B - \lambda I)$$, then $$A$$ and $$B$$ will have the same eigenvalues.  

Note that the expression on both sides of this equation is a polynomial.  So it is essentially saying that the two matrices have the same characteristic polynomial.

", "created": "2024-03-18T16:13:49Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltx5b0gafpg6hu", "updated": "2024-03-18T16:13:49Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I think it is true because you use the characteristic equation to solve the eigenvalue(roots of the characteristic equation is eigenvalue) so the same determinant can implies the same characteristic equation, so the same eigenvalue.", "created": "2024-03-18T16:14:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwe9bk4si65f", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltx5bfjnqn05ay", "updated": "2024-03-18T16:14:09Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltx0thnxt3ri4", "updated": "2024-03-18T16:14:09Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltx0pvci8ca2x8", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457304718, "default_anonymity": "no"}

How did you get $$\lambda_1 = \lambda_2 = \lambda_x$$ from

$$\lambda_x(\vec u + \vec v) = \lambda_1 \vec u + \lambda_2 \vec v$$?

I'll offer an intuitive reason why this result is true.

Consider the respective eigenspaces of $$\vec u, \vec v$$. Suppose they are different eigenspaces. Imagine "joining" these eigenspaces together to form a larger subspace. Since eigenspaces are subspaces, this must be closed under addition, hence $$\vec u + \vec v$$, which lives in this "combined" subspace must have the same eigenvalue as that of $$\vec u$$ and $$\vec v$$, if it is an eigenvector.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdweou4p2j4"], "children": [], "id": "ltxa3hpqb1nmo", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "ltx9wb1vqjw6v4", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457312108, "default_anonymity": "no"}
