"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-18T23:02:11Z", "content": "

Yes I believe it is true, you can prove it by expanding along the corresponding row /column with almost all zeroes, I think you will get that the characteristic polynomial is of the form $$(a_1-\lambda)(a_2-\lambda)\dots(a_n-\lambda)$$, so the eigenvalues are the diagonal entries. Here is a picture of what I mean: (red is what you expand along)

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["krvaikp4js87pd", "idt8cfyuv993c4"], "children": [], "id": "ltxjw6lky3v6cw", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Do we have to use the transpose matrix for proving the lower-triangular case? Is row-swaping necessary? Thanks.", "created": "2024-03-19T08:44:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

You don't have to use the transpose for the lower-triangular case but you could. 

You could use row swapping but it's not necessary.    Since there are lots of zeros in a lower triangular case you could just evaluate the determinant directly with a good choice of row/column expansions.

{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 904, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-19T12:36:02Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltycysalant2l0", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-19T12:36:02Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "ltycysaa1wd2kz", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-19T13:21:46Z", "cid": "ltyelm7bsid2go", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "ltyfly89klt3rs", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-03-19T13:50:02Z"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Persevere!", "created": "2024-03-19T13:50:02Z", "content": "

We have now completed more than 3/4 of the course!  Only 8 lectures to go!  Hopefully most of your midterms have passed now.  If you are like me, you may be feeling pretty tired.  I want to give a word of encouragement to everyone to keep going.  I know some of you may be tempted to give up, but I encourage you to persevere.  Keep asking questions.  Keep learning.  Keep on doing your best.  Find things to bring a smile to your face.

 

As you think about preparing for final exams, it’s a good idea have a plan.  Plan out a study schedule.  During midterm season you may have fell behind on some things.  Update your definitions list.  Update your theorems list.  Getting organized now will help a lot later.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Persevere!", "created": "2024-03-19T12:36:02Z", "content": "

As think about preparing for final exams, it’s a good idea have a plan.  Plan out a study schedule.  During midterm season you may have fell behind on some things.  Update your definitions list.  Update your theorems list.  Getting organized now will help a lot later.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa4"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Danielle Alterman", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwb4wzraz68t", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 188, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-20T03:47:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Landon Trinh", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcmng7k212i", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-20T03:47:37Z", "content": "

The definition of a subspace is as follows:

$$V$$ is a subspace if and only if

1. $$0 \in V$$

2. For all $$\vec x, \vec y \in V$$, $$\vec x + \vec y \in V$$

3. For all $$c \in \mathbb R, \vec v \in V$$, $$c \vec v \in V$$

Which means that if $$V$$ is a subspace, then each of 1., 2., and 3. are satisfied.

An equivalent characterization of subspaces are the two criteria (a) and (b) you have posted.

It turns out that a subspace is always a span of some vectors (we will talk about this more later), but this is a useful way to think of subspaces.

I see. Thanks for the clarification.

In that case, why is the equivalent characterization that I posted equivalent - since it doesn't mention anything about the zero vector?

", "created": "2024-03-20T04:00:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Or does the fact that it's non-empty => zero vector?", "created": "2024-03-20T04:02:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "ltza28o7v1t5qb", "updated": "2024-03-20T04:02:30Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

If $$V$$ satisfies (a) and (b), then since $$V$$ is nonempty, let $$\vec v \in V$$. By (b), choosing $$\vec x = \vec v, \vec y = \vec v, c = -1$$, we can see that

$$0 = -\vec v + \vec v = c \vec x + \vec y \in V$$

I'll leave the other condition and the other direction for you to check.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 915, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-21T12:10:23Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lu16xida4ss2zt", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-21T12:10:23Z"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Talk It Out", "created": "2024-03-21T12:10:23Z", "content": "

If you are an external processor like me (someone who processes information by talking about it out loud), then it is really important to have people to talk through your ideas with.\u00a0 When I was a student, I found it really helpful to have a study group.\u00a0 We discussed things that we didn't understand in lectures.\u00a0 We discussed assignment questions (respecting academic integrity).\u00a0 And we talked about our learning.\u00a0 We shared ideas with each other about how we were learning the material.\u00a0 These conversations were really helpful for me.\u00a0\u00a0 It really helped me process the things I was learning and it was really great for my mental health because I was often reminded that I was not alone in the situations I found myself in.\u00a0 In the process we also had fun as we laughed and joked together.\u00a0

\n

\u00a0

\n

I also found it helpful for studying for tests and exams.\u00a0 We would summarize the material together and quiz one another.\u00a0 One option was to name an idea like "rank of a matrix" and then we all shared as much as we could about that idea.\u00a0 Preparing in this way will improve your recall of ideas and it will also help you see more connections between concepts that you didn't see on your own.\u00a0

I'm confused about the following two propositions:

The underlying question is how can a set made from part of the span of a single vector be linearly dependent? I would imagine that in order for a set of vectors to be linearly dependent, there would have to be at least two vectors.

For a) specifically, would {s[1]: |s| < 5} work as a counterexample?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jinwoo Kim", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwadghazy1fl", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 79, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-22T16:30:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Charlie Li", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8w0ryf67pe", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-22T16:30:42Z", "content": "

Here, it is not specified that $$S$$ is a span of vectors.

For instance, $$S$$ could be $$\{(1, 1, 1), (2, 2, 2), (3, 3, 3)\}$$ which is just 3 points.

(a) is linearly dependent because you can choose any scalar in front of the $$0$$ vector, and choose all $$0$$s in front of the others, and you would have a nontrivial linear combination which equals $$0$$

(b) the backwards direction of (b) is given by (a)

For the forward direction, if $$x \neq 0$$, then $$a \vec x = 0$$ iff $$a = 0$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8w0ryf67pe"], "children": [], "id": "lu2vo4s0kuz6qz", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I'm still confused about the difference between points in sets and vectors in sets. In your example with S = {(1, 1, 1), (2, 2, 2), (3, 3, 3)}, is that the same as a set of vectors [1 1 1]^T, [2 2 2]^T, and [3 3 3]^T?", "created": "2024-03-22T16:42:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqw8w0ryf67pe", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Yes, that is the same.", "created": "2024-03-22T16:43:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lu2w3zjhgbp78d", "updated": "2024-03-22T16:43:02Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I see, so a set can have one vector and still be linearly dependent if that vector is a zero vector because there exists solutions to c(zero vector) = 0 for which c is not 0?", "created": "2024-03-22T16:47:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa4"], "nr": 944, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-23T16:50:50Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lu4btvretvr5zy", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-23T16:50:50Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lu4c0q0ptec22m", "to": "lu4btvqyo4y5zw", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-23T16:56:09Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "If A is diagonalizable over F, is A similar to D?", "created": "2024-03-23T16:50:50Z", "content": "

If D = P^-1AP does A = PDP^-1?

\n

Just wanted clarification, sorry if this is an obvious question

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa4"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 131, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-23T16:56:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Oluwafadekemi Odu-onikosi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llnqx80eduxbu", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-23T16:56:09Z", "content": "Yep! No need to apologize :D\u00a0

Let\u2019s start with $$D=P^{-1}AP$$

Multiply the left side by $$P$$:
$$PD = PP^{-1}AP = AP$$

Multiply the right side by $$P^{-1}$$:
$$PDP^{-1}=APP^{-1}= A$$

So we arrive at the other side!
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["llnqx80eduxbu", "krvaikp4js87pd"], "children": [], "id": "lu4c0q0j5rs22l", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lu4btvqyo4y5zw", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457363284, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 945, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-23T17:15:48Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lu4cpzslsz17b2", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-23T17:15:48Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lu4d8qdv9th44w", "to": "lu4cpzsc56s7b1", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-23T17:30:23Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lu4dc58jaxkqy", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-23T17:33:02Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lu4cpzsc56s7b1", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-23T17:33:12Z", "cid": "lu4dccmtztz4jm", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "to": "lu4cpzsc56s7b1", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-23T17:39:39Z", "cid": "lu4dkn8gy5f3yn"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Subspaces", "created": "2024-03-23T17:15:48Z", "content": "I'm a bit confused on the difference between subspaces and spans, can someone clarify?

Thanks!"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 108, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-23T17:30:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Ryan Xiang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdbue9f76p8", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-23T17:33:02Z", "content": "A subspace is an abstract definition of this collection of vectors that:
a) contains $$\\vec 0$$
b) is closed under addition
c) is closed under scalar multiplication
(Definition 8.1.1)\u00a0

We have lots of examples of this, and all of them *happen* to be spans (not a coincidence, I\u2019ll get to that), but subspaces are that specific definition I mentioned above\u00a0

A span is anything of the form Span{$$\\vec v_1, \\ldots , \\vec v_k$$}. It contains all the linear combinations of its spanning set ($$\\vec v_1, \\ldots, \\vec v_k$$). A more concrete way of saying this is that any vector in the span is of the form $$\\vec z = c_1\\vec v_1 + \\ldots + c_k\\vec v_k$$ where $$c_1,\\ldots , c_k \\in \\mathbb{F}$$. That\u2019s what a span is by definition.\u00a0

Turns out, in 8.4 we learn that all subspaces can be represented by spans! Check out Theorem 8.4.1 to see this. Likewise, every span is a subspace, as defined in 8.1.2 part b)

So spans and subspaces are characterized by different definitions, but are essentially the same

Does that help?
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-23T17:30:23Z", "content": "A subspace is an abstract definition of this collection of vectors that:
a) contains $$\\vec 0$$
b) is closed under addition
c) is closed under scalar multiplication
(Definition 8.1.1)\u00a0

We have lots of examples of this, and all of them *happen* to be spans (not a coincidence, I\u2019ll get to that), but subspaces are that specific definition I mentioned above\u00a0

A span is anything of the form Span{$$\\vec v_1, \\ldots , \\vec v_k$$}. It contains all the linear combinations of its spanning set ($$\\vec v_1, \\ldots, \\vec v_k$$). A more concrete way of saying this is that any vector in the span is of the form $$\\vec z = c_1\\vec v_1 + \\ldots + c_k\\vec v_k$$ where $$c_1,\\ldots , c_k \\in \\mathbb{F}$$. That\u2019s what a span is by definition.\u00a0

Turns out, in 8.4 we learn that all subspaces can be represented by spans! Check out Theorem 8.4.1 to see this. Likewise, every span is a subspace, not sure if this is explicitly in the course notes but it seems reasonable enough to prove.\u00a0

So spans and subspaces are characterized by different definitions, but are essentially the same

Does that help?
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdbue9f76p8", "krvaikp4js87pd"], "children": [], "id": "lu4d8qd9cov44v", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Yea that helps a lot, thanks!", "created": "2024-03-23T17:33:12Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Ok great, I\u2019m glad it helped. "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa4"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 208, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-23T21:22:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Karam Hammal", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwbzfpydn4na", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-23T21:22:05Z", "content": "all the vectors in S1 and S2 without u"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwbzfpydn4na"], "children": [], "id": "lu4lipmtaix73y", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-24T00:42:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-24T00:42:35Z", "content": "

The backslash (\setminus) denotes "setminus", which is the operation of removing something from a set.

e.g.

$$\{\text{apple, orange, kiwi, watermelon}\} \setminus \{\text{apple}\} = \{\text{orange, kiwi, watermelon}\}$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["kggoe9bxe5d42u"], "children": [], "id": "lu4sojqo7r533", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lu4ld3mr3ln3av", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457368563, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa4"], "nr": 970, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-24T21:24:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lu6125pjpyc4py", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-24T21:24:53Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lu613fdi63z68", "to": "lu6125pbrw94pw", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-24T21:25:52Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Set is linearly independent iff Matrix is not invertible?", "created": "2024-03-24T21:24:53Z", "content": "Since from Pivots and Linear Independence we have that a set of vectors is linearly independent iff r = rank(A) = k, does this mean that if we have a set of n vectors in F^n, that a criteria for this set being linearly independent is that the nxn matrix made from the vectors in this set is invertible? In other words, is the set of n vectors in F^n linearly independent if and only if the matrix [v1 ... vn] is invertible? I vaguely remember this being discussed in lectures but I don't think it was written down formally.\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa4"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 138, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-24T21:25:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-24T21:25:52Z", "content": "Yes! {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa4"], "nr": 975, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-25T00:37:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lu67xy6wa8v58e", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-25T00:37:34Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lu6800pbnna2ed", "to": "lu67xy6o7c658d", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-25T00:39:11Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lu67xy6o7c658d", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-25T00:46:03Z", "cid": "lu688v9ej9p43k", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "lu67xy6o7c658d", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-25T00:48:26Z", "cid": "lu68bxnocqv1yj"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lu67xy6o7c658d", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-25T00:50:41Z", "cid": "lu68ets3i7fay", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "lu67xy6o7c658d", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-25T00:52:17Z", "cid": "lu68gvwm9qk45r"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Q4 WA4", "created": "2024-03-25T00:37:34Z", "content": "For this question, I am confused about (S1 union S2) \ {u}

Can we write it as the combination of vectors in S1 and S2 then get rid of set u?
"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa4"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 162, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-25T00:39:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-25T00:39:10Z", "content": "

I don't understand your question.

$$(S_1 \cup S_2) \setminus \{\vec u\}$$ denotes the set of vectors $$S_1 \cup S_2$$, with $$\vec u$$ removed. The definition is given in the question:

$$(S_1 \cup S_2) \setminus \{\vec u\} := \{\vec v_1, \ldots, \vec v_k, \vec w_1, \ldots, \vec w_\ell\}$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lu6800p2buw2eb", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "For example 
I wrote 
a0u+ a1v1+…+akvk = 0
b0u +b1w1+…+blwl=0
Add them up we have 
a0u + a1v1 +…+akvk +b0u +b1w1+…+blwl=0
(Consider it as S1 union S2)
Then (S1 union S2) \ {u}
Can be expressed as 
a1v1 +…akvk+ b1w1+…+blwl=0
(Just get rid of vector u)

Is the form correct?
", "created": "2024-03-25T00:46:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

No.

You should get $$a_1\vec v_1 + \cdots + a_k\vec v_k + b_1 \vec w_1 + \cdots + b_\ell \vec w_\ell = -(a_0 + b_0) \vec u$$, right?

", "created": "2024-03-25T00:48:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lu68bxnocqv1yj", "updated": "2024-03-25T00:48:26Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lu688v9ej9p43k", "updated": "2024-03-25T00:51:23Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Yeah, it is true so since we have (S1 union S2)\{u}, then i thought we can just remove all u vectors as it shown above directly, but now it seems wrong", "created": "2024-03-25T00:50:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

To clarify, we don't "have" $$(S_1 \cup S_2) \setminus \{u\}$$. This is a set of vectors, not a hypothesis (i.e. we aren't saying anything about that set).

I'm still not sure what you are asking.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa4"], "nr": 977, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-25T03:04:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lu6d7h9721764i", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-25T03:04:57Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lu6d8ve244yjn", "to": "lu6d7h8x8sz64h", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-25T03:06:02Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lu6d7h8x8sz64h", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-25T18:12:55Z", "cid": "lu79n4ugiox5rj", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "lu6d7h8x8sz64h", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-25T18:16:29Z", "cid": "lu79rq05rn4se"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Showing RREF work", "created": "2024-03-25T03:04:57Z", "content": "At this point in the course for this WA when finding an RREF, do we still need to show the full work (as in in showing what changes we are making each step)"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa4"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 153, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-25T03:06:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Kush Madan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwc7rqqei65o", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-25T03:06:02Z", "content": "You don't have to write out every step, but please don't write "The RREF of this matrix is ...""}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwc7rqqei65o"], "children": [], "id": "lu6d8vduinmjm", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "What do you mean by that? Are we still supposed to show some steps or are you saying there should be a different format?", "created": "2024-03-25T18:12:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

You don't have to put 1 ERO per step, you can merge multiple at a time.\u00a0

\n

\n

In general, if it is easy to see how you row reduced (e.g. if you only made 1 row operation), then it is fine to leave it out. For readability's sake, it is good to see how you got from step A to step B, and if you row reduced 10 different row operations, then you should write them out since your reader will not be able to follow so easily.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["wa4"], "nr": 983, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-25T15:46:06Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lu74ebsxcde9j", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-25T15:46:06Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lu74nj46cl35i0", "to": "lu74ebspfkp9i", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-25T15:53:15Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lu74ebspfkp9i", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-25T16:43:25Z", "cid": "lu76g1mx6vv4iq", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Q4 WA4", "created": "2024-03-25T15:46:06Z", "content": "Since it's been proven in class, can we say without proof that the subset of a matrix is linearly dependent, then its superset is also linearly dependent?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "wa4"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 151, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-25T15:53:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Nicole Anne Go", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdqj252r1jl", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-25T15:53:15Z", "content": "

What do you mean by the subset of a matrix?\u00a0

\n

\n

We proved in class that if a set is linearly dependent, then any superset of that set will be linearly dependent.\u00a0 You can use that fact.\u00a0

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdqj252r1jl"], "children": [], "id": "lu74nj3yucy5hw", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "thanks! i meant to say set", "created": "2024-03-25T16:43:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lu76g1mx6vv4iq", "updated": "2024-03-25T16:46:23Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lu74ebspfkp9i", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457404325, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 988, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-25T19:52:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lu7d6vqz5y3478", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-25T19:52:15Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "lu7daryfalujr", "to": "lu7d6vqrj1f476", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-03-25T19:55:17Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Notation for zero vector in n-dimensional vector space", "created": "2024-03-25T19:52:15Z", "content": "For $$n\\times 1$$ zero vector we can write $$\\mathcal{O}_{n\\times 1}$$, but is it acceptable to represent the same vector as $$\\vec{0}_n$$ (similar to the zero square matrix)?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 72, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-25T19:55:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-25T19:55:17Z", "content": "An instructor will have a more definitive answer for this, but I don\u2019t recall us ever using a subscript to denote the length of a vector. "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["logistics", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xinhao Wang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwelvposqnn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 74, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-26T02:32:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-26T02:32:52Z", "content": "Think about setting a linear combination of them equal to the zero vector and solving for the scalars.\u00a0 In this system of equations, for each variable that is a free variable, the components in the vectors will all be 0 except for in one vector where it will be a 1.\u00a0 Therefore, the linear combination will have to have all 0's as the scalars and so the only solution is the trivial solution.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lu7ri2wk1cx6le", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwelvposqnn"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lu7jcxxyr4l6wq", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457413788, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Greatly appreciated."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 63, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-27T02:58:55Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {"lqzlhgdj56n6xt": 1710434473}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-27T02:58:55Z", "content": "

Vectors are what we choose to make of them. All that vectors are are groups of numbers; it is what we choose to represent with them that matters.

The notation $$\vec x \in \mathbb F^n$$ implies that $$\vec x$$ is written with respect to the standard basis. We directly take the values of $$\vec x$$ to be what they mean. For instance, 

$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 3\end{bmatrix}$$

is simply an object that contains three numbers: $$1, -2, 3$$.

However, if we write

$$[\vec x]_{\mathcal B} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}$$

the vector $$[\vec x]_{\mathcal B}$$ is still the exact same vector; an object which contains three numbers: $$1, -2, 3$$. However, this notation represents something, which is that in the ordered basis $$\mathcal B = \{\vec b_1, \vec b_2, \vec b_3\}$$, we know that

$$\vec x = 1 \vec b_1 - 2 \vec b_2 + 3 \vec b_3$$

The two examples I gave you technically represent the same object, but they convey different meanings.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l6at4v5pzre7le"], "children": [], "id": "lu97vf9surq3e8", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lu9554epnoada", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457419064, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"2024-03-28T05:49:18Z", "content": "Are efficient spanning sets linearly independent?\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 50, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-28T12:46:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Arav Sharma", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ktn8lt6g2yi515", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-28T12:46:23Z", "content": "I'm guessing you got the phrase "efficient spanning set" from me.\u00a0 This isn't a technical linear algebra term with a formal definition.\u00a0 I use it to mean that every vector in the spanning set is needed to maintain the span.\u00a0 If one of the vectors is a linear combination of the others, then we can see informally that anything that vector contributes to the span can be contributed by the other vectors and so that vector is redundant and can be removed from the spanning set and the span of the set won't change.\u00a0 So essentially that means that any spanning set which has vectors in it that can be expressed as linear combinations of other vectors won't be an efficient spanning set.\u00a0\u00a0 So in other words an efficient spanning set won't have any vectors in it that are linear combinations of the others.\u00a0 We do have a theorem about that and it says that such a set is linearly independent.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["ktn8lt6g2yi515"], "children": [], "id": "lub8as0vbrc5qy", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 1009, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-28T15:43:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lubem495wpy2p8", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-28T15:43:10Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lubeo4upr3l1xm", "to": "lubem48sghk2p7", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-28T15:44:44Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Can a coordinate vector be the zero vector?", "created": "2024-03-28T15:43:10Z", "content": ""}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 49, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-28T15:44:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-28T15:44:44Z", "content": "

The zero vector has the same representation in every basis (why is this the case?).

\n

\n

Moreover, it is clear that if $$[\\vec v]_{\\mathcal B} = \\vec 0$$, then $$\\vec v = \\vec 0$$ (using that $$\\mathcal B$$ is linearly independent).

Hello,

In question 1 c) of the recommended problems for the written practice set, the solutions say that

S = {$${{\begin{bmatrix} x_{1}\\ x_{2}\\ x_{3} \\ \end{bmatrix}} \in \mathbb{R}^{3} : |x_{1}| + |x_{2}| - |x_{3}| = 0} $$} is not a subspace and they provide a counterexample.

The counterexample made sense, but I was just curious if there was a way to prove that the set doesn't have closure using general variables, instead of a counterexample (i.e. cx + y), similar to what was done in part a)? If so, could someone explain what that might look like for this example?

Thanks!

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Recommended Problems 1.c", "created": "2024-03-30T16:10:27Z", "content": "

In general, there is nothing wrong with a proof by counterexample (this is just good of a proof as any other proof). It demonstrates that something cannot be true because it does not account for this specific case.

However, perhaps you are wondering how they come up with certain counterexamples. For this one, the best way to work out a counterexample is just to try various numbers, or to think about this geometrically. The set $$S$$ in questions concerns all vectors in $$\mathbb R^3$$ which have the sum of magnitudes of the first two coordinates equal to the magnitude of the third coordinate.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luebmft89kd7bj", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lueagwri7ch2p9", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457440349, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 1018, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-30T17:54:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luee6yz7stb4iu", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-30T17:54:42Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "luef3jnf35v7di", "to": "luee6yyzi2o4is", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-30T18:20:02Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luee6yyzi2o4is", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-30T18:27:05Z", "cid": "luefcm5hduw5bx", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luee6yyzi2o4is", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-30T18:44:01Z", "cid": "luefyebq51b6y9", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Take-home practice problem Lecture 28", "created": "2024-03-30T17:54:42Z", "content": "

Find the basis for the subspace of $$\mathbb{R}^3$$

$$V = \left\{ \begin{bmatrix}x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \end{bmatrix} \right\}\in\mathbb{R}^3: x_1+x_2-x_3=0$$

The solution was:

$$\left\{\begin{bmatrix}1 \\ 0 \\ 1\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}0 \\ 1 \\ 1\end{bmatrix}\right\}$$ is a basis V


I'm a little lost why the basis solution does not have 3 vectors in it. Doesn't the number of elements in a basis for a subspace have to have n vectors (n = 3 in this case)?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 52, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-30T18:20:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-30T18:20:02Z", "content": "

Subspaces do not necessarily have the same dimension. In this case, $$V$$ happens to be lower in dimension than $$\mathbb R^3$$. Some other cases in which this happen are:

- The zero subspace (i.e. $$\{\vec 0\}$$) which has dimension $$0$$

- Lines through the origin (e.g. $$\{s \vec x_1 : s \in \mathbb R\}$$ for $$x_1 \neq 0$$) which have a dimension of $$1$$

- Planes through the origin (e.g. $$\{s \vec x_1 + t \vec x_2 : s, t \in \mathbb R\}$$ for $$\{x_1, x_2\}$$ linearly independent) which have a dimension of $$2$$

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luef3jn71v17df", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "So subspaces are the exception to proposition 8.5.3 for size of a basis for $$\mathbb{F}^n$$?", "created": "2024-03-30T18:27:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Or is it because the subspace does not span all of $$\mathbb{R}^3$$", "created": "2024-03-30T18:44:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["krvaikp4js87pd"], "id": "luefyebq51b6y9", "updated": "2024-03-30T18:57:13Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luefcm5hduw5bx", "updated": "2024-03-30T18:57:16Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luee6yyzi2o4is", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457441408, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week10"], "nr": 1020, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-30T19:36:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luehu55etr72xb", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-30T19:36:42Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lueil6g6wdt77f", "to": "luehu5558so2xa", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-30T19:57:43Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "week 10 practice problem Q7", "created": "2024-03-30T19:36:42Z", "content": "

can someone explain this? I cannot understand well.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week10", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 75, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-30T19:57:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Taehyeon Kim", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwehero027lg", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-30T19:57:43Z", "content": "

The matrix

$$A = \begin{bmatrix} \vec v \mid \vec e_1 \mid \cdots \mid \vec e_n\end{bmatrix}$$

is $$n \times (n + 1)$$. Since it contains the standard basis, its columns pace spans $$\mathbb F^n$$, so it must have rank $$n$$. This means that in its RREF, there are $$n$$ pivots, of which the first column must have one (because $$\vec v \neq \vec 0$$).

Then, take the submatrix of $$A$$ (note: $$A$$, not $$\text{RREF}(A)$$) by taking the $$n$$ columns which have pivots in them. This matrix is $$n \times n$$, and must be invertible because in its RREF, there is a pivot in each column.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehero027lg"], "children": [], "id": "lueil6fztoa77d", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luehu5558so2xa", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457443528, "default_anonymity": "no"}

For part a) of this question, the answer key claimed that Null(A) has no basis. But I thought Null(A) is a subspace and by Every subspace has a basis, it should have some sort of basis.

This is WP10 Q8 btw

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 74, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-30T21:50:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yilin", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwam6q3i52z9", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-30T21:50:00Z", "content": "

You are right that the nullspace of every matrix is a subspace, and every nontrivial subspace (i.e. $$V \neq \{\vec 0\}$$) has a basis.

By convention, we take the emptyset $$\emptyset$$ to be a basis for the trivial subspace $$\{\vec 0\}$$. You can see the note under 8.2.6 for further reference.

For EP10 Q5b, I'm confused by this solution because I don't get how e_i = [v_i]_B

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-31T00:04:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yilin", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwam6q3i52z9", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-31T00:04:33Z", "content": "

Write out $$[\vec v_i]_{\mathcal B}$$.

We want to express $$\vec v_i$$ as a linear combination of the vectors in $$\mathcal B = \{\vec v_1, \ldots, \vec v_n\}$$, so we need to find $$c_1, c_2, \ldots, c_n$$ so that

$$\vec v_i = c_1 \vec v_1 + \cdots + c_n \vec v_n$$

Of course, we can take

$$c_j = \begin{cases} 0, &i \neq j \\ 1 & i = j\end{cases}$$

and these exactly are the coordinates that make $$\vec e_i$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q5"], "nr": 1030, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-31T16:12:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lufpysvxjco1bh", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-31T16:12:02Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lufrgfnq6fq76j", "to": "lufpysv5htw1bf", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-31T16:53:45Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lufpysv5htw1bf", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-03-31T23:30:22Z", "cid": "lug5mhj42han", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "lufpysv5htw1bf", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-31T23:31:47Z", "cid": "lug5obkwm8u3hh"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lufpysv5htw1bf", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-03-31T23:39:22Z", "cid": "lug5y2owfl07dh", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "EP10 Q10", "created": "2024-03-31T16:12:02Z", "content": "

I'm confused how this statement is correct because aren't subspaces a set of vectors and for a set of vectors to equal F^n we need more than n vectors? I thought it's only the span(V) that spans all F^n if V has n independent vectors.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 70, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-31T16:53:45Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-31T16:53:45Z", "content": "

I'm not sure exactly what you are asking.

A nontrivial subspace will contain an infinite number of vectors (since it is closed under scalar multiplication, you can scale any nonzero element by any real or complex number).

However, if $$V \subseteq \mathbb F^n$$ is a subspace, then $$V$$ is spanned by at most $$n$$ linearly independent vectors (as otherwise, if $$V$$ contains $$n + 1$$ or more linearly independent vectors, then $$\mathbb F^n$$ must also contain $$n + 1$$ linearly independent vectors, which means a basis for $$\mathbb F^n$$ must contain more than $$n$$ vectors).

Does this answer your question?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q5"], "nr": 1031, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-31T17:31:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "data": "lufsssjobcu48c", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-03-31T17:31:21Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "luftdm309ub6pf", "to": "lufsssjdjf48a", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-03-31T17:47:32Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "luftehwnn9pbw", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-03-31T17:48:13Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "subject": "R^2 subspace of R^3?", "created": "2024-03-31T17:31:21Z", "content": "

can I say {[0,0]^T} is a subspace in R^3? Will the dimension of a subset for determining its subspace?

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 56, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-31T17:47:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-31T17:48:13Z", "content": "

$$\left\{\begin{bmatrix}0\\0\end{bmatrix}\right\}$$ is not even a subset of $$\mathbb{R}^3$$, so it cannot be a subspace of $$\mathbb{R}^3$$.

We don't say "dimension of a subset". Dimension is defined to describe a (sub)space, which is the cardinality of a smallest spanning set (i.e. basis).

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-31T17:47:32Z", "content": "

$$\left\{\begin{bmatrix}0\\0\end{bmatrix}\right\}$$ is not even a subset of $$\mathbb{R}^3$$, so it cannot be a subspace of $$\mathbb{R}^3$$.

We don't say "dimension of a subset". Dimension is defined to describe a (sub)space, which is the cardinarlity of a smallest spanning set (i.e. basis).

Here is another way to think about it.

Suppose you want to find a basis $$\mathcal B$$ for $$\mathbb F^n$$.

Put the vectors in $$\mathcal B$$ into a matrix $$A$$. Our goal is to show that $$A$$ has at least $$n$$ columns.

Since $$\mathcal B$$ must be spanning, we must have $$\text{Col}(A) = \mathbb F^n$$, so this implies that $$n = \dim(\mathbb F^n) = \dim(\text{Col}(A)) = \text{Rank}(A)$$ (using 8.7.8).

Then, using the rank bound, we know that $$A$$ has at least $$n$$ columns.

Why is a set of $$n$$-linearly independent vectors of $$\mathbb{F}^n$$ a basis for $$\mathbb{F}^n$$?

You can prove this by definition. In order for it be a basis for $$\mathbb{F}^n$$, the set needs to be (1) linearly independent, (2) sufficient to span $$\mathbb{F}^n$$. In the posted answer, we have (1). It remains proving (2). 

Now, you assign coefficients $$c_1, c_2, \dots, c_n$$ to these linearly independent vectors, say $$\vec{v_1}, \vec{v_2}, \dots, \vec{v_n}$$ and look at the equation

           $$ c_1 \vec{v_1} + c_2\vec{v_2} + \cdots + c_n\vec{v_n} = \vec{b}$$.

Does this equation always have a solution for arbitrary $$\vec{b}$$ (i.e. $$\vec{v_1},\dots, \vec{v_n}$$ can linearly express all $$\vec{b}\in \mathbb{F}^n$$ and hence spans $$\mathbb{F}^n$$)? Check the coefficient matrix $$A=[\vec{v_1} \ \cdots \vec{v_n}]$$ (and count pivots). The conclusion follows from Invertibility Criteria.

I'm not sure if I'm making an assumption here that I can't make."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 60, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-03-31T20:09:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-03-31T20:09:36Z", "content": "

We don't have "dimension of a basis". Dimension is defined for a (sub)space. 

>>for a spanning set to be a basis it has to have n vectors?

A basis for what space? If a set $$\mathcal{B}$$ spans $$\mathbb{F}^n$$ then $$\mathcal{B}$$ contains at least $$n$$ vectors. (why?) If $$\mathcal{B}$$ is also a basis for $$\mathbb{F}^n$$ then $$\mathcal{B}$$ contains exactly $$n$$ vectors. (why?)

Two $$4$$-dimensional subspaces of $$\mathbb{F}^{7}$$ may not be the same, but two $$7$$-dimensional subspaces of $$\mathbb{F}^7$$ must be the same. (why?)

I think that it helps to think about dimension intuitively, If you are only given one vector to work with, you can "access" a one dimensional space e.g a line. Adding another linearly independent vector "unlocks" a new dimension, and you can now access a plane. $$\mathbb{R}^4$$ takes 4 vectors since it is 4 dimensional - you need 4 independent vectors to get everywhere. This also makes it clear that any subspace in $$\mathbb{R}^4$$ has a dimension less or equal to 4, since its obvious that it cant be a higher dimension. Also, we can see that when $$B$$ spans $$\mathbb{F}^n$$, then $$B$$ needs $$n$$ vectors, since $$B$$ is intuitively "$$n$$ dimensional".

$$S$$ in the above example does not span $$\mathbb{R}^4$$, since for instance, you could not reach $$[0~1~0~0]^T$$ (Since we are only given one vector, $$\vec{e}_1$$ in the span, any element in $$S$$ is a multiple of $$\vec{e}_1$$, and therefore must have $$0$$ as their 2nd, 3rd, and 4th component). $$S$$ is a line in $$\mathbb{R}^4$$ which is one dimensional, so the basis has one vector

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week9", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 63, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-01T00:53:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Tuan Anh Nguyen Pham", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwedxqjbh6yr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T00:59:34Z", "content": "

You cant just combine the two equations into one - you lose information by doing that.

For instance, suppose we have the equations,

$$x_1+x_2 = 0$$, and 

$$x_3+x_4 = 0$$

This is not the same as $$x_1+x_2=x_3+x_4\iff x_1+x_2-x_3-x_4=0$$. Note that if we took $$x_1=x_2=x_3=x_4=1$$, this would satisfy this equation, but not our original. We are "losing" information, since now we are only enforcing that $$x_1+x_2$$ and $$x_3+x_4$$ are equal to each other, when originally they need to be equal to each other, and also equal to 0.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T00:54:07Z", "content": "

Or should we write out each ERO?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 86, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-01T16:05:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "David Sun", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697911870, "llazq0fual03ej": 1701957412, "ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1702076911, "global": 1711048172}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwatvoglc4bh", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T16:05:28Z", "content": "I think you should show your steps.\u00a0 But in the example you gave above you could simply say that the matrix is invertible and therefore, it's RREF is the identity matrix.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwatvoglc4bh"], "children": [], "id": "luh567ke30e1ea", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luh2u6ouyyt1zu", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457474377, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week10"], "nr": 1053, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-01T16:53:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luh6vjadv1j4na", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-01T16:53:10Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "data": "luh7kmeuoqd2q2", "to": "luh6vja6ep24n9", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-01T17:12:40Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WPP 10 Q8 (C)", "created": "2024-04-01T16:53:10Z", "content": "

when finding the basis for Col(A), the rank of the matrix is 2 which is not equal to 3, so that means the set is linearly independent, so how can it have a basis?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week10", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 62, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-01T17:12:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T17:12:40Z", "content": "

>>the rank of the matrix is 2 which is not equal to 3, so that means the set is linearly independent

You meant the three columns are linearly dependent?

Here, you are asked to find basis for the span

$$\mathrm{Span}\left\{ \begin{bmatrix}1\\-1\\1 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}2\\-2\\3 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix}0\\0\\-1 \end{bmatrix} \right\}$$. Every span is a subspace hence has a basis. In this case, the basis cannot be formed by all three vectors as they are linearly dependent,  but how about two vectors or one vector?

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luh7kmelps32pz", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luh6vja6ep24n9", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457478576, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week9", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-01T17:21:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Landon Trinh", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcmng7k212i", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T17:21:36Z", "content": "

This question is a bit subtle. One should be careful about what whole space is given. Here, you are checking subspace of "$$\\mathbb{R}^3$$"! This means the scalar multiplication inherits from that of $$\\mathbb{R}^3$$, which is $$\\mathbb{R}$$.

\n

The set $$V$$ is defined in $$\\mathbb{Q}$$, so scalar multiples like $$\\sqrt{2} \\begin{bmatrix}x_1\\\\x_2\\\\x_3 \\end{bmatrix}$$ are not in $$V$$. (not closed)

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwcmng7k212i"], "children": [], "id": "luh7w44m7oo35m", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I see. Isn't the rational set a subset of the real set?", "created": "2024-04-01T17:33:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "To be in $$V$$, the components of the vector must be rational.\u00a0 The scalars when checking closure under scalar multiplication are real numbers so you may end up with real numbers which are not rational and therefore, they won't be in $$V$$.", "created": "2024-04-01T17:57:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Landon Trinh", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcmng7k212i", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwcmng7k212i"], "id": "luh95u1pfcy3p", "updated": "2024-04-01T18:36:16Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luh8bcqd3hm53m", "updated": "2024-04-01T18:36:14Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luh7n4jfhzc4eb", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457480687, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 64, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-01T17:44:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T20:04:50Z", "content": "No, because lines and planes that do not go through the origin are not subspaces.  (They do not contain the zero vector.)"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T17:44:31Z", "content": "No, because lines and planes through the origin are not subspaces.  (They do not contain the zero vector.)"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luh8pktodh764y", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "You mean that don’t go through the origin right? (Speaking to Professor Bauman)", "created": "2024-04-01T19:21:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Yes, I believe he meant to write lines and planes NOT through the origin are not subspaces.

We call those sets affine subspaces, if they are a translation of a subspace (i.e. you add a constant vector $$\vec v$$ to every vector in your subspace).

", "created": "2024-04-01T19:22:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4"], "id": "luhc7pu98062hz", "updated": "2024-04-01T20:04:53Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "So they come from a subspace that did have the zero vector but now no longer does because there was a vector-scaled transformation applied to it?", "created": "2024-04-01T19:24:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luhcahs0w7l1c6", "updated": "2024-04-01T19:24:46Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Yes.

(please note that this content about affine subspaces is not part of this course, and I'm just mentioning it as an aside).

An affine subspace $$W \subseteq \mathbb F^n$$ satisfies $$W = \{\vec w + \vec v : \vec w \in V\}$$ for some vector $$\vec v$$, and subspace $$V \subseteq \mathbb F^n$$. Some examples of affine subspaces are lines and planes which may or may not pass through the origin.

Note that if we take $$\vec v = \vec 0$$, we end up with $$W = V$$, so every subspace is also an affine subspace.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week10"], "nr": 1066, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-01T22:31:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luhiybpth426ie", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-01T22:31:15Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "data": "luhjd1wieiw78", "to": "luhiybpgo7z6id", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-01T22:42:42Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "data": "luhjlcl6pt12u0", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-04-01T22:49:09Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "luhs459fpdvet", "to": "luhiybpgo7z6id", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-02T02:47:43Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "A Problem about Dimension of Subspaces", "created": "2024-04-01T22:31:15Z", "content": "

Hello! I was trying to figure out how can we give a formal proof to the following statement.

If $$V$$ and $$W$$ are subspaces of $$\mathbb{F}^n$$ such that $$W \subseteq V$$, then $$\dim{(W)} \leq \dim{(V)}$$.

Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week10", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 72, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-01T22:42:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xing Liu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcf5nkeh7gy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T22:49:09Z", "content": "Here is a rough idea, Consider the basis of W, and suppose for a contradiction that dim(W)>dim(V). But since W is a subset of V, we can express each vector in the basis for W in terms of vectors in the basis of V (but there are less vectors in V than W)."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-01T22:42:42Z", "content": "Here is a rough idea, Consider the basis of W, and suppose for a contradiction that dim(W)>dim(V). But since W is a subset of V, we can express each vector in the basis for W in terms of vectors of V (but there are less vectors in V than W)."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwcf5nkeh7gy"], "children": [], "id": "luhjd1w4zn875", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-02T02:47:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-02T02:47:43Z", "content": "Consider a basis for $$W$$.  Every vector in $$W$$ is also in $$V$$ and so we have a linearly independent set in $$V$$ (since a basis for $$W$$ is linearly independent).  Now think about growing this set into a basis for $$V$$. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luhs459bq77es", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luhiybpgo7z6id", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457492287, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 1068, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-02T01:42:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwcfhf3hp7j6", "data": "luhprp955ad32", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-02T01:42:03Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "luifk28pz94f9", "to": "luhprp8xi132z", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-02T13:43:57Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwcfhf3hp7j6", "to": "luhprp8xi132z", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-02T14:00:27Z", "cid": "luig5a6fhgk5np"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "hbsg02xli8p54o", "to": "luhprp8xi132z", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-02T15:48:44Z", "cid": "luik0j60s1w62a"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwcfhf3hp7j6", "to": "luhprp8xi132z", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-03T01:20:13Z", "cid": "luj4fgh2b722m6"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "luhprp8xi132z", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-03T16:57:39Z", "cid": "luk1x067j6t7oh"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwcfhf3hp7j6", "to": "luhprp8xi132z", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-04T01:19:37Z", "cid": "lukjujztvmi6qf"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwcfhf3hp7j6", "subject": "Some general questions", "created": "2024-04-02T01:42:03Z", "content": "Hi sorry to bother, can I get some insights into these questions that I have? 1. We know that the inner product corresponds to the work done (energy) in physics, which is conserved in any coordinate/reference systems by relativity. So I naturally thought the inner product should be the same in different coordinate systems. But obviously, it has different values with respect to different bases. Is it because every time we change the bases, we also have to multiply by something (the Gram matrix) in order to get the same value for inner products? 2. How to derive the rank-nullity theorem for an infinite dimensional vector space? I've heard that it's V/Ker f = Im f, but I don't know how to derive it. Does it have any relationships with the finite-dimensional one? 3. What are some uses of complex eigenpairs, perhaps in physics? I suppose it's not only scaling the vectors but also rotating them at the same time, since it's being multiplied by ki (rotation by pi/2). 4. Why are we interested in singular matrices? I thought matrices that don't have inverses are somewhat less interesting. 5. What is the intuition behind the Jordan Canonical Form, and how does it simplify the understanding of linear operators? Thanks in advance."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 112, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-02T13:43:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-02T13:43:57Z", "content": "

These are some pretty big questions and a lot of them are beyond the scope of the course.  I might suggest that you ask some of the questions to your instructor in office hours because it would take quite a lot of work to type out answers here on Piazza.  I don't want to discourage your questions, but I think you might get better answers this way. 

Maybe some of the other instructors will respond below. 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luifk28ipmh4f8", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Thanks Professor Bauman, I’m pretty sick these days because of the weather 🥺 and can’t attend office hours so I just asked the questions that I’ve been pondering on piazza. Any discussions are welcome.

", "created": "2024-04-02T14:00:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwcfhf3hp7j6", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I can answer a couple of these:

2. What you have stated is the first isomorphism theorem for vector spaces. Once you have an understanding of cosets of $$W$$ in $$V$$, you can read about quotient vector spaces. Then, you can read up on the first isomorphism theorem for vector spaces.

4. Homogeneous systems $$Ax=0$$ have come up countless times in our course, in a variety of different contexts. Only singular matrices have interesting nullspaces.  

5. The intuition behind JCF is that not all matrices are diagonalizable over $$\mathbb{C}$$, but all complex matrices are similar to an upper triangular matrix which is "almost diagonal". 

Coincidentally, MATH 245 is the course you should take to properly learn about the things you are asking about.

What are some examples of "interesting nullspaces"? 5. Is the arrowhead matrix the "almost diagonal" matrix?", "created": "2024-04-03T01:20:13Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwcfhf3hp7j6", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luj4fgh2b722m6", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-04-03T01:20:13Z", "config": {"editor": "md"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "4. For example, in optimization, it is common to look at the orthogonal complement of sets. This is defined to be $$V^\perp = \{\vec w \in \mathbb R^n : \vec v^\top \vec w = 0, \forall \vec v \in V\}$$. This is to say that $$V^\perp$$ is the set of all things which are orthogonal to everything in $$V$$. It turns out that for linear operators, $$\text{Null}(A) = \text{Ran}(A^\top)^\perp$$ (note: this holds for nonsquare matrices too) This idea is what makes up a large part of Farkas's Lemma (and the similar variant such as Gordon's Lemma, Stiemke's Lemma, and Theorem of the Alternative), and is an idea that is commonly used in optimization. If $$\text{Null}(A) = \{\vec 0\}$$, then this fact is not very useful because you already know so much about $$\text{Null}(A)$$ and $$\text{Ran}(A^\top)$$. If you are interested in this type of content, you should take a look at taking CO250 or CO255. 5. The "almost diagonal" matrix that Blake is referring to is called the Jordan Normal Form $$J$$ of a matrix, which is block diagonal: $$J = \begin{bmatrix} B_1 & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & B_2 & \cdots & 0 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & \cdots & B_k \end{bmatrix}$$ where each $$B_1$$ is a square matrix. A most useful application of Jordan Forms arises whenever you want to exponentiate a matrix. You can check that for all positive integers $$m$$, $$J^m = \begin{bmatrix} B_1^m & 0 & \cdots & 0 \\ 0 & B_2^m & \cdots & 0 \\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ 0 & 0 & \cdots & B_k^m \end{bmatrix}$$ which is computationally much easier to do. One instance in which we actually used the Jordan form was in Math 249 (Intro to Combinatorics) when we studied a way of representing recurrence relations as a matrix-vector product. Then, to find the next numbers in that recurrence, we needed to exponentiate a matrix, which is where the Jordan Form came in. If you are interested in this content, you should take MATH 245, which (to the best of my knowledge) is the only undergraduate course offered which covers the Jordan Form.", "created": "2024-04-03T16:57:39Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luk1x067j6t7oh", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-04-03T16:57:39Z", "config": {"editor": "md"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "That makes sense, thanks Frank!", "created": "2024-04-04T01:19:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwcfhf3hp7j6", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lukjujztvmi6qf", "updated": "2024-04-04T01:19:37Z", "config": {}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luig5a6fhgk5np", "updated": "2024-04-04T01:19:37Z", "config": {}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luhprp8xi132z", "config": {"editor": "md", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457494402, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I'm not sure whether the below statements are valid.

Let $$S = \{ \vec{v}_1, \ldots, \vec{v}_k \}$$ be a set of $$k$$ vectors in $$\mathbb{F}^n$$. Let $$A = \begin{bmatrix} \vec{v}_1 & \cdots & \vec{v}_k \end{bmatrix}$$ be the $$n \times k$$ matrix whose columns are the vectors in $$S$$. Then, the following statements are equivalent to $$A$$ is invertible.

  • $$\operatorname{rank}{(A) = n}$$, where $$n$$ is the number of rows
  • $$\operatorname{Span}{(S)} = \mathbb{F}^n$$
  • $$S$$ (or the columns of $$A$$) are linearly independent

Since $$A$$ is $$n \times n$$ we have that $$k=n$$.  But other than that it looks good.

$$(A^{-1})^T A^T = (A A^{-1})^T = I^T = I$$.

Thus, $$A^T$$ has the inverse $$(A^{-1})^T$$.
