I recommend focusing on material covered since the midterm (but don't totally ignore pre-midterm material since it is the foundation.)  Do as many of the practice problems as you can.  

Be careful not to over focus on one of the weeks and run out of time.  Maybe start by doing 5 warm-up problems and 5 recommended problems from each week and once you have finished that go back and do 5 more from each week.   This has the advantage of not doing all questions on one topic but rather switching from topic to topic which is what will happen on the exam. 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqweg7lidj7dl", "lkqwclm3shhvy"], "children": [], "id": "luik46c468970a", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Hello, just a follow-up. Do you think it is worth going through every single proof in the course notes to prepare for the final exam?", "created": "2024-04-02T18:03:06Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

We won't ask to reprove any theorems that are given in the textbook.  That being said, you may get some proof ideas from these proofs that may be useful in proving other things.  Also understanding the proof of a statement sometimes gives you a deeper understanding of the statement. 

However, I would focus on doing the practice problems and if you have time left over then you can working through all of the proofs in the textbook.

", "created": "2024-04-04T22:35:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Think about what the eigenvectors of the reflection should be.

Any vector on the plane should stay the same, and a vector that is exactly perpendicular to the plane should be negative of itself.

Thus, if we pick two vectors $$\vec v_1, \vec v_2$$ which form a basis for the plane, then we should expect $$\text{refl}_{\vec n}(\vec v_1) = \vec v_1$$, and $$\text{refl}_{\vec n}(\vec v_2)$$ and $$\text{refl}_{\vec n}(\vec n) = -\vec n$$, so these are our 3 eigenvectors.

From here, do you see why $$[\text{refl}_{\vec n}]_{\mathcal B}$$ is diagonal with those values?

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 1094, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-04T13:17:33Z", "bucket_order": 0, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lul9htc3n1n7n0", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-04T13:17:33Z"}], "bucket_name": "Pinned", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "Abstraction", "created": "2024-04-04T13:17:33Z", "content": "

For most of the course so far, we have worked with vectors and matrices, which are in themselves abstract objects, but in many situations we can think of think of these objects as representing something physical.  We can carry out the operations we have defined on them easily.

 

In Chapter 10 we will look at vectors spaces which takes abstraction to the next level.  (Since this topic is not covered on the final exam your instructor may or may not talk about this material.)  For a vector space we have a set of objects, a set of scalars and two operations.  One of these operations combines two objects from the set in some way.  And the other operation combines a scalar and an object from the set in some way.  These objects could be all kinds of things and the operations can be defined in wacky ways.  However, if we know that what we are dealing with is a vector space, then we know that these objects with these operations satisfy closure under addition and scalar multiplication along with the 8 axioms of a vector space. 

 

Using the axioms of a vector space we can prove some properties that apply to all vector spaces.  For example, $$0 \bigodot \vec{x} = \vec{0}$$, $$a \bigodot \vec{0} = \vec{0}$$ and $$- \vec{x} = (-1) \bigodot \vec{x}$$.  Provided we have a vector space, these properties will hold regardless of what the actual objects are or what the actual operations are. 

 

To think like mathematicians, we need to question whether other properties we know about vectors still hold true in general for abstract vector spaces.  We can work with known concepts like linear independence, spanning and basis and see if they apply to all vector spaces.

 

This level of abstraction will be exciting for some, but I know that it will be painful for others.  For those of you who get excited, the land of pure math awaits.   And for those of you who find it painful and pointless, there's always computer science.  (Just kidding of course, CS has its own abstraction challenges!).

"}], "type": "note", "tags": ["instructor-note", "pin", "tips"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Yichen Gao", "endorser": {"lqzlhgdj56n6xt": 1710434473}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l6at4v5pzre7le", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Nadeen Findakly", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1699541637}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwd85z5pt61k", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Yassa Taiseer", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqweeqkowg746", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 157, "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["l6at4v5pzre7le", "lkqwd85z5pt61k", "lkqweeqkowg746"], "id": "lul9htbuanx7mz", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 2, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457521999, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I was wondering whats the process of getting those vectors

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week11", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {"lr5ecl50k5u23j": 1711835446}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 73, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-05T02:18:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-05T02:18:09Z", "content": "They are a basis of eigenvectors.  Remember that an eigenvector of a linear transformation $$T$$ is a vector $$\vec{x}$$ such that $$T(\vec{x})= \lambda \vec{x}$$.  So we can use our geometrical knowledge of the transformation to choose eigenvectors which are linearly independent. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lum1dob412j5mn", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwec73jwh6mz"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luly7l1j9s05ua", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457530458, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["q5"], "nr": 1103, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-05T04:47:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "data": "lum6ppmojx3599", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-05T04:47:29Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "data": "lum7av1u6667b4", "to": "lum6ppmf4bl598", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-05T05:03:56Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "data": "lum7bs8zqz611p", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-04-05T05:04:39Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "data": "lum7dpy5i3h40l", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-04-05T05:06:09Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "subject": "quiz 5 mc d", "created": "2024-04-05T04:47:29Z", "content": "How can this be true? Consider $$V= \\{[1,0]^T,[0,1]^T\\} \\in R^2$$. $$dim(V) = 2$$ However, $$\\{[1,0]^T,[0,1]^T\\} \\neq R^2$$. Only $$span\\{[1,0]^T,[0,1]^T\\} = R^2$$."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 56, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-05T05:03:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xinhao Wang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwelvposqnn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-05T05:06:09Z", "content": "

I think you have gotten subspaces and bases mixed up, $$V$$ is a subspace, $$\\{[1~0]^T,[0~1]^T\\}$$ is the base for the subspace, so it is true that $$V=\\mathbb{R}^2$$ since $$V$$ is the span of its base,

\n

\n

$$\\dim(V)=2$$ means that the base of $$V$$ has two vectors in it, not that $$V$$ has two vectors in it ($$V$$ would have infinitely many vectors in this case)

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-05T05:04:39Z", "content": "I think you have gotten subspaces and bases mixed up, $$V$$ is a subspace, $$\\{[1~0]^T,[0~1]^T\\}$$ is the base for the subspace, so it is true that $$V=\\mathbb{R}^2$$ since $$V$$ is the span of its base"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-05T05:03:56Z", "content": "I think you have gotten subspaces and bases mixed up, $$V$$ is a subspace, $$\\{[1~0]^T,[0~1]^T\\}$$ is the base for the subspace, so it is true that $$V=\\mathbb{R}^2$$ since $$V$$ is indeed the span of the base"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwelvposqnn", "krvaikp4js87pd"], "children": [], "id": "lum7av1mxg97b3", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lum6ppmf4bl598", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457531517, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week10"], "nr": 1105, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-05T14:54:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 1, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lumse4uf97n6w1", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-05T14:54:20Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lumt2271iu97pd", "to": "lumse4u8y506w0", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-05T15:12:57Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lumse4u8y506w0", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-09T15:55:53Z", "cid": "luskcoixkl6zt", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "PP10 Q10", "created": "2024-04-05T14:54:20Z", "content": "Can someone please explain how using the super augmented matrix gives C[I]B?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week10", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {"lr5ecl50k5u23j": 1711835446}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 65, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-05T15:12:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Matthew WenYue Liu", "endorser": {"ll8neyb2eq31eo": 1695658850, "global": 1701470489, "lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1702143473, "lqzes2lznxt50s": 1707071031, "lr148a6jm3j40f": 1709849396, "lr5ecl50k5u23j": 1711029429}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-05T15:12:56Z", "content": "<md>Suppose you have two $$n \times n$$ matrices $$A, B$$, and you are looking at the super augmented matrix $$[A \mid B]$$.

Suppose $$B = [B_1 \mid \cdots \mid B_n]$$ where $$B_i \in \mathbb F^n$$ for each $$1 \le i \le n$$.

Then, the super augmented matrix can equivalently be written as $$n$$ systems of equations:

$$[A \mid B_1], [A \mid B_2], \ldots, [A\mid B_n]$$

Putting them together into the super augmented matrix is simply a way to solve all of these systems at the same time.

For this problem, we are trying to determine $$\vphantom{}_{\mathcal C}[\mathcal I]_{\mathcal B} = \begin{bmatrix} [\vec v_1]_{\mathcal w} & [\vec v_2]_{\mathcal w}\end{bmatrix}$$

We know that $$\underbrace{[\vec w_1 \mid \vec w_2]}_{\in M_{2 \times 2}(\mathbb R)}[\vec v_1]_{\mathcal w} = \vec v_1$$, so we can take $$A = [\vec w_1 \mid \vec w_2]$$, and put all of the columns of $$B$$ as the basis vectors in $$\mathcal B$$.</md>"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdweou4p2j4"], "children": [], "id": "lumt226iz107pc", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Could someone explain a little further? How can you have a coordinate vector $$[v1]_w$$ ? {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week11"], "nr": 1111, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-06T15:12:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luo8htxaght69g", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-06T15:12:53Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "luob714kges3g3", "to": "luo8htx2l7o69f", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-06T16:28:28Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luo8htx2l7o69f", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-06T16:58:11Z", "cid": "luoc99ipi8e7ai", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "luof30h5b4p7mx", "type": "i_answer_update", "when": "2024-04-06T18:17:19Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luo8htx2l7o69f", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-09T16:32:18Z", "cid": "luslnj16m0d3q", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WP11 Q2", "created": "2024-04-06T15:12:53Z", "content": "

I wonder how we can get the algebraic multiplicity is 2. Thanks.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week11", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-06T16:28:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Li Xuanhe", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwej5x9pg6c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-06T18:17:19Z", "content": "The algebraic multiplicity of an eigenvalue $$\lambda$$ is the degree of $$\lambda$$ as a root in the characteristic polynomial.

This characteristic polynomial is $$C_A(x) = (\lambda - x)^2$$, so the algebraic multiplicity of $$\lambda$$ is 2.
"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-06T16:28:28Z", "content": "The algebraic multiplicity of an eigenvalue $$\lambda$$ is the degree of $$\lambda$$ as a root in the characteristic polynomial.

This characteristic polynomial is $$C_A(\lambda) = (\lambda - \mu)^2$$, so the algebraic multiplicity of $$\mu$$ is 2.
"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwej5x9pg6c"], "children": [], "id": "luob714c5z03g2", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

But the characteristic polynomial should be 0*0 - 0*\mu  

", "created": "2024-04-06T16:58:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Oscar Liu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwd1pdujw4wz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Li Xuanhe", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwej5x9pg6c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sa'ad Farooq", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdmtccazxn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sylvia Niu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwegn0dxq7gb", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "^^^^", "created": "2024-04-09T16:32:18Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luslnj16m0d3q", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-04-09T16:32:18Z", "config": {"editor": "md"}}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwd1pdujw4wz", "lkqwej5x9pg6c", "lkqwdmtccazxn", "lkqwegn0dxq7gb"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luoc99ipi8e7ai", "updated": "2024-04-10T02:42:27Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luo8htx2l7o69f", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 6, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457539959, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["final"], "nr": 1112, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-06T16:01:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luoa82y14pc4j2", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-06T16:01:17Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "luobac0jho4vx", "to": "luoa82xtffq4j1", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-06T16:31:02Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Column space and row space clarification", "created": "2024-04-06T16:01:17Z", "content": "Does the column space include all columns of the matrix? If two columns are equivalent to each other then are both columns included in the column space?\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 50, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-06T16:31:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Branca Xing", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8zcl4pgki", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-06T16:31:02Z", "content": "The column space is the set of all linear combinations of the columns, so the columns are included in the columns space (consider taking just $$1$$ copy of each column).

For writing the column space as a span of vectors, it doesn\u2019t matter if you include redundant vectors (or linearly dependent ones), unless the question asks to find a basis for the column space.

On the exam, it will be clearly stated if we want you to find a basis or not.
"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8zcl4pgki"], "children": [], "id": "luobac0bja2vw", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luoa82xtffq4j1", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457541017, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week11"], "nr": 1113, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-06T16:05:42Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luoadr2151l7fi", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-06T16:05:42Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "luobejgqvrw6o5", "to": "luoadr1t8on7fg", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-06T16:34:18Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luoadr1t8on7fg", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-06T16:51:32Z", "cid": "luoc0p7insn3td", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "luoadr1t8on7fg", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-06T17:08:13Z", "cid": "luocm5lmnul2x1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luoadr1t8on7fg", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-06T23:19:54Z", "cid": "luopw5hqes742r", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "to": "luoadr1t8on7fg", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-07T16:05:10Z", "cid": "luppsxlo6u052t"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luoadr1t8on7fg", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-11T21:35:45Z", "cid": "luvrdgt8yb86mf", "uid_a": "a_2"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "to": "luoadr1t8on7fg", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-11T23:34:01Z", "cid": "luvvljqxgkf1bj"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "WP11 Q8", "created": "2024-04-06T16:05:42Z", "content": "

For this question, why is the matrix that diagonalizes A and B the same? I suppose it should be two invertible matrices P1, P2 filled with the same eigenvectors vi in different order, however, the answer says that P1 = P2. Is there anything wrong with my thinking process? Thank you."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week11", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 64, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-06T16:34:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Li Xuanhe", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwej5x9pg6c", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-06T16:34:18Z", "content": "If a matrix $$A$$ is diagonalizable, then the matrix which diagonalizes $$A$$ is going to be the matrix whose columns are all eigenvectors. i.e.

$$A=PDP^{-1}$$

where $$D$$ is diagonal with entries full of the eigenvalues, and the columns of $$P$$ are the corresponding eigenvectors of $$A$$.

Does this answer your question?
"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwej5x9pg6c"], "children": [], "id": "luobejgip3e6o4", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "If P1=P2, I suppose D1 should also equal to P2 because eigenvalues and eigenvectors are corresponding to each other. We are given in the question that each $$\vec v_i$$ is an eigenvector shared by both $$A$$ and $$B$$. However, we don't have any info about the eigenvalues. So we know the eigenvectors are the same but we don't know about the eigenvalues.

Does that clarify your question?

This follows from questions like Example 9.4.15 in the course notes. We have a bunch of eigenvectors that are the same for both $$A$$ and $$B$$ (all the $$\vec v _i$$)

So if we construct a matrix $$P$$ whose columns are $$\vec v_1, \ldots, \vec v_n$$, it will diagonalize both $$A$$ and $$B$$

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week11"], "nr": 1118, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-06T21:38:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luom9tbd9af2f", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-06T21:38:33Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "luot2nzrh3839v", "to": "luom9tb6txe2e", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-07T00:48:57Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Choice of Basis and Reflection", "created": "2024-04-06T21:38:33Z", "content": "

Hi, I'm confused about if we have to apply the operation that we learned about refl here and how does the reflection do so "through the origin"? Furthermore why is it that the eigenvectors of refl make sure that its diagonalizable? Why were those two vectors chosen other than linear independence? Could we have chosen [1 0 0]T instead of [1 0 1]T?

I'd really appreciate any help in filling my gaps in understanding, thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week11", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 95, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-07T00:48:57Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "camariut@uwaterloo.ca", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8gwt19q556", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-07T00:48:57Z", "content": "

We are reflecting the vectors through a plane through the origin.  If we reflect vectors through a plane that doesn't go through the origin, then $$T(\vec 0) \neq \vec 0$$ and the transformation will not be linear. 

 We have proved that a linear transformation is diagonalizable if and only if we can find a basis of eigenvectors.  

The equation of the plane will be $$x-z=0$$.  To get two eigenvectors with eigenvalue 1, they chose two linearly independent vectors in the plane.  The vector $$[1,0,0]^T$$ does not lie in the plane because it does not satisfy the equation of the plane. 

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8gwt19q556"], "children": [], "id": "luot2nzjtcb39u", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luom9tb6txe2e", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457547361, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["final"], "nr": 1125, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-07T14:23:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lupm6e4wkau1cu", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-07T14:23:40Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lupormttks84iy", "to": "lupm6e4ped91ct", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-07T15:36:10Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_2", "data": "lut0boy28lk2bq", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-04-09T23:23:00Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Diagonalization", "created": "2024-04-07T14:23:40Z", "content": "Why is being diagonalizable sometimes A = PD(P)^-1 and sometimes PA(P)^-1 = D? Are they used interchangeably?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Jason Hon", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": "2e15ed57-8695-4b55-9a7d-04e6f474114b_200.jpg", "id": "lkqwc62io9y5uf", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lkqwc62io9y5uf/2e15ed57-8695-4b55-9a7d-04e6f474114b_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 56, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-07T15:36:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_2", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-09T23:23:00Z", "content": "Yeah pretty much. The first is to express the matrix A and the second to express the diagonal matrix $$D$$. Given the first equation $$A = PDP^{-1}$$, you can multiply both sides by $$P$$ and $$P^{-1}$$ to get $$D = P^{-1}AP.$$\u00a0"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-07T15:36:10Z", "content": "

Yeah pretty much. The first is to express the matrix A and the second to express the diagonal matrix D. Given the first equation A = PD(P)^-1, you can multiply both sides by P and P^-1 to get D = (P)^-1AP.\u00a0

\n

\n

Side note: D = (P)^-1AP not PA(P)^-1\u00a0

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4"], "children": [], "id": "lupormtmbfr4ix", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwc62io9y5uf"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lupm6e4ped91ct", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457555046, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week11"], "nr": 1128, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-07T18:30:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l7s7g2ty49x44n", "data": "lupuz77rre1449", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-07T18:30:01Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lupvqcm23fx3i2", "to": "lupuz77jta6448", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-07T18:51:08Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "lupw21mrb2z10j", "to": "lupuz77jta6448", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-07T19:00:13Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lupwe6w7q4g2db", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-04-07T19:09:40Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "lupuz77jta6448", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-07T19:09:51Z", "cid": "lupwefvfmhl2uh", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "l7s7g2ty49x44n", "subject": "what is a8 = g8 means", "created": "2024-04-07T18:30:01Z", "content": ""}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week11", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 64, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-07T18:51:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Shiqi Cai", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l7s7g2ty49x44n", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-07T19:09:40Z", "content": "

This is the algebraic and geometric multiplicities. The geometric multiplicity is the number of vectors you find in the eigenspace (in this example, 2). The algebraic multiplicity is the multiplicity/exponent of the eigenvalue in the characteristic polynomial.

So for example $$(2-\lambda )^3$$ would tell you the Eigenvalue 2 has a algebraic multiplicity of 3.

In order for a matrix/linear operator to be diagonalizable we need the algebraic multiplicity to equal the geometric multiplicity for every Eigenvalue.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-07T18:51:07Z", "content": "

This is the algebraic and geometric multiplicities. The algebraic multiplicity is the number of vectors you find in the eigenspace (in this example, 2). The geometric multiplicity is the multiplicity/exponent of the eigenvalue in the characteristic polynomial.

So for example $$(2-\lambda )^3$$ would tell you the Eigenvalue 2 has a geometric multiplicity of 3.

In order for a matrix/linear operator to be diagonalizable we need the algebraic multiplicity to equal the geometric multiplicity for every Eigenvalue.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["l7s7g2ty49x44n"], "children": [], "id": "lupvqclv51s3i1", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-07T19:00:13Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-07T19:00:13Z", "content": "The student answer has swapped the definitions: the geometric multiplicity is the dimension of the eigenspace, while the algebraic multiplicity is the degree of the eigenvalue as a root in the characteristic polynomial. Note that every vector which is orthogonal to $$\vec n$$ will be on this plane, so we can simply solve the system $$\vec n^\top \vec x = 0$$ i.e. solve the system $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -1\end{bmatrix} \vec x = 0$$ for $$\vec x \in \mathbb R^3$$. This is equivalent to solving a homogenous system, hence why we know that it is a basis. Lastly, if we think about how the transformation should act on these three vectors, we can deduce that $$T(\vec n) = -\vec n$$ (since the normal vector should be reflected across the plane), and $$T(\vec u) = \vec u, T(\vec v) = \vec v$$ where $$\vec u, \vec v$$ are the basis vectors of the plane."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-07T19:08:21Z", "content": "Since we are given a normal vector $$\vec n$$, we are interested in finding the plane which is orthogonal to this normal vector. {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["final"], "nr": 1133, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-07T21:10:39Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwcbs34566v9", "data": "luq0prvfa2r1hn", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-07T21:10:39Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "luq5l5uh8yj3ww", "to": "luq0prv8d4f1hk", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-07T23:27:02Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwcbs34566v9", "subject": "Citing propositions on the final exam", "created": "2024-04-07T21:10:39Z", "content": "

For the large amount of propositions that we learned, some of them have intuitive names like System Rank Theorem, but a lot of them have really long names that are hard to remember exactly, like "Composition of Linear Transformations Is Linear"

\n

\n

What are the requirements when we cite the usage of a proposition from the textbook?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "camariut@uwaterloo.ca", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8gwt19q556", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Nathan McGregor", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdgm8kam7jk", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 68, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-07T23:27:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750, "llazq0fual03ej": 1702407827, "global": 1707613189}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-07T23:27:02Z", "content": "You don't need to cite things by name.\u00a0\u00a0 You won't be penalized for not using the names of the theorems.\u00a0"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwca7ky8m6lh"], "children": [], "id": "luq5l5uabrv3wv", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqw8gwt19q556", "lkqwdgm8kam7jk"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luq0prv8d4f1hk", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457563502, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"", "created": "2024-04-07T23:31:30Z", "content": "If $$h(x)$$ is not a constant polynomial, then that means the factorization of the characteristic polynomial into irreducible factors will not only {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week11"], "nr": 1135, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-07T21:26:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luq1ab3mqww1lw", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-07T21:26:37Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "luq1p0kdtsf4nn", "to": "luq1ab3d5gb1lu", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-07T21:38:03Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luq1ab3d5gb1lu", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-07T21:53:15Z", "cid": "luq28jyylfq5tr", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "to": "luq1ab3d5gb1lu", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-07T22:05:23Z", "cid": "luq2o5wa43338t"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "invertible", "created": "2024-04-07T21:26:37Z", "content": "Is it when all the eigen values are 0, then it is not invertible or is it when one of the eigen value is 0 then not invertible?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week11", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 54, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-07T21:38:03Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "camariut@uwaterloo.ca", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8gwt19q556", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Kelvin Zhou", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lm71gzp8lv22ji", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-07T21:38:03Z", "content": "There only needs to be one eigenvalue that is 0

Recall that $$A$$ invertible $$\\Leftrightarrow$$ Null(A)={$$\\vec 0$$}

So having $$0$$ as an eigenvalue means that there is an eigenvector (non zero by definition) where $$A \\vec x = 0\\cdot \\vec x = 0$$ so the Null(A) contains a vector other than the zero vector!

Hope that helps!
"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw8gwt19q556", "idt8cfyuv993c4", "lm71gzp8lv22ji"], "children": [], "id": "luq1p0k7prb4nm", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Does if a matrix is not invertible then the there is eigen value 0 make sense?", "created": "2024-04-07T21:53:15Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Yep! Recall Proposition 7.3.1:
A invertible $$\\Leftrightarrow$$ 0 is not an eigenvalue of A.\u00a0

So by contrapositive, we see that \u00ab if A is not invertible, then 0 is an eigenvalue \u00bb is also true

Hope that helps!

If $$[T]_B$$ and $$[T]_C$$ are similar, we have $$[T]_C ={}_{C}[I]_B [T]_B {}_{B}[I]_C$$.

since the change base matrix can also change matrix, $$[T]_C =[T]_C {}_{B}[I]_C$$

$$([T]_C)^{-1}[T]_C =([T]_C)^{-1}[T]_C {}_{B}[I]_C$$

Does that means $$I_n= {}_{B}[I]_C$$? But $$I_n$$ will change nothing, how can it is a change base matrix?

Thank you

Thank you", "created": "2024-04-08T03:04:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

>>since the change base matrix can also change matrix, ..

This is clearly not right. Change of basis matrix is for converting corrdinates.

$$_{\mathcal{B}}[I]_{\mathcal{C}}\ [\vec{x}]_{\mathcal{C}}$$ makes sense, which gives the $$\mathcal{B}$$-coodinate vector $$[\vec{x}]_{\mathcal{B}}$$.

$$[T]_{\mathcal{C}}\ _{\mathcal{B}}[I]_{\mathcal{C}}$$ doesn't make sense.

", "created": "2024-04-08T03:33:59Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xinhao Wang", "endorser": {"lr148a6jm3j40f": 1712329010}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwelvposqnn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwelvposqnn"], "id": "luqeeqw88q7213", "updated": "2024-04-08T03:44:45Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

I am confused.

https://piazza.com/class/lqzes2lznxt50s/post/1064

This post said that change of basis matrix can also converts matrix.

So why is 

$$[T]_C =({}_{C}[I]_B [T]_B) {}_{B}[I]_C$$

$$\implies [T]_C =[T]_C {}_{B}[I]_C$$

wrong?

", "created": "2024-04-08T03:46:16Z", "bucket_order": 5, "bucket_name": "This week", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luqeujndv607ct", "updated": "2024-04-08T03:46:16Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "
  • basis matrix can also converts matrix, if the columns of the right matrix can be interpreted as coordinate vectors. So essentially, by definition it only convert proper coordinates. 
  • Your formula is easy to check. Think of $$\mathcal{C}=\mathcal{E}$$, $$[T]_{\mathcal{E}}=I_n$$ and $$\mathcal{B}\neq \mathcal{E}$$, so that $$[T]_{\mathcal{B}}\neq I_n$$.

Columns of $$[T]_{\mathcal{B}}$$ are not $$\mathcal{B}$$-coordinates of columns of $$[T]_{\mathcal{C}}$$. Again, change of basis matrix doesn't convert everything from $$\mathcal{B}$$ to $$\mathcal{C}$$. It only converts coordinates.

I recommend you read the proof of $$[T]_C ={}_{C}[I]_B [T]_B {}_{B}[I]_C$$ in the course notes.

", "created": "2024-04-08T03:54:04Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xinhao Wang", "endorser": {"lr148a6jm3j40f": 1712329010}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwelvposqnn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwelvposqnn"], "id": "luqf4kgnpz5k4", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-04-09T14:41:53Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

For instance, let $$\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{v}_i\}$$ and $$\mathcal{C}=\{\vec{w}_i\}$$.

$$[T]_{\mathcal{B}}$$ by definition is the matrix formed by $$\mathcal{B}$$-coodinates of $$T(\vec{v}_i)$$. If you convert it using $$_{\mathcal{C}}[I]_{\mathcal{B}}$$, $$_{\mathcal{C}}[I]_{\mathcal{B}}[T]_{\mathcal{B}}$$ gives you a matrix whose columns are $$\mathcal{C}$$-coodinates of $$T(\vec{v_i})$$.

$$[T]_{\mathcal{C}}$$ by definition is the matrix consisting of $$\mathcal{C}$$-coodinates of $$T(\vec{w}_i)$$

A matrix consisting of $$\mathcal{C}$$-coodinates of $$T(\vec{v_i})$$ is not necessarily the matrix consisting of $$\mathcal{C}$$-coodinates of $$T(\vec{w}_i)$$.

", "created": "2024-04-08T04:17:40Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xinhao Wang", "endorser": {"lr148a6jm3j40f": 1712329010}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwelvposqnn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwelvposqnn"], "id": "luqfyx6jkyl5bt", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-04-09T14:41:54Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "In this sentence, "your formula is easy to check", could you explain which 'formula' are you referring to? Thank you", "created": "2024-04-09T20:13:02Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "lustje6vqh01s5", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-04-09T20:13:24Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

>>So why is 

$$[T]_C =({}_{C}[I]_B [T]_B) {}_{B}[I]_C$$

$$\implies [T]_C =[T]_C {}_{B}[I]_C$$

wrong?

Let $$\mathcal{C}=\{\vec{e_1}, \vec{e_2}, \vec{e_3}\}$$. Let $$T(\vec{x})=\vec{x}$$ for all $$\vec{x}\in \mathbb{F}^3$$.

  • Can you work out what $$[T]_{\mathcal{C}}$$ is?

Let $$\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{e_1}+\vec{e_2}, \vec{e_2}, \vec{e_3}\}$$.

  • Can you work out $$_{\mathcal{B}}[I]_{\mathcal{C}}$$ and $$_{\mathcal{C}}[I]_{\mathcal{B}}$$?
  • Can you also work out $$[T]_{\mathcal{B}}$$?
  • Then can you see that your implication isn't right since $$_{\mathcal{C}}[I]_{\mathcal{B}}\ [T]_{\mathcal{B}}$$ isn't $$[T]_{\mathcal{C}}$$?

W here is defined as {$$\vec x \in \mathbb{R}^3 : \vec v \cdot \vec x = \vec 0 $$ for all $$\vec v \in S$$}. Recalling what the dot product looks like:

$$\vec v \cdot \vec x = v_1x_1 + v_2x_2 + v_3x_3 = 0$$

Now, we're given that this must hold for all $$\vec v \in S$$ so we have this:

1st vector in S:      $$ x_1 + x_2 + x_3 = 0$$

2nd:                      $$ 2x_1 + 2x_2  = 0$$

3rd:                       $$ 3 x_3 = 0$$

4th:                       $$ 3x_1 + 3x_2 + 4x_3 = 0$$

I just replaced each $$v_i$$ with the corresponding component of the vectors from S, I can elaborate more if this is unclear.

So now we can stick this into an augmented matrix! Also notice how it is just the transpose of $$A$$.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week8"], "nr": 1141, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-08T03:35:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luqeh2gkumsuq", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-08T03:35:47Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "luqx00ror372c6", "to": "luqeh2gdd57up", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-08T12:14:25Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "homogenous non-linear systems", "created": "2024-04-08T03:35:47Z", "content": "I had two questions: (1) Can there be a homogenous non-linear system? If yes, what's a good example of them? (2) Can a homogenous non-linear system be a subspace?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week8", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 45, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-08T12:14:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Arav Sharma", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "ktn8lt6g2yi515", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-08T12:14:24Z", "content": "

Yes, there can be a homogenous non-linear system.\u00a0 For example\u00a0 $$x^2=0, y^2=0$$ is a homogeneous non-linear system.\u00a0

\n

\n

For your second question, I assume you are asking whether the solution set to a homogeneous non-linear system could be a subspace.\u00a0 The answer is yes.\u00a0 Consider my example above.\u00a0 The solution set to this system consists of only the zero vector in $$\\mathbb{R}^2$$.\u00a0 And the set which consists of only the zero vector is a subspace.\u00a0

{"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

In part c) you are essentially creating an entirely separate matrix to tackle a new problem. You want the set of vectors such that these vectors 'dot' the vectors in S is zero.

If you took the dot product of an arbitrary vector $$\vec{x}$$ with every vector in S you would get a system of equations that looks something like this:

You want the vector that simultaneously fulfils all these requirements. You need to solve the system for that vector. Remember systems of equations correspond to matrices, so converting this into a matrix gets you the matrix B:


You now need to solve the system $$B\vec{x} = \vec{0}$$ to find the dimension of your new set, W.

Had we used the matrix from part a) it would have gotten us nowhere because it's not actually relevant to the problem we were trying to solve. We constructed B out of a system of linear equations specifically designed to meet our goal of $$\vec{x}\epsilon W$$.

The fact that B is the transpose of our matrix in part a) is more like a happy coincidence, and not really relevant to our goal. Hope this helps :)

Hello,

I just wanted to ask if it's ok to use the determinant when proving linear independence of a span. When we put the span vectors into a matrix 'A' as columns we should get the RREF being the identity if the vectors are LI, right? So by our invertibility criteria this is equivalent to det(A) != 0

Im not sure if this is obvious or completely wrong so I am just asking to be sure. If it is true do we need to explain this logic on the final, or is it implied?

Thanks!

Is it true that?

If A, B is invertible,

$$(A^{-1}B^{-1})$$ is also invertible?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 54, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-08T18:21:19Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-08T18:21:19Z", "content": "It is true.   Can you prove it? "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lura3vavam86u", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Is the following reasonable?

Since $$A$$ and $$B$$ are invertible, we know that the product matrix $$BA$$ is also invertible using $$\text{det}{(BA)} \neq 0$$. We can show that $$(BA)^{-1} = A^{-1}B^{-1}$$, which is invertible.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["final"], "nr": 1154, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-08T18:58:27Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lurbfmcq9s85nm", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-08T18:58:27Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lurc5apz6b243o", "to": "lurbfmcb7eo5nl", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-08T19:18:25Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Invertibility and linear dependence/independence", "created": "2024-04-08T18:58:27Z", "content": "What is the connection/theorem relating invertibility and linear independence and dependence"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 47, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-08T19:18:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-08T19:18:25Z", "content": "

Not sure if it's explicitly stated in a theorem anywhere (maybe it is!) but as far as the logic is concerned lets consider a set of n linearly independent vectors.

By pivots and linear independence we know that we can put these vectors in a matrix and row reduce. The fact that we have specifically n vectors is important, it means that these vectors create a square matrix. Since the vectors are Linearly independent, you would get that every column gets a pivot (therefore every column vector is worth keeping in the set).

But then, you have a matrix where the RREF is the identity. This is a statement in our invertibility criteria. If a matrix has an RREF which is the identity matrix, it is invertible. So the matrix constructed from linearly independent vectors is invertible.

You also get a bunch of other things from the invertiblilty criteria for free, like the determinant of the matrix not being zero, the corresponding linear transformation being one-to-one/onto, etc.

The reverse here is also true. An invertible matrix means the vectors which make its columns are linearly idependent.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwclm3shhvy", "idt8cfyuv993c4"], "children": [], "id": "lurc5apkki643l", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lurbfmcb7eo5nl", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457585746, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hello, could anyone clarify the main ideas for when to tell a basis is a spanning set for Fn?

I find all the theorems to be very closely related but also different - but here's what I'm thinking as of right now:

1. Let S be subspace. Span(S) = F^n iff rank(A) = n

2. This is the same idea as V = F^n iff dim(V) = n. Since V is obtained by taking the pivot columns of A, dim(V) = n = rank(A).

3. We also note that if V is basis for F^n => f the basis has n vectors? (not an iff statement)

4. But if we say V is linearly independent and has n vectors => V is basis for F^n?

Essentially, I just want to clarify if these ideas can be clarified/distinguished concisely by anyone? Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 54, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-09T02:31:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Landon Trinh", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcmng7k212i", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Xinhao Wang", "endorser": {"lr148a6jm3j40f": 1712329010}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwelvposqnn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-09T02:31:11Z", "content": "It looks like you may be confusing the idea of a subspace and its basis. I'm not exactly sure what some of your questions are asking since you didn't define some objects, so I will try to give an overview. We always say that a set of vectors $$B$$ is a basis for a subspace $$W$$. This means 2 things: 1. $$B$$ is linearly independent. 2. $$\text{Span}(B) = W$$ From here, we define the dimension of a subspace $$\dim(W)$$ to be the number of vectors in any basis $$B$$ for $$W$$. Note that this definition is consistent because every basis has the same number of vectors in any basis. By convention, we take $$\emptyset$$ to be a basis for the trivial subspace $$\{\vec 0\}$$. Conversely, any set satisfying 1. and 2. is a basis for $$W$$. We have some bounds: for a subspace $$W$$ of dimension $$d$$, if $$B \subseteq W$$ is linearly independent, then there are at most $$d$$ vectors in $$B$$. This means that if $$B$$ has exactly $$d$$ vectors, and is linearly independent, then $$B$$ must be a basis for $$W$$. Also, if $$B \subseteq W$$ is spanning, i.e. $$\text{Span}(B) = W$$, then $$B$$ has at least $$d$$ vectors in $$B$$. This means that if $$B$$ has exactly $$d$$ vectors, and is spanning, then $$B$$ must be a basis for $$W$$. From these two ideas, we can gather two different ways of thinking of a basis $$B$$ for a subspace $$W$$: 1. $$B$$ is a maximal linearly independent set 2. $$B$$ is a minimal spanning set Here, the term maximal is used to mean that you can't add any more vectors to the set which preserve the linear independence of the set, and minimal is used to mean that there are no spanning sets with less vectors. Does this help?"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwcmng7k212i", "lkqwelvposqnn"], "children": [], "id": "lurrlu2yci3yh", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

So to clarify the main ideas/theorems we should know, are the following:

I was also wondering this: @1151

It's just the idea that we hope there's some solution, v such that Av = cb.

In this case, we plug v = cx to get A(cx) = c(Ax) = cb, as desired.

For this question from quiz 5, I put false, thinking of the following counter-example:

if B = {$$\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$, $$\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$} and C = {$$\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$, $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$}, since they are ordered bases, they are different but both spans $$F^2$$. 

For a vector $$\begin{bmatrix} 7 \\ 7 \end{bmatrix}$$ as an example, the coordinate vector for both bases would be $$\begin{bmatrix} 7 \\ 7 \end{bmatrix}$$. 

I am having trouble understanding why my counter-example doesn't work and therefore it's a true statement. Is there any logical flaw in my understanding or my counter-example? I would appreciate any explanations. 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 57, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-09T02:46:52Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mathilda Lee", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "l3a6u2rficd4fp", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-09T02:50:16Z", "content": "

It doesn't satisfy that $$[\vec{x}]_\mathcal{B} = [\vec{x}]_\mathcal{C}$$ for every $$\vec{x}$$. For instance, if $$\vec{x}=[1~0]^T$$, $$[\vec{x}]_\mathcal{B}=[1~0]^T$$, but $$[\vec{x}]_\mathcal{C}=[0~1]^T$$

Also I think you didn't actually mean this in your wording, but note that the counter-example not working doesn't mean its a true statement.

You can show the statement is true, since you can do something similar to column extraction with the two sets. If $$[\vec{u_1}]_\mathcal{B}=[1~\dots~0]^T$$, and this is the same for $$\mathcal{C}$$, then $$\vec{u}_1=\vec{v}_1$$, you can repeat the same with all the other vectors

Classes have finished and so this will be my final post in the tips category for the semester.  I hope these posts have been helpful to at least some of you.  Thank you to those of you have interacted with my posts and shared some of your own thoughts.   I know that many of you have been following along since MATH 135. 

 

It’s clear from the questions that some of you have asked on Piazza that you are working hard to master the material.  I hope things are coming together and that you are seeing the many ways that the material we have learned is connected. 

 

I wish you good luck on your final exams.  Keep persevering and do your best! The end of the semester is in sight.

 

All the best!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["final"], "nr": 1179, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-09T14:39:40Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lushmocsjiw3ic", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-09T14:39:40Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "lushvgv39bh4l0", "to": "lushmockhrw3ib", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-09T14:46:30Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "lushx9ksa5f15l", "to": "lushmockhrw3ib", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-09T14:47:54Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Span the subspace?", "created": "2024-04-09T14:39:40Z", "content": "

If V is a subspace, can we do span(V)? Will span(V) equal to V because subspace is closed under addition and multiplication?

Thank you

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 49, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-09T14:46:30Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xinhao Wang", "endorser": {"lr148a6jm3j40f": 1712329010}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwelvposqnn", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-09T14:46:30Z", "content": "

If $$V$$ is a subspace, then $$\text{Span}(V) = V$$.  

(There is going to be a lot of redundancy in this spanning set though.)

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwelvposqnn"], "children": [], "id": "lushvguukie4ky", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-09T14:47:54Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-09T14:47:54Z", "content": "I believe so as V is a set of vectors. And span(V) = V by closure. Although it's closure under addition of 2 vectors, it would generalize to any finite linear combination of vectors."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lushx9ko3p015k", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lushmockhrw3ib", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457612359, "default_anonymity": "no"}

If a set of vectors are linearly dependent, that doesn't necessarily mean that the sum of the scalars is not 0 right? Since if we have v = [1 -1] and w = [-1 1], 1v - 1w = 0.

In that case, any hints to continue this proof (I used contrapositive rather than direct proof as shown in solutions)

Hi!

I'm having difficulty seeing why the question below is false.

Initially I had thought that because $$\vec{x} \in V$$, $$\vec{x}$$ can be written as a linear combination of $$\vec{v_1} ... \vec{v_m}$$, and that  can be split to become $$Span(\vec{x}, \vec{v_1} ... \vec{x_m}) = Span(\vec{v_1} ... \vec{x_m}) = V$$.

I am further confused by the counter-example:. Doesn't this set not take into account that $$\vec{x}$$ is added to every vector in the original set? Should it not be $$Span({\vec{0}}, \vec{e_2} - \vec{e_1}, \vec{e_3} - \vec{e_1})$$ which can be split to become $$Span({\vec{e_1}}, \vec{e_2}, \vec{e_3})$$?

I would appreciate the clarification/if anyone could point out where my misunderstanding is. Thank you!

Is this correct?"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "A plane is a span of two vectors if it passes through the origin,", "created": "2024-04-09T18:26:03Z", "content": "and a span of three vectors if it does not. 

Is this correct/"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week2", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 43, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-09T18:27:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-09T18:29:25Z", "content": "

A plane passing through the origin is a span of two linearly independent vectors.

A plane not passing through the origin would not be the span of any vectors, since it is no longer a subspace (does not contain $$\vec{0}$$)

I think you got confused by that a plane not passing through the origin is equal to a plane passing through the origin plus another vector

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-09T18:27:16Z", "content": "

A plane passing through the origin is a span of two linearly independent vectors.

Can someone please explain the definition of change-of-basis matrix step?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["q5", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 65, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T02:27:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T02:27:23Z", "content": "

$$_\mathcal{B}[P]_\mathcal{E}$$ represents changing a vector in terms of $$\mathcal{E}$$ into a vector in terms of the vectors of $$\mathcal{B}$$. In this case, $$\vec{u}_1,\dots,\vec{u}_n$$ is $$\mathcal{B}$$, so the representation would be $$I_n$$.

For instance, to rewrite $$\vec{u}_3$$, it would clearly just become $$\vec{e}_3$$ since we are taking the third vector from $$\mathcal{B}$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T02:27:07Z", "content": "

$$_\mathcal{B}[P]_\mathcal{E}$$ represents a vector in terms of $$\mathcal{E}$$ in terms of the vectors of $$\mathcal{B}$$. In this case, $$\vec{u}_1,\dots,\vec{u}_n$$ is $$\mathcal{B}$$, so the representation would be $$I_n$$.

For instance, to rewrite $$\vec{u}_3$$, it would clearly just become $$\vec{e}_3$$ since we are taking the third vector from $$\mathcal{B}$$

The answer is correct, but not straightforward... 

Following the standard process, $$c_n$$ is the free parameter and other $$c_i$$ can be directly determined by $$c_n$$ using the RREF. (Then, you realize this is the same as the solution.) Just stick with the standard method, if it makes you comfortable.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week11"], "nr": 1220, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T02:23:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "lut6rp3r19e352", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-10T02:23:25Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "data": "lut7ie3hblg5s", "to": "lut6rp3fjlz350", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-10T02:44:10Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Proof of Exercise in Ch. 9.1", "created": "2024-04-10T02:23:25Z", "content": "I created a proof but I'm unsure about some steps. I labelled them 1, 2, 3 for reference.\u00a0

So In step 2, it's pretty obvious by defn that the matrix to the right of A is P, and that is by definition of change of bases matrix.\u00a0
And I know I can prove that P^-1 shows up to the left of A just by inverting the change of matrix.\u00a0

However, in step 2, I wrote out the change of matrix B[I]E in a different form [[e1]B ... [en]B]. To be honest, by looking at this matrix, I don't immediately see how it corresponds to P^-1. The standard basis vectors with B-components corresponding to P^-1 is a bit hard to think about.

On an exam, I would probably ignore writing it out and just invert\u00a0 B[I]E to be (E[I]B)^-1 = P^-1 which I knew how to solve. But just as a discussion, how would I know [[e1]B ... [en]B] = P^-1 with the given information?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week11", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 71, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T02:44:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Lydia He", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwclm3shhvy", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T02:44:10Z", "content": "

This is just what the change of basis matrix is. $$P$$ is the matrix changing from $$\\mathcal{B}$$ to $$\\mathcal{E}$$, so $$P^{-1}$$ is changing back from $$\\mathcal{E}$$ to $$\\mathcal{B}$$.

\n

\n

In the matrix you wrote out, you can see that it makes sense that this is changing from $$\\mathcal{E}$$ to $$\\mathcal{B}$$ if you think about what happens when you multiply some vector $$[\\vec{v}]_\\mathcal{E}$$ by it. Each of the entries of the vector, $$v_1,\\dots,v_n$$ will be "transformed" into their respective representations in terms of the vectors of $$\\mathcal{B}$$.

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwclm3shhvy"], "children": [], "id": "lut7ie39ve95r", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "lut6rp3fjlz350", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457655872, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 57, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T03:32:53Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T03:32:53Z", "content": "This is still a transformation of vectors to vectors: $$T_2 \circ T_1 : \mathbb F^n \to \mathbb F^p$$."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "lut9919476c60u", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

But for this question why we are obtaining matrixes at the end?

", "created": "2024-04-10T15:40:17Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

The question is asking for $$[T_A \circ T_B]_\mathcal{E}$$, so we are finding the corresponding matrix for the linear transformation. Remember that all linear transformations can be represented by matrix multiplication, the composed transformation is not an exception.

While maybe this isn't a perfect analogy, you can think of elementary row operations as an example We can represent them in terms of matrices, and instead of doing each row operation individually, we can find a matrix that does the same thing as doing all of our row operations one after another.

For questions like these, I was wondering if row reducing A first(only by adding scalar multiples) and then taking the det(A-$$\lambda$$I) was the same as doing the direct det(A-$$\lambda$$I) 

My intuition tells me it doesn't since det(A+B) != det(A) + det(B). I was simply wondering because the way I have been doing them, I find the computation and algebra to be very long and so I was wondering if there was a more efficient way of doing these.

Thanks!

I think however, you could first do $$A-\lambda I$$, and then perform row operations on that, but that may not even be worthwhile"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luu1xyhuux5545", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Yeah I feel like performing row operations with $$ A - \lambdaI$$ is not rly worth. Note that similarity $$P^{-1}AP$$ doesn't change eigenspace and character poly for $$\det(P^{-1}AP - P^{-1}(\lambda I)P)=\det(A-\lambda I)=C_\lambda(A)$$.  This means if you want to perform row operations to $$A$$, to preseve the eigen-stuff, you need to perform "certain column operations". Since it involves column operations, this trick is not required in the couse. 

As for calculating determinant, there are also many tricks. For instance, if you want to decompose determinant as a sum, you can do the following.

$$ \det\begin{pmatrix} 2-\lambda & 2 & -1\\ -4 & 1-\lambda &2\\ 2 & 2 & -1-\lambda \end{pmatrix}$$

$$= \det\begin{pmatrix} 2-\lambda & 2 & -1\\ -4 & 1-\lambda &2\\ 0 & 0 & -\lambda \end{pmatrix} + \det\begin{pmatrix} 2-\lambda & 2 & -1\\ -4 & 1 -\lambda &2\\ 2 & 2 & -1 \end{pmatrix} $$

$$= -\lambda((\lambda-2)(\lambda-1)+8) + \det\begin{pmatrix} -\lambda & 0 & 0\\ -4 & 1-\lambda &2\\ 2 & 2 & -1 \end{pmatrix} $$

$$= -\lambda(\lambda^2-3\lambda+10) -\lambda((\lambda-1)-4)=-\lambda(\lambda^2-2\lambda+5) $$

Not necessarily shorter, but this method is clearer for double checking the solution.

Based on the practice final I would say no.

I'd recommend trying the practice final, I imagine it will be remarkably similar to the real final. There were 11 questions total (Q1 was all T/F and the rest long/short answer stuff). 

The main "themes" or sections of the practice final focus on chpt 6 determinants, chpt 7 eigenvectors / eigenvalues, chpt 8 subspaces / bases, and chpt 9 diagonalization, it appears there are about 1 or 2 long answers per chpt. Wouldn't be surprised if it is the same / very similar for Friday's exam. 

Computing RREF and other things that were pre-midterm are prerequisite knowledge for most of the 6-9 content, but not the focus of the questions.

I hope that gives you better direction for your review, but I understand the desire for the exam breakdown

false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 72, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T18:16:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T18:16:30Z", "content": "

Algebraic multiplicities are the powers of the linear factors in the factorization of the characteristic polynomial.

For example, if one has $$C_\lambda(A)= (\lambda-1)^2(\lambda+5)^3 (\lambda - 4)$$, then the algebraic multiplicity of $$\lambda=1$$ is $$2$$; algebraic multiplicity of $$\lambda=-5$$ is $$3$$, etc..

Speaking of your question, can you work out the characteristic polynomial and factor it into linear pieces? Then you will see the algebraic multiplicity. 

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T18:16:14Z", "content": "

Algebraic multiplicities are the powers of the linear factors in the factorization of the characteristic polynomial.

For example, if one has $$C_\lambda(A)= (\lambda-1)^2(\lambda+5)^3 (\lambda - 4)$$, then the algebraic multiplicity of $$\lambda=1$$ is $$2$$; algebraic multiplicity of $$\lambda=-5$$ is $$3$$, etc..

Speaking of your question, can you work out the characteristic polynomial and factor it into linear pieces? Then you will see algebraic multiplicity.

(with lambda in it) Then I believe the characteristic polynomial is just 0-0 = 0, how can I know the algebraic multiplicity if there's no lambda in the characteristic polynomial?", "created": "2024-04-10T18:31:35Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Oluwafadekemi Odu-onikosi", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "llnqx80eduxbu", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {"lr5ecl50k5u23j": 1711835446}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

>>Do you mean I need to find the characteristic polynomial based on the matrix given by the question? (with lambda in it)

Yes.

>>Then I believe the characteristic polynomial is just 0-0 = 0, how can I know the algebraic multiplicity if there's no lambda in the characteristic polynomial?

You need to review how to calculate characteristic polynomial. Read pp 170--172 of the course notes. (An $$n\times n$$ matrix always has a degree-$$n$$ characteristic polynomial, so must have $$\lambda$$ in it.)

Would appreciate a breakdown."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week10", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {"lr5ecl50k5u23j": 1711835446}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 63, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T19:05:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Shihan Sharar", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1702155408, "lpvj0xmshic497": 1706729797, "lr5ecl50k5u23j": 1709240524, "global": 1711544832}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdbxatel6pr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T19:05:31Z", "content": "

Given $$\mathcal{B}=\{\vec{v_1},\vec{v_2}\}$$, the matrix formed by basis vectors $$[\vec{v_1}\ \ \vec{v_2}]$$ is exactly $$_{\mathcal{E}}[I]_{\mathcal{B}}$$. (Why? check course notes or lecture notes)

Same holds for other ordered basis $$\mathcal{C}=\{\vec{w_1}, \vec{w_2}\}$$.

The row-reduction algorithm is turning the LHS into an identity matrix and meanwhile (left)multiplying the inverse of LHS to the RHS. 

Therefore by a theorem, $$[\vec{w_1} \ \ \vec{w_2}]^{-1} [\vec{v_1}\ \ \vec{v_2}]$$ $$=\ _{\mathcal{E}}[I]_{\mathcal{C}}^{-1}$$ $$_{\mathcal{E}}[I]_{\mathcal{B}} =\  _{\mathcal{C}}[I]_{\mathcal{B}}$$.

"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdbxatel6pr"], "children": [], "id": "luu6kemtztr4mb", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwec73jwh6mz"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luu62zu031g2a5", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457681416, "default_anonymity": "no"}
