{"history_size": 2, "folders": ["midterm", "other", "final"], "nr": 1250, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T19:33:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luu7kgp3nmn7ia", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-10T19:33:33Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "luu7lpntl6i37i", "v": "all", "type": "update", "when": "2024-04-10T19:34:31Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "luu9dqbuiw948a", "to": "luu7kgowtuk7i9", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-10T20:24:18Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luu7kgowtuk7i9", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-10T20:25:59Z", "cid": "luu9fw6zw7n2oa", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "to": "luu7kgowtuk7i9", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-10T20:28:54Z", "cid": "luu9jnhk7gz1dw"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "[Q7][Sample Midterm] Is this a valid solution?", "created": "2024-04-10T19:34:31Z", "content": "

A is invertible where $$A^{-1} = A$$
Follows from Invertibilty criteria that $$Null(A) = \{ \vec{0}\}$$ and $$Col(A) = \mathbb{F^N} $$ which implies that $$\vec{0}\in Col(A)$$

is this enough?

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "[Q7][Sample Midterm] Is this a valid solution?", "created": "2024-04-10T19:33:33Z", "content": "

A is invertible where $$A^{-1} = A$$
Follows from Invertibilty criteria that $$Null(A) = \{ 0\}$$ and $$Col(A) = \mathbb{F^N} $$ which implies that $$0\in Col(A)$$

is this enough?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "midterm", "other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 71, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T20:24:18Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Milind Singh Meetarbhan", "endorser": {"lpvj0xmshic497": 1712170637}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcbcphb86sf", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T20:24:18Z", "content": "

I would say that is sufficient for the ($$\subseteq$$) direction.

I agree with you that the ($$\supseteq$$) is kind of implied by this proof, however I would include it just to be safe (and it's really straightforward)

So just add one line like "since Col(A) and Null(A) are spans, $$\vec 0 \in Col(A) \cap Null(A) \Rightarrow \{\vec 0\}\subseteq Col(A) \cap Null(A)$$ ".

Then it's a watertight proof!

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["final"], "nr": 1252, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T20:28:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luu9iodpzrx7ea", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-10T20:28:09Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "luuai3313ua67t", "to": "luu9iodhp917e8", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-10T20:55:41Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "luuaj5mscpjwb", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-04-10T20:56:31Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "luuakx53e294lb", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-04-10T20:57:53Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "luui7m49bge51v", "to": "luu9iodhp917e8", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-11T00:31:29Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "linearly dependence question", "created": "2024-04-10T20:28:09Z", "content": "

does a set of linearly independent vectors have to equal to dimension they belong to? 

for example if you have a set of vectors in R^n S that are linearly independent does this imply that the span(S) = R^n?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 52, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T20:55:41Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T20:57:53Z", "content": "

I'm not entirely certain what your question is asking. A set of linear independent vectors is a set, dimension is the number of vectors in the basis of a subspace. 

If you have a set of vectors in $$\mathbb{R}^n$$ that are linearly independent, Span(S) $$\subseteq \mathbb{R}^n$$, and Span(S) = $$\mathbb{R}^n$$ iff dim(Span(S)) = n.

Does that answer your question? Feel free to elaborate further if I misinterpreted what you are asking

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T20:56:31Z", "content": "

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luuai32wvq367s", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T00:31:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T00:31:29Z", "content": "If a set of vectors is linearly independent, it doesn't have to be a spanning set for the vector space it is from.  For, example if I choose one non-zero vector from $$\mathbb{R}^2$$ it will be a linearly independent set, but it will not be a spanning set for $$\mathbb{R}^2$$."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luui7m3ubbf51t", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luu9iodhp917e8", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457689886, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["final"], "nr": 1254, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T20:49:47Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luuaahwj4pg4c1", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-10T20:49:47Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "luuaeg1w1t013a", "to": "luuaahwbs04c0", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-10T20:52:51Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Practice final Q5b", "created": "2024-04-10T20:49:47Z", "content": "

Can someone explain why dim(Span(S)) = rank(A) in all cases?

\n

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 52, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-10T20:52:51Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "David", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwa7mpvvkep", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T20:52:51Z", "content": "The rank(A) is the number of pivots, and by the LI and pivots theorem, every pivot column corresponds to a basis vector. ", "created": "2024-04-10T21:41:06Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luuc4i7d2c53p", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-04-10T21:41:07Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Like, if the transformation is T, I know that T($$\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 1\\ \end{bmatrix}$$) = $$\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 1\\ \end{bmatrix}$$ and T($$\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ -1\\ \end{bmatrix}$$) = $$\begin{bmatrix} -1\\ 0\\ 1\\ \end{bmatrix}$$, so if I add these 2 together I get T($$\begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 0\\ 0\\ \end{bmatrix}$$) = $$\begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0\\ 2\\ \end{bmatrix}$$. But this gives me an elementary matrix. ", "created": "2024-04-10T21:45:41Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luucadxbgwzhe", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-04-10T21:45:41Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "How are you getting these outputs of $$T$$? It isn't clear to me why $$T\left( \begin{bmatrix}1\\0\\1\\ \end{bmatrix} \right)=\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\\1\\ \end{bmatrix}$$", "created": "2024-04-10T22:04:46Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luucyx8yevk76q", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-04-10T22:04:46Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Well, my thought process was that if you reflect a vector on the plane through the plane it will remain as the same vector. I could be wrong though. ", "created": "2024-04-10T23:54:56Z", "bucket_order": 4, "bucket_name": "Yesterday", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luugwm6ftaj3gy", "d-bucket": "Yesterday", "updated": "2024-04-10T23:54:57Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "The vector $$[2, 0, 0 ]^T$$ is not an eigenvector of the linear transformation.  This basis will not produce a B-matrix which is diagonal. ", "created": "2024-04-11T00:45:24Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luuipibgm356a8", "updated": "2024-04-11T00:45:24Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "So for this question, the linearity of transformation wouldn't apply?", "created": "2024-04-11T00:47:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luuis9dopdz2he", "updated": "2024-04-11T00:47:33Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Linearity applies.  But you are looking for eigenvectors of the transformation.  The vectors you are taking a linear combination of are from different eigenspaces and therefore, their linear combination is not guaranteed to be an eigenvector. ", "created": "2024-04-11T00:52:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luuiyrkgo9a3i5", "updated": "2024-04-11T00:52:36Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "So when I'm simply looking for the transformation matrix and not the P matrix I still need to make sure the columns are Eigenvectors? Why is that the case?", "created": "2024-04-11T00:55:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luuj1y8y7t33x4", "updated": "2024-04-11T00:55:05Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "If you want the B-matrix to be diagonal, then your basis must be a basis of eigenvectors.    If you choose a basis which are not eigenvectors, then your B-matrix will not be diagonal. ", "created": "2024-04-11T00:56:37Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luuj3xfjepv6pp", "updated": "2024-04-11T00:56:37Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "To get a diagonal matrix you need $$T(\vec{v}_i) = c\vec{v}_i$$ so that $$[T(\vec{v}_i)]_B=c\vec{e}_i$$.", "created": "2024-04-11T00:59:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luuj70tnynu632", "updated": "2024-04-11T00:59:01Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "So matrices are only diagonal if the basis is made up of their Eigenvectors? In this question, how would I obtain the Eigenvectors? ", "created": "2024-04-11T01:16:25Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luujtdxa49hv1", "updated": "2024-04-11T01:16:25Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "To get a diagonal B-matrix you need B to be a basis of eigenvectors.  To find eigenvectors for this question it's good to think about the geometry involved.  Any vectors in the plane will be mapped to themselves and so they will be eigenvectors with eigenvalue 1.  Any vector orthogonal to the plane will be mapped to their negative and so they will be eigenvectors with eigenvalue $$-1$.", "created": "2024-04-11T01:21:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luujzmnwxc77gm", "updated": "2024-04-11T01:21:16Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I think I understand now! Thank you so much!", "created": "2024-04-11T01:23:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4"], "id": "luuk2gcvhgu5vr", "updated": "2024-04-11T01:24:09Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 1, "id": "luub6pjpbqy49o", "updated": "2024-04-11T01:23:28Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luub0jor29n2ki", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 1, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457695179, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I think it should be $$P^{-1}[T]_\mathcal{E}P=D$$. $$[T]_\mathcal{B}$$ is indeed the diagonal matrix with the eigenvalues of $$T$$.

Consider $$[T]_\mathcal{B}\vec{e}_i$$. This is extracting the $$i$$th column of $$[T]_\mathcal{B}$$, which we would expect to be $$\lambda_i \vec{e}_i$$.

Indeed, $$[T]_\mathcal{B}\vec{e}_i = ~_\mathcal{B}[I]_\mathcal{E}~[T]_\mathcal{E}~_\mathcal{E}[I]_\mathcal{B}~\vec{e}_i=~_\mathcal{B}[I]_\mathcal{E}~[T]_\mathcal{E}~\vec{v}_i=~_\mathcal{B}[I]_\mathcal{E}~\lambda_i\vec{v}_i=\lambda_i\vec{e}_i$$

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-10T22:14:56Z", "content": "

I think it should be $$P^{-1}[T]_\mathcal{E}P=D$$. $$[T]_\mathcal{B}$$ is indeed the diagonal matrix with the eigenvalues of $$T$$.

Consider $$[T]_\mathcal{B}\vec{e}_i$$. This is extracting the $$i$$th column of $$[T]_\mathcal{B}$$, which we would expect to be $$\lambda_i \vec{e}_i$$.

Indeed, $$[T]_\mathcal{B}\vec{e}_i = ~_\mathcal{E}[I]_\mathcal{B}~[T]_\mathcal{E}~_\mathcal{E}[I]_\mathcal{B}~\vec{e}_i=~_\mathcal{E}[I]_\mathcal{B}~[T]_\mathcal{E}~\vec{v}_i=~_\mathcal{E}[I]_\mathcal{B}~\lambda_i\vec{v}_i=\lambda_i\vec{e}_i$$

Consider $$[T]_\mathcal{B}\vec{e}_i$$. This is extracting the $$i$$th column of $$[T]_\mathcal{B}$$, which we would expect to be $$\lambda_i \vec{e}_i$$.

Indeed, $$[T]_\mathcal{B}\vec{e}_i = ~_\mathcal{E}[I]_\mathcal{B}~[T]_\mathcal{E}~_\mathcal{E}[I]_\mathcal{B}~\vec{e}_i=~_\mathcal{E}[I]_\mathcal{B}~[T]_\mathcal{E}~\vec{v}_i=~_\mathcal{E}[I]_\mathcal{B}~\lambda_i\vec{v}_i=\lambda_i\vec{e}_i$$

From part b), we prove that an arbitrary vector $$\vec x$$ is a linear combination of the basis, so it is within the span of the basis, which means it can be mapped with the linear transformation associated to the basis. In other words, we can arrive at any $$\vec x$$ using the linear transformation which is the definition of onto / surjective.

In terms of proof tips:

There's a lot of different definitions to be familiar with in this course, but my approach has never been to simply practice memorizing them. Try the practice problems and see what pieces are needed to bring everything together. We need to go from point A to point B using the knowledge we've gained through the term, so I find trying a variety of problems helps me see that path more clearly. Once you see the given info, try to lay out everything you know about the start and the destination and see if you can recall any theorems we have to get between the two. It can definitely be tricky! 

Office hours have also been my go-to-- if there's something you don't fully understand, ask! Not sure what office hours are left at this point but Piazza may be a great resource

Bottom line: practice problems and office hours is the best advice I can give, although maybe others have good tips to share

We want to find a transformation $$T$$ such that if we apply it twice on some vector $$\vec{x}$$, it has the effect of multiplying $$\vec{x}$$ by $$-1$$. It is just saying that if we can find a matrix $$A$$ such that $$A^2 = -I_2$$, then $$T_A$$ will have this property since applying $$T_A$$ twice is just multiplying by $$A$$ twice, and

$$AA\vec{x} = -I_2\vec{x}=-\vec{x}$$ like we want

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T01:19:23Z", "content": "

$$\text{If V is a subspace of }\mathbb{F}^n, \text{ then }\bar{V} \cup\{\vec{0}\} \text{ is a subspace of }\mathbb{F}^n$$

Is this true or false?

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week9", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 58, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T01:35:14Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Milind Singh Meetarbhan", "endorser": {"lpvj0xmshic497": 1712170637}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwcbcphb86sf", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T01:35:14Z", "content": "What do you think?  Compare your solution to mine:  https://youtu.be/p9ZdlFQELZI?si=_k8j-3ttCzU-mgRq"}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwcbcphb86sf"], "children": [], "id": "luukhlaswd1x3", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T01:36:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T01:36:56Z", "content": "

I would think it is false but i may be wrong.

$$U=\mathbb{F}^n \backslash V$$ is the set of all elements in $$F^n$$ but not in V. Even if we have the zero vector, $$U$$ might not be closed under addition or scalar multiplication since the sum of two vectors in U may lie in V. 

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luukjry2cuv1sy", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I think $$V^c \cup \{\vec{0}\}$$ is closed under scalar multiplication though, If $$V$$ is a subspace and some vector $$\vec{x}\notin V$$, then $$c\vec{x}\notin V$$ for $$\forall c\neq0$$ (and $$0\vec{x}= \vec{0}$$), so if I'm not missing something the problem is just closure under addition", "created": "2024-04-11T01:42:08Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Actually, would it be true that $$\dim(V)\geq n-1\implies V^{c}\cup\{\vec{0}\}$$ is a subspace?  Im not sure if it is true that the dimension of the complement and $$V$$ need to add to $$n$$ if the complement is a subspace

Edit: nevermind this is not true

For the recommended questions, number 6.

Since the rank is less than n, it is not equal to n which means it is not invertible. So the determinant is equal to zero. 

since the determinant is the product of eigenvalues. One of the eigenvalues is zero.

There was also a theorem that said that if the matrix is invertible, 0 is an eigenvalue.

same way you find solution sets for other matrices.

$$x_2 = s$$

$$x_3 = t$$

and you'll get the solution set in the picture.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 67, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T05:09:20Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Anchang Yuan", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8n9v69s68t", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T05:09:20Z", "content": "

I think it's because to have a basis for R4, we require 4 vectors. So we add 4 vectors which we know span R4(the standard basis) and then we can row reduce to determine which of the 6 vectors are linearly independant(by looking at which columns have pivots in them), creating our basis for R4.\u00a0

\n

\n

Side note: I think because we put the two vectors we want at the first two columns of the matrix, that it ensures they are included in the basis since we are considering an ordered basis.

I was wondering if the following is a valid solution for part (b) of q8:

Suppose there exists such a linear map. Then $$T \circ T = \textrm{id}_3 \\$$ meaning $$[T \circ T]_\varepsilon = [T]_\varepsilon [T]_\varepsilon = [-\textrm{id}_3]_\varepsilon = -I_3$$ but then we take the determinant of both sides so $$\det([T]_\varepsilon [T]_\varepsilon) = \det([T]_\varepsilon)\det([T]_\varepsilon) = \det([T]_\varepsilon)^2 = \det(-I_3) = - 1$$ but the determinant is real so we have a contradiction.

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other"], "nr": 1286, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T08:55:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luv084d15qw3t2", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-11T08:55:46Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "luv7wx3s4yw2uz", "to": "luv084cuke83t1", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-11T12:31:00Z"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luv084cuke83t1", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-11T16:47:23Z", "cid": "luvh2m5dlux638", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "to": "luv084cuke83t1", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-11T16:50:29Z", "cid": "luvh6m22fy22nz"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Quiz 5", "created": "2024-04-11T08:55:46Z", "content": "Could someone please further expand on this for some reason despite the solution I'm not bale to understand. "}], "type": "question", "tags": ["other", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 56, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T12:31:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T12:31:00Z", "content": "

We have $$m$$ vectors in the spanning set, and we are working in $$\mathbb{F}^n$$. Recall that the dimension of a subspace is the number of vectors in the basis. 

We can get a basis from $$V$$ by taking the vectors in the spanning set as columns of a matrix, row reducing to RREF, then taking the original vectors whose columns contain a pivot. This means that the dimension cannot be greater than the number of vectors in the spanning set, since this process is not going to add any vectors, only potentially take them away. So we have that $$\dim(V)\leq m$$

The second part comes from this theorem: 

We can't have a subspace of $$\mathbb{F}^n$$ that has a greater dimension than $$\mathbb{F}^n$$ itself. 

Putting those two facts together, we have that $$\dim(V) \leq \min\{m,n\}$$

Hope that helps!

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["idt8cfyuv993c4", "kggoe9bxe5d42u"], "children": [], "id": "luv7wx3jux72uy", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "Beautiful explanation thank you so much", "created": "2024-04-11T16:47:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Oh wow, thanks! {"history_size": 1, "folders": ["final"], "nr": 1292, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T14:40:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luvcji7uer64sv", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-11T14:40:33Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "luvcpsyc5wd3g3", "to": "luvcji7nh4p4st", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-11T14:45:26Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "luvcqffif8s4rk", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-04-11T14:45:56Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "luvd2a5fiy85jf", "to": "luvcji7nh4p4st", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-11T14:55:09Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "diagnolizability test", "created": "2024-04-11T14:40:33Z", "content": "For the condition of h(lambda) is a constant polynomial. Can we understand in this way: the whole CA(lambda) equation will have root over F off h(lambda) is a constant polynomial? Thanks.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 79, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T14:45:26Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xiemin Wen", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwehxe2xz7ok", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T14:45:55Z", "content": "

Yes, basically if $$C_A(\lambda)$$ has $$n$$ roots in $$\mathbb{F}$$, it is diagonalizable over $$\mathbb{F}$$

The only case where this would not happen given some characteristic polynomial is if there is an irreducible quadratic polynomial, and this would mean it is not factorable over $$\mathbb{R}$$.

So $$h(\lambda)$$ has to be the constant polynomial for it to factor completely, as you said

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T14:45:26Z", "content": "

Yes, basically if $$C_A(\lambda)$$ has $$n$$ roots in $$\mathbb{F}$$, it is diagonalizable over $$\mathbb{F}$$

The only case where this would not happen if we have the characteristic polynomial is if there is an irreducible quadratic polynomial, and this would mean it is not factorable over $$\mathbb{R}$$.

So $$h(\lambda)$$ has to be the constant polynomial for it to factor completely, as you said

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehxe2xz7ok"], "children": [], "id": "luvcpsy05gh3g1", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T14:55:09Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Xiemin Wen", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwehxe2xz7ok", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Yue Yang", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwerfxazc1nt", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T14:55:09Z", "content": "We need to have $$n$$ roots with repetition to have any hope of diagonalizing the matrix.  So if you are factoring over the reals and some of the roots are non-real, then the matrix will not be diagonalizable.  If you have $$n$$ real roots, then you will need to go on and check that all of the geometric and algebraic multiplicities match. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehxe2xz7ok", "lkqwerfxazc1nt"], "children": [], "id": "luvd2a5a9k5je", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luvcji7nh4p4st", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 4, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457732420, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["final"], "nr": 1293, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T14:40:36Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "data": "luvcjkoxsflcr", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-11T14:40:36Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "data": "luvd8jugi9f7ga", "to": "luvcjkon7mucq", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-11T15:00:01Z"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "to": "luvcjkon7mucq", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-11T17:12:29Z", "cid": "luvhyw0qrspsx"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "to": "luvcjkon7mucq", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-11T23:24:08Z", "cid": "luvv8um74gq1bi"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "Practice Final Q10", "created": "2024-04-11T14:40:36Z", "content": "

This was my answer to practice final q10:

I have this theorem from class (here's a picture of my lecture notes):

Apologies for the bad handwriting, but the gist of it is that if the sum of the geometric multiplicities is $$n$$ then $$A$$ is diagonalizable. It's a little more powerful / useful than the Diagonalizability Test but I am unsure of whether the markers will recognize / accept this. The sample solutions are a lot more detailed than mine since they use the regular Diagonalizability Test.

I know it was mentioned in previous posts that we can just cite "by a theorem in lecture" but I just wanted to double check

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 76, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T15:00:01Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T15:00:01Z", "content": "I think you would want to explain this a bit more to be on the safe side. "}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luvd8juax9u7g9", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "

Here is my approach:

We have $$a_1\leq g_2 \leq a_2, ~a_2 \leq g_1 \leq a_1 \implies a_1 = a_2.$$

Now, $$g_2 \geq a_1 = a_2 \implies g_2 = a_2$$ and similarly $$g_1=a_1,$$ so $$A$$ is diagonalizable ($$h(x)$$ is constant since $$a_1+a_2=n$$)

I think the theorem you are using is where the diagonalizability test comes from - I wouldn't say its more powerful since the result also directly follows from the diagonalizability test, along with the fact that $$g_\lambda \leq a_\lambda$$

", "created": "2024-04-11T14:59:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

Based on the instructor response, we can use this without proof anyways! 

But here's a sketch of what I would do to prove this:

($$\Rightarrow$$)

the columns of $$A$$ are lin. indep. $$\Rightarrow$$ there is a pivot in each row by 8.3.6 pivots and lin. indep. $$\Rightarrow$$ rank(A)=m=n $$\Rightarrow$$ (invertibility criteria) A is invertible

($$\Leftarrow$$) A is invertible $$\Rightarrow$$ there is a pivot in each row $$\Rightarrow$$ 8.3.6 the columns are lin. indep. 

Hope that helps! :)

Is y an eigenvector of T(y) because it is in the form of Ay = $$\lambda$$y? 

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 66, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T15:34:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T15:34:31Z", "content": "

Yep! We have a theorem that the eigenvectors (and eigenvalues) of $$T(\vec x)$$ are the same as the eigenthings of $$A$$ where $$A$$ is the standard matrix associated to the linear transformation $$T$$

Basically to find the eigenthings of T, find the matrix for T and then find the eigenthings like we usually do with characteristic polynomials and such

Technically the form would be $$T(\vec x) = \lambda \vec x$$ but we already know that we can represent T as a matrix

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["tips"], "nr": 1301, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T16:04:34Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luvfjkgvc4u3gj", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-11T16:04:34Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "luvfmxqxfwccf", "to": "luvfjkgmrus3gi", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-11T16:07:11Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "luvfnu1c4u51r3", "type": "s_answer_update", "when": "2024-04-11T16:07:53Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luvfjkgmrus3gi", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-11T16:15:47Z", "cid": "luvfxzjhy592ii", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Question about rank of augmented matrix", "created": "2024-04-11T16:04:34Z", "content": "When asking about the rank of an augmented matrix [A|b], if the last pivot is in augmented part, do we consider it's rank same as rank(A) or rank(A)+1?"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "tips"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 49, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T16:07:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "instructor", "name": "Shane Bauman", "endorser": {}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "idt8cfyuv993c4", "photo_url": null, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T16:07:53Z", "content": "

if your matrix looks like this: $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 |& 3 \\ 0 & 0|& 1 \\ \end{bmatrix}$$, then the rank of A (without the the augmented section) is 1. but rank([A|b]) = 2. 

Does that answer your question?

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T16:07:11Z", "content": "

if your matrix looks like this: $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 &0 |& 3 \\ 0 & 0|& 3 \\ \end{bmatrix}$$, then the rank of A (without the the augmented section) is 1. but rank([A|b]) = 2. 

Does that answer your question?

Intuitively, you can think of it like this,

$$\mathbb{F}^n$$ is a $$n$$ dimensional space. We need at least $$n$$ vectors, each "giving access to a new dimension" to reach all of $$\mathbb{F}^n$$. 

In particular, adding a linearly independent vector a span is what gives access to a "new dimension", so $$n$$ linearly independent vectors will span $$\mathbb{F}^n$$. Therefore if you had more than $$n$$ vectors, they must be linearly dependent, since once $$n$$ are linearly independent, the next one has to be in the span of the first $$n$$ since they span $$\mathbb{F}^n$$

You can also think of it in terms of matrices, if $$\dim(V)=n$$, then forming the corresponding matrix with the linearly independent vectors in base of $$V$$, the rank would equal $$n$$ so the matrix is consistent for all $$\vec{b}\in\mathbb{F}^n$$, so it spans $$\mathbb{F}^n$$. If there were less than $$n$$, the rank would be less than $$n$$, and if there were more than $$n$$, there have to be free variables, meaning they would be linearly dependent, contradicting that they from a basis

The actual condition is for $$h(\lambda)$$ to be constant. $$h(\lambda)$$ is whatever is left over in the characteristic polynomial when you have factored all you can (into linear factors).

For instance, if $$C_A(\lambda)=(\lambda-1)(\lambda^2+1)$$, then $$h(\lambda)=\lambda^2+1$$ which is not constant. 

I'm not sure what you mean by the i being constant, note that $$h(\lambda)$$ would be constant if we were instead working in $$\mathbb{C}$$, since we could then factor $$\lambda^2+1$$

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week10", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 41, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T18:06:23Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Zhirui Lyu", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": "1700080244_200.jpg", "id": "lkqwehdad3p7l6", "photo_url": "https://cdn-uploads.piazza.com/photos/lkqwehdad3p7l6/1700080244_200.jpg", "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T18:06:23Z", "content": "The span of any set of elements is always a subspace, but to see why $$\text{Span}(S) \subseteq \text{Span}(T)$$, see that $$S \subseteq T$$, so any linear combination of elements in $$S$$ is also a linear combination of elements of $$T$$ (namely, the same elements, which happen to all be elements of $$T$$ anyway)."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwehdad3p7l6"], "children": [], "id": "luvjw81rdfo3cf", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luvjdoy69ja4ey", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457749639, "default_anonymity": "no"}

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week11", "student"], "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Vishesh Gupta", "endorser": {"lr5ecl50k5u23j": 1711835446}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwec73jwh6mz", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "unique_views": 72, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T18:33:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Abhinav Jha", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw929po8912g", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T18:33:15Z", "content": "Do you mean to explain the question statement, or to explain the solution method? The solution is that if we want to find a basis $$\mathcal B$$ so that $$[\text{refl}_{\vec n}]_{\mathcal B}$$, then we should expect that $$\mathcal B$$ is a basis of eigenvectors. Then, we can think about which vectors should be eigenvectors based on this reflection. Any vector on the plane should stay in the same spot after the reflection, and any normal vector should be reflected across the origin, i.e. $$T(\vec n) = -\vec n$$."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqw929po8912g"], "children": [], "id": "luvkury6wlr274", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwec73jwh6mz"], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luvkjbouqad6h8", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457755992, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["other", "final"], "nr": 1320, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T19:22:44Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luvmmeq3dwtrr", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-11T19:22:44Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "luvmv1d6zj0286", "to": "luvmmeptpjlrq", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-11T19:29:27Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luvmmeptpjlrq", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-11T19:34:50Z", "cid": "luvn1ym93nc67h", "uid_a": "a_0"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "[Similar Matrices and Characteristic Polynomial]", "created": "2024-04-11T19:22:44Z", "content": "

What would a proof for the fact that similar matrices have the same characteristic polynomial look like?  

Heres what I came up with but it feels too messy

$$A = P^{-1}BP$$

Say $$B\vec{x} = \lambda \vec{x}$$. Since $$B=PAP^{-1}$$ we have 
$$PAP^{-1}\vec{x} = B\vec{x}$$
$$PAP^{-1}\vec{x} = \lambda\vec{x}$$
(multiplying by $$P^{-1}$$) we get 

$$A(P^{-1}\vec{x}) = \lambda(P^{-1}\vec{x})$$
So A and B share the same eigenvalues

anyone have an easier way?

I'm no expert, but as a piece of advice, just try considering what information you have, and what you are looking to prove before you solve the problem. Think about what it would mean by definition to prove what are you trying to prove. Also, I find that a large amount of proofs rely heavily on the use of just basic definitions, and being able to string different ideas together, so understanding concepts like what it means for a set of vectors to be linearly independant, what defines a basis, etc is important.

Don't stress too much, study as hard as you can and I'm sure you will do great!

If we are told that a linear transformation is one-to-one then does that mean it is linearly independent.

And what information could we use in a proof if given that the transformation was onto (I know it means the range(T) = F^n but I am a bit confused on how to utilize this in a proof).

Thanks.

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 54, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T20:52:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Danielle Alterman", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwb4wzraz68t", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwerfxazc1nt", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T20:54:03Z", "content": "- " If we are told that a linear transformation is one-to-one then does that mean it is linearly independent." We can also say $$Col(A) = \mathbb F^n$$, $$rank(A) = m$$, refer to the Onto Criteria."}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwerfxazc1nt", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T20:52:31Z", "content": "- " If we are told that a linear transformation is one-to-one then does that mean it is linearly independent." Q1. Let A be a n x n invertible matrix. Determine det(adj(A)).

Q2. Let $$X = [ \vec{v}_1 \dots \vec{v}_k]$$ and $$Y = [\vec{u}_1 \dots \vec{u}_k]$$ be n x k matrices. Prove that if $$ Span\{\vec{v}_1, \dots, \vec{v}_k\} \subseteq Span\{\vec{u}, \dots, \vec{u_k} \}$$, then there exists Z such that X = YZ

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 79, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T20:55:02Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T20:56:10Z", "content": "

Hints:

  1. We know $$\mathrm{adj}(A)\cdot A = \det(A)\, I_n$$. Throwing determinant carefully gives $$\det(\mathrm{adj}(A))=...$$
  2. Since the span of $$v_i$$ is contained the span of $$u_i$$, each $$v_i$$ can be linearly expressed by $$u_i$$. The coefficients of these linear expressions naturally give you the desired matrix $$Z$$. 

I will leave the details for you all to complete.

I did see someone suggest substituting u = $$4 - \lambda$$ if thats something you want to try."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwcmng7k212i", "kggoe9bxe5d42u"], "children": [], "id": "luvrc7bzglu3ao", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T22:23:11Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Shihan Sharar", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1702155408, "lpvj0xmshic497": 1706729797, "lr5ecl50k5u23j": 1709240524, "global": 1711544832, "lqzes2lznxt50s": 1712859771}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdbxatel6pr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Abhinav Jha", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw929po8912g", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T22:28:34Z", "content": "

$$ \det\begin{pmatrix} 4-\lambda & 2 & 2\\ 2 & 4-\lambda &2\\ 2 & 2 & 4-\lambda \end{pmatrix}$$

$$= \det\begin{pmatrix} 4-\lambda & 2 & 2\\ 2 & 4-\lambda &2\\ 0 & 0 & 2-\lambda \end{pmatrix} + \det\begin{pmatrix} 4-\lambda & 2 & 2\\ 2 & 4-\lambda &2\\ 2 & 2 & 2 \end{pmatrix} $$

$$= (2-\lambda)\det\begin{pmatrix} 4-\lambda & 2 \\  2 & 4-\lambda \end{pmatrix} + \det\begin{pmatrix} 2-\lambda & 0 & 0\\ 0 & 2-\lambda &0\\ 2 & 2 & 2 \end{pmatrix} $$

$$= (2-\lambda) (\lambda^2-8\lambda+12)+2(2-\lambda)^2 = (2-\lambda)(\lambda^2 - 10\lambda +16) = (2-\lambda)(\lambda-2)(\lambda-8)$$

where the formula

$$ \det\begin{pmatrix} a_1+b_1 & a_2+b_2 & a_3+b_3 \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \end{pmatrix} = \det\begin{pmatrix} a_1 & a_2 & a_3 \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \end{pmatrix} + \det\begin{pmatrix} b_1 & b_2 & b_3 \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \end{pmatrix}$$

holds for any row and column. In fact this directly follows from the row/column expansion of determinant.

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "llux8psc8tj5zh", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T22:23:11Z", "content": "

$$ \det\begin{pmatrix} 4-\lambda & 2 & 2\\ 2 & 4-\lambda &2\\ 2 & 2 & 4-\lambda \end{pmatrix}$$

$$= \det\begin{pmatrix} 4-\lambda & 2 & 2\\ 2 & 4-\lambda &2\\ 0 & 0 & 2-\lambda \end{pmatrix} + \det\begin{pmatrix} 4-\lambda & 2 & 2\\ 2 & 4-\lambda &2\\ 2 & 2 & 2 \end{pmatrix} $$

$$= (2-\lambda)\det\begin{pmatrix} 4-\lambda & 2 \\  2 & 4-\lambda \end{pmatrix} + \det\begin{pmatrix} 2-\lambda & 0 & 0\\ 2 & 4-\lambda &2\\ 2 & 2 & 2 \end{pmatrix} $$

$$= (2-\lambda) (\lambda^2-8\lambda+12)+(2-\lambda)(4-2\lambda) = (2-\lambda)(\lambda^2 - 10\lambda +16) = (2-\lambda)(\lambda-2)(\lambda-8)$$

where the formula

$$ \det\begin{pmatrix} a_1+b_1 & a_2+b_2 & a_3+b_3 \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \end{pmatrix} = \det\begin{pmatrix} a_1 & a_2 & a_3 \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \end{pmatrix} + \det\begin{pmatrix} b_1 & b_2 & b_3 \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \\ \ast & \ast & \ast \end{pmatrix}$$

holds for any row and column. In fact this directly follows from the row/column expansion of determinant.

Why does the fact that the col(A) is independent imply that A is invertible?\u00a0"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["student", "tips"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 68, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T22:37:15Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T22:37:15Z", "content": "Only square matrices are invertible. Besides that, if you have n vectors in $$\\mathbb{F}^n$$ which are linearly independent then yes, the nxn matrix formed by inserting those vectors as columns is invertible.

To understand why just think of rank. The matrix A would row reduce to the identity since the vectors are linearly independent. So RREF(A) = In which is in our invertibility criteria. Thus the matrix is invertible."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luvtkjyo64623o", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I forgot that only invertible matrices are invertible LOL...", "created": "2024-04-12T00:01:32Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luvwky4inhv2i9", "updated": "2024-04-12T00:05:55Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luvt1hmbjc95t2", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457786245, "default_anonymity": "no"}

Hello,

We have a number of theorems which place a bound on certain values. For example, rank bounds restricts the rank of a mxn matrix to min{m, n}. Another is how geometric multiplicity is always bound by algebraic multiplicity.

I noticed these theorems are especially useful when making contradictions in proofs, so I wanted to ask if there are any more "bounding" theorems. I tried thinking about one for dimension but was a little confused so I figured I should ask instead.

Thanks!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 66, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-11T23:27:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750, "llazq0fual03ej": 1702407827, "global": 1707613189}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}, {"role": "student", "name": "Sampoorna Prakash", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1697050635}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "kggoe9bxe5d42u", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqw8iusqnz5hk", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-11T23:27:21Z", "content": "

The dimension is bounded by $$n$$ (from $$\mathbb{F}^n$$) and 0.

Also from what I've come to realize there is no such connection between invertibility and the matrix being diagonalizable."}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week11", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 52, "children": [{"history_size": 3, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-12T00:51:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Abhinav Jha", "endorser": {}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw929po8912g", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-12T00:52:03Z", "content": "

Yeah if the algebraic multiplicities are all 1, then A is diagonalizable since the geometric multiplicities will also always equal to 1.

Also yeah, in general there isn't really a connection between diagonalizability and invertibility.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-12T00:51:33Z", "content": "

Yeah if the algebraic multiplicities are all 1, then A is diagonalizable since the geometric multiplicity will always equal to 1.

Also yeah, in general there isn't really a connection between diagonalizability and invertibility.

"}, {"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-12T00:51:21Z", "content": "

Yeah if the algebraic multiplicities are all 1, then A is diagonalizable since the geometric multiplicity will always equal to 1, hence A will be diagonalizable.

Hint: what are the eigenvectors?", "created": "2024-04-12T02:31:07Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luw1xazl8zp6dd", "updated": "2024-04-12T02:31:07Z", "config": {"editor": "md"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "There wouldn't be real eigenvalues right?", "created": "2024-04-12T02:35:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luw22b4r5fhtg", "updated": "2024-04-12T02:35:00Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

As a followup to your hint, I guess the vector $$\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1  \end{bmatrix}$$ would be essentially multiplied by -1 when rotated. Same with $$\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$. But that's just one Eigenvalue, are there any more?

Also would this question work if you didn't choose a rotation by pi? Like say a rotation by $$\frac{3\pi }{4}$$. Would you be able to determine the effect of a scalar multiple vs there operator?

", "created": "2024-04-12T02:46:10Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luw2gntn9fm7n1", "updated": "2024-04-12T02:46:10Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "I feel like if its by like 3pi/4, I don't think you could come up with any real eigenvalues. Geometrically, what vector could you rotate by 3pi/4 to get a scalar multiple of that vector", "created": "2024-04-12T02:54:33Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "ta", "name": "Frank Wang", "endorser": {"lhfjfa06czd637": 1691414307}, "admin": true, "photo": null, "id": "krvaikp4js87pd", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["krvaikp4js87pd"], "id": "luw2rg4ctjr5ui", "updated": "2024-04-12T02:59:04Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "A rotation by $$\pi$$ is the same as a reflection, so there would be real eigenvalues. In general, however, the eigenvalues of a rotation tend to have non-trivial imaginary parts.", "created": "2024-04-12T02:59:59Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luw2yfmqmko6h9", "updated": "2024-04-12T02:59:59Z", "config": {"editor": "md"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Would the process to solving this question simply just finding the eigenvalues of the standard matrix, determining corresponding eigenvectors and create a basis out of those vectors?", "created": "2024-04-12T03:01:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luw30d6ytt86m", "updated": "2024-04-12T03:01:29Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Yes, because we have a basis of eigenvectors, we know that in that basis, the linear transformation must be diagonal (with diagonal entries being the corresponding eigenvalues).", "created": "2024-04-12T03:33:05Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luw44zo6n4n6x9", "updated": "2024-04-12T03:33:05Z", "config": {"editor": "md"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luw1hyifrkx724", "updated": "2024-04-12T03:33:07Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luw0xit5qul4ri", "config": {"has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": {}, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 7, "num_favorites": 2, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457804280, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["final"], "nr": 1362, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-12T02:53:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luw2pw68op5346", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-12T02:53:21Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "data": "luw2rpvwfdj47o", "to": "luw2pw60xre345", "type": "s_answer", "when": "2024-04-12T02:54:46Z", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luw2pw60xre345", "type": "followup", "when": "2024-04-12T02:56:31Z", "cid": "luw2tz6uidf3eq", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luw2pw60xre345", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-12T02:58:12Z", "cid": "luw2w5a26h96k4", "uid_a": "a_2"}, {"anon": "stud", "to": "luw2pw60xre345", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-12T02:58:43Z", "cid": "luw2wssnjcdcs", "uid_a": "a_1"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "to": "luw2pw60xre345", "type": "feedback", "when": "2024-04-12T03:02:00Z", "cid": "luw311apf7c4lf"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "Proving linear independence vs proving spanning set for basis", "created": "2024-04-12T02:53:21Z", "content": "

Hello,

In my lectures, I remember my prof would say that when we are proving a basis spans $$\mathbb{F^n}$$ we need n vectors, and then we could prove they are linearly independent or that they are a spanning set.

However, he basically always chose to prove linear independence. Could someone explain how the other option would work? How do we prove the vectors are a spanning set? Or is proving linear independence the only way?

Thank you!

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 113, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-12T02:54:46Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_1", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-12T02:54:46Z", "content": "There’s a theorem that states n vectors span F^n iff they are linearly independent. If you prove they are LI, they are also a spanning set."}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luw2rpvmmbj47m", "config": {}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "I understand but is there a way to go the other way and prove they are a spanning set first, and then get that the vectors are LI for free? My professor often said it like we had a choice, and I just want to make sure I understand the multiple strategies.", "created": "2024-04-12T02:56:31Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_0", "children": [{"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "The statement is an if and only if. You can prove either.", "created": "2024-04-12T02:58:12Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [], "uid_a": "a_2", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": [], "id": "luw2w5a26h96k4", "updated": "2024-04-12T02:58:12Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}, {"anon": "stud", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "Sure I guess you can do something like using the invertibility criteria. And if rank=n, you have that column space is F^n.", "created": "2024-04-12T02:58:43Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750, "llazq0fual03ej": 1702407827, "global": 1707613189}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid_a": "a_1", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwca7ky8m6lh"], "id": "luw2wssnjcdcs", "updated": "2024-04-12T02:59:18Z", "config": {}}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "You can prove either. To show that $$\{\vec v_1, \ldots, \vec v_n\}$$ spanning, you would show that for any $$\vec x \in \mathbb F^n$$, there exist scalars $$c_1, \ldots, c_n$$ so that $$\vec x = c_1 \vec v_1 + \cdots + c_n \vec v_n$$", "created": "2024-04-12T03:02:00Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "feedback", "tag_good": [{"role": "student", "name": "Mustafa Mian", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1698000750, "llazq0fual03ej": 1702407827, "global": 1707613189}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwca7ky8m6lh", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "children": [], "tag_good_arr": ["lkqwca7ky8m6lh"], "id": "luw311apf7c4lf", "updated": "2024-04-12T03:07:55Z", "config": {"editor": "md"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luw2tz6uidf3eq", "updated": "2024-04-12T03:35:20Z", "config": {"editor": "rte"}}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luw2pw60xre345", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 5, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457807462, "default_anonymity": "no"}

{"history_size": 1, "folders": ["practice_week11"], "nr": 1363, "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-12T02:57:16Z", "bucket_order": 3, "no_answer_followup": 0, "change_log": [{"anon": "stud", "data": "luw2uy5vx683px", "v": "all", "type": "create", "when": "2024-04-12T02:57:16Z", "uid_a": "a_0"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "data": "luw4ao1n9jx1tc", "to": "luw2uy5cl8q3pv", "type": "i_answer", "when": "2024-04-12T03:37:29Z"}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "stud", "uid_a": "a_0", "subject": "if det(A - $$\\lambda I$$) = 0, then how is $$a_{\\lambda}$$ = 2", "created": "2024-04-12T02:57:16Z", "content": ""}], "type": "question", "tags": ["practice_week11", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 149, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-12T03:37:29Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Shihan Sharar", "endorser": {"lm6xvdp0poj2ah": 1702155408, "lpvj0xmshic497": 1706729797, "lr5ecl50k5u23j": 1709240524, "global": 1711544832, "lqzes2lznxt50s": 1712859771}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqwdbxatel6pr", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "krvaikp4js87pd", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-12T03:37:29Z", "content": "The algebraic multiplicity $$a_\\lambda$$ is determined by looking at the degree of the root in the characteristic polynomial.\n\nThe characteristic polynomial is $$c_A(x) = (x - \\lambda)^2$$ (note that this is a polynomial in $$x$$, not $$\\lambda$$, since our usual parameter $$\\lambda$$ is already a variable). Thus, we can see that the root $$x = \\lambda$$ has degree $$2$$ in the polynomial."}], "type": "i_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": ["lkqwdbxatel6pr"], "children": [], "id": "luw4ao1fjo21tb", "config": {"editor": "md"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}], "tag_good_arr": [], "no_answer": 0, "id": "luw2uy5cl8q3pv", "config": {"editor": "rte", "has_emails_sent": 1}, "status": "active", "drafts": null, "request_instructor": 0, "request_instructor_me": false, "bookmarked": 3, "num_favorites": 0, "my_favorite": false, "is_bookmarked": false, "is_tag_good": false, "q_edits": [], "i_edits": [], "s_edits": [], "t": 1714457808517, "default_anonymity": "no"}

I understand the upper left matrix's characteristic polynomials is $$(\lambda_i-\lambda)$$, but how can we just multiple the two characteristic polynomials(cp) to get the  cp for the whole matrix? Thank you"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 193, "children": [{"history_size": 1, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-12T04:21:56Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-12T04:21:56Z", "content": "

Consider actually finding the characteristic polynomial and expanding by the first column, then the second column, and so on.

It should seem similar to this

"}], "type": "s_answer", "tag_endorse_arr": [], "children": [], "id": "luw5vtazind20x", "config": {"editor": "rte"}, "is_tag_endorse": false}, {"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "no_upvotes": 0, "subject": "But we don’t know what is M1 and M2, so this is not necessarily an upper or lower triangle. Could you explain more? Thanks", "created": "2024-04-12T12:04:28Z", "bucket_order": 3, "bucket_name": "Today", "type": "followup", "tag_good": [], "uid": "lkqwelvposqnn", "children": [{"anon": "no", "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": null}, "subject": "

We don't need to know $$M_1$$. We know the matrix in the bottom left is the zero matrix, so we can just use column expansions. Maybe my answer was a little confusing - I didn't mean it is an upper/lower triangular matrix I just meant that when you calculate the determinant, its similar as to when you try to calculate the determinant of a upper/lower triangular matrix.

To calculate determinant, expand along the first column, which should reduce to $$(\lambda_i - \lambda)(\text{sub matrix determinant})$$. Then if you expand along the first column of the submatrix, you get $$(\lambda_i - \lambda)(\text{"sub sub" matrix determinant})$$, all the way until you get $$(\lambda_i - \lambda)^k(\det(M_2-\lambda))$$

I know it's early but I was wondering what the marking will be like if there was a small arithmetic error. 

For Q1, I think I made an error in my row reductions to get A-1 and I was wondering whether marks would be deducted for part b since you needed to use the inverse determined in part a. Also how many marks are usually deducted for arithmetic errors in matrix calculations

Thanks

"}], "type": "question", "tags": ["final", "student"], "tag_good": [], "unique_views": 271, "children": [{"history_size": 2, "folders": [], "data": {"embed_links": []}, "created": "2024-04-12T16:13:21Z", "bucket_order": 3, "tag_endorse": [{"role": "student", "name": "Andy Lau Moon Lin", "endorser": {"lqzes2lznxt50s": 1712852226}, "admin": false, "photo": null, "id": "lkqw8dqa8gc4mm", "photo_url": null, "published": true, "us": false, "facebook_id": null}], "bucket_name": "Today", "history": [{"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-12T16:13:26Z", "content": "

I think for Q1 if you made a small mistake in the row reductions, it would probably be 1/2 or 1 mark off, and I don't think they would remove a point when you find $$\vec{x}$$ with the incorrect matrix.

You can also check your work during the test to see if $$A^{-1}$$ and $$\vec{x}$$ are correct, though it does take some time

"}, {"anon": "no", "uid": "lkqwdweou4p2j4", "subject": "", "created": "2024-04-12T16:13:21Z", "content": "
